PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Financial Constraints
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the imposition of sales tax, import duties and other financial constraints on Telecom Australia will have effects of:
Increasing local and STD call charges.
Increasing telephone rental charges.
Increasing delays in providing services to new, rural, most small business and domestic subscribers.
Decreasing service standards generally.
Leading to the destruction of the Australian telecommunications manufacturing industry.
Increasing the internal and external pressures for the deregulation and/or privatisation of Telecom Australia.
Leading to the abandonment of the ``service to all Australians'' principle on which Telecom Australia has always operated if deregulation and/or privatisation continues further.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government revokes its recent decisions applying extra financial burdens on Telecom Australia and takes appropriate steps to ensure that Telecom Australia has the legal, and financial ability to discharge its statutory obligations to provide universal service under its present monopoly status as the national telecommunications provider. Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Cooney (from eight citizens) and Zakharov (from 48 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Preservation of the Environment: Referendum
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

But for a High Court decision narrowly favouring the Federal Government, 20,000 years old archaeological cave sites near the Franklin River, Tasmania, would have been destroyed, like a United Kingdom Government unable to stop a Wiltshire authority from clearing Stonehenge for a freeway. Constitutional protection for historical and environmental assets is needed.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to hold a referendum to amend the Constitution so that:

The Federal Government has the bounden constitutional duty, which any citizen may legally require it to perform and a right superior to state and local governments, to set above the commercial advantage of one generation, protect and restore all we hold in trust for the future-

Including relics, sites, features, areas, wildlife, buildings or things of Aboriginal and other historical, cultural, architectural, scientific, aesthetic, ecological or environmental importance, and-

To care for the maintenance of the balance of nature, manage land, marine and atmospheric use so as to avoid their degradation and act nationally and internationally in any matter seen as related to these, including-

To prevent military and commercial use of uranium and derivatives, beach and related mining; to preserve Heritage Areas, The Great Barrier Reef Region at least as originally defined in the 1975 Act and extended into Torres Strait.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That the Constitution of the Commonwealth has served Australia well, is not out of date, has proved to be flexible and should not be radically altered.

2. Our deep concern that the recommendations of the Constitutional Commission and its advisory committees which propose radical changes to the Constitution are threatening to reduce our rights as citizens of the Commonwealth.

3. Our strongest opposition to any referendum proposals of the Hawke Government which gives more power to the Government and less to the people and which concentrates that power in Canberra at the expense of the States and weakens the role of the Senate.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Durack (from 140 citizens) and Panizza (from 14 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth.
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide independent radio and television service.
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Release of Confidential Medical Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizen, respectfully showeth:

That we express grave concern about the public release of confidential medical information by the Government, sufficient to enable the public identification of Doctors and their patients and calls upon the Parliament to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the privacy of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes: Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out that aged and disabled people who require accommodation and support in nursing homes are entitled to the highest possible standard and quality of nursing care.

We the petitioners, request the Government to ensure that provision of funds for nursing homes in Victoria is sustained at least at a level sufficient to maintain the high standard of care now available in nursing homes in this State.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Patterson (from 15,613 citizens) and Robert Ray (from nine citizens).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MACKLIN

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate a petition, from 410 citizens, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form, praying that the Senate request the Government to oppose the process of food irradiation.

SPEECH.PARA: Petitions received.
Senator LEWIS (Victoria)-I seek leave to make a short statement about petitions not in conformity with Standing Orders.
Leave granted.

Senator LEWIS-The coalition parties have become concerned about the large number of petitions not in conformity with Standing Orders which seem always to be presented on broadcast days. As a result of that, I have indicated to Senator Robert Ray, on the Government side, and Senator Haines of the Australian Democrats-and I now publicly indicate this to Senator Wood and Senator Vallentine-that hereafter the coalition parties will refuse leave for the presentation of petitions not in conformity with Standing Orders on broadcast days, so that they may be given then on non-broadcast days.

Senator ROBERT RAY (Victoria-Minister for Home Affairs)-by leave-The Government takes the same view as the coalition on this matter. Whilst not imputing motives to people presenting these petitions, I point out that five or six years ago, when we used to abuse the petition process when in opposition, we had a long debate on this matter. I might just say that one day I counted 45 minutes of reading out petitions. That is why we got rid of that process. If it is relegated to non-radio days, there can be no accusation that anyone is trying to duck the system, and it still maintains the democratic rights of senators to present petitions not in conformity with Standing Orders. The Government agrees with the Opposition, and we also will be opposing the presentation of these petitions on radio days.

Senator HARRADINE (Tasmania)-by leave-This is the first time I have heard of this proposal. The right is available to any honourable senator to refuse leave if he or she considers that it is not appropriate for this to occur on broadcast days. Other than that, if it is to be a general rule, the appropriate procedure to be followed would be to refer the matter to the Standing Orders Committee for consideration and report to the Senate, so that matters upon which that Committee has reported can be properly discussed and debated in this chamber. If that is what Senator Lewis and Senator Ray want as a general rule, that is what they should do-not exercise de facto power on behalf of the Government or the Opposition to decide what shall or shall not be done. That is what the Standing Orders Committee is for and that is the procedure it should follow.

(b) further notes growing opposition around the world to nuclear power since the accident and the continued slowing down of the nuclear industry in terms of the construction of new plants;

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (URANIUM CONCENTRATE EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 April, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Lewis had moved by way of amendment:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the Hawke Government should be condemned:

(a) for its failure to limit the role, the duties and the accountability of the Office of the Supervising Scientist in the light of 10 years' experience in its monitoring of the Alligator Rivers region, the grant of self-government to the Northern Territory and the establishment of the University College of the Northern Territory; and
(b) for the imposition of this additional levy on uranium at a time when Australian uranium exporters are struggling to remain competitive on world markets''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been discussing the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1988. As I said in my earlier remarks, this Bill seeks to raise the duty on exported uranium concentrate mined in the Alligator Rivers region. This is to support the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS), which has been doing an excellent job of monitoring results of uranium mining in Kakadu National Park and which is a necessary part of the operation of the mine itself. I would like now to take a look at the uses of the uranium. Some organisation-may be beyond the scope of the OSS, certainly beyond the scope of the Australian Safeguards office-should be looking after the use of the concentrate, where it goes, and how it is tracked through the system. I will not go through all the details but in the past few months there have been revelations in Europe that our uranium basically enters a worldwide pool of uranium. The atoms enter the pool and we track the paper through our safeguards systems but we do not track the atoms. Our uranium has been involved in a swap in Europe which has caused a scandal in which three people in the two companies involved have committed suicide. In fact, Nukem and Transnuklear have been closed down. They have admitted to $14m in bribes. It is a massive scandal in Europe and our uranium was involved through flag swapping.

SPEECH.PARA: More recently, we have seen surfacing Euratom documents which show that it is enthusiastic about flag swapping, and they actually maintain that Australia should be `re-educated' in relation to the need for flag swapping-`re-educated' is the exact word used in the Euratom documents. Today at 1.30 there will be a Press conference where Ms Undine-Ura Bloch von Blottnitz will tell of an incident in Europe where South African uranium and Australian uranium have been involved with the Soviet Union-swapping involving South African uranium intended to go to the Soviet Union. Ms Undine-Ura Bloch von Blottnitz is a member of the Greens Party and a member of the European Parliament and she has passed most of the documents in relation to flag swaps to me and to others. She will lay on the table this evidence, which represents another frightening indictment of the fact that we simply do not know what happens to our uranium.

The Government's response over this issue has been predictable. It has manned the barricades and simply dug a hole. It has said that everything is fine, that it will not change, that its position is static and fixed. Its position should not be fixed because there are great difficulties with the Government's present position in relation to uranium, and certainly there are equivalent difficulties with the Opposition's stance. On Thursday, 21 April 1988, I asked a question in Parliament of the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook). In my question I referred to an article in the December 1984-January 1985 edition of Cogemagazine, which is the journal of the French company Cogema, which is responsible for producing nuclear reactor and bomb fuel in France. The article is entitled `The enrichment factory's function in stages' and it states that the low and medium level cascades in the Pierrelatte military uranium enrichment plant were closed in October 1982, leaving only the high level cascades operating. I point out that at Pierrelatte low and medium level enrichment of a batch of uranium must occur before high level enrichment. The only other place where low and medium level enrichment is possible in France is at the Tricastin enrichment plant since Pierrelatte closed down its first two stages.

In this chamber on 22 August 1986 the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) said that Australian uranium was enriched at Tricastin, which he then described as a civil nuclear enrichment facility. I asked Senator Cook a number of questions as to whether he was aware of this and whether it indicated that our uranium from Ranger was entering what is in fact a joint military-civil plant at Tricastin. Senator Cook replied:

I am pleased to observe also from the question that at last there is a recognition that there are two French factories, the Tricastin factory and the Pierrelatte factory, and that the Tricastin one enriches for the civil program and the Pierrelatte factory enriches for the weapons program.
I did not say that at all. Senator Cook continued:

Up to 20 per cent is enriched for the civil program, and up to 90 per cent for the weapons program. The important point to make in answering Senator Sanders's question is that Australian uranium goes to the Tricastin plant-
he did admit this-
and not the Pierrelatte plant . . .
At this point I interjected and the Hansard record continues:

TALK.START.PARA: —But they have closed down the first stage at Pierrelatte.

—It is entirely irrelevant, in terms of Australian uranium, whether the first or all of the stages at Pierrelatte have been closed down, because Pierrelatte is dedicated to the making of bombs. Australian origin nuclear material is put into the civil cycle in France, which is, as Senator Sanders properly identified, the Tricastin plant.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook, the Minister in charge of this matter in this chamber, is obviously ignorant of the functions of the Tricastin plant and did not understand the question. He did not understand the situation in France and he does not understand that our uranium, once it goes to France, enters a joint civil-military plant. There is no guarantee that our uranium does not end up in French bombs-no guarantee whatsoever, except that the French tell us that it does not end up in bombs. The French tell us that; the safeguards do not say it. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, the Minister in this chamber, Senator Cook, and Hans Blix of the International Atomic Energy Agency have all said that we cannot track our molecules of uranium but we can track equivalent amounts. That is not good enough. We want to know where our uranium is going once it leaves the Ranger mine. We need an organisation, such as the Office of the Supervising Scientist, but further downstream, to track our uranium. This organisation must have the funds and the will-and the Government must have the political will-to find out where our uranium is going. In fact, I say with certainty that our uranium-some of our molecules-has ended up in French bombs which were exploded at Mururoa.

There is another track for our uranium. As I discovered in Finland last August, that track is through the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. When Finland bought uranium from us it first went to France where it was made into a gas at Tricastin. From there it went to the Soviet Union where it was enriched. The enriched uranium was then sent to West Germany or Sweden where it was made into fuel rods, and then it ended up in Finland. There is a good chance that our molecules of uranium have actually ended up in Soviet weapons-statistically it is a certainty. Are we to continue exporting uranium when we cannot control it, when there is a statistical certainty that it has ended up in French bombs-which we protest against in the Pacific-and in Soviet nuclear weapons? Many on the Opposition side would claim that the Soviet Union is our greatest threat to peace. They say we must guard ourselves against Soviet nuclear weapons with the presence of the United States bases here. Yet the Opposition condones the use of our own uranium in Soviet weapons. I would like to hear the Opposition's opinion on this. I doubt very much whether Opposition members would condone this, yet they are doing so when they advocate the shipment of uranium from Ranger or anywhere else in Australia into the world uranium pool. There is only one obvious conclusion that can be drawn from all this: since there are no safeguards on our uranium it must be left in the ground.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1988 amends the 1980 Act to incorporate the tariff proposal of the 1987-88 Budget. It increases the duty on uranium mined in the Alligator Rivers region from 80c to $1.02 per kilogram as from September 1987. The duty is to support the supervisory, coordination and research roles of the Office of the Supervising Scientist and is expected to raise $600,000 in the financial year and $900,000 over the full year, which is estimated to cover 75 per cent of the costs of the Office of Supervising Scientist. The Australian Democrats have proposed amendments to increase the export duty on uranium concentrate to $1.36 a kilo to cover 100 per cent of the costs of the operation of the Office of the Supervising Scientist.

SPEECH.PARA: I will speak in support of both the amendment and the Bill. Even though I do not support in principle the mining of uranium, it is at least welcome that the Bill moves towards the recovery of more of the cost of the monitoring of the uranium industry-an industry which, I might say, is heavily subsidised by the taxpayer. Whilst I will continue to work as hard as I can for the closure of all uranium mines in Australia, at least in the interim it is not at all unreasonable to expect that those companies which will get the profits from the mining of uranium should also pay the costs, not the taxpayers. Why should taxpayers' money be used to provide the infrastructure necessary for the mining companies? It is adding insult to injury to ask taxpayers to pay for the service of monitoring the environmental impact of uranium mining in the heart of one of their national parks and an area of international significance.

The Office of the Supervising Scientist was set up under the Fraser Government after the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry. Its role is regulatory-monitoring and research-and it collaborates with the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation. The Office of the Supervising Scientist monitors tailings storage and worker health-exposure to radiation. The Office will be very important in the future in monitoring the water disposal, the revegetation and all of the other very real problems associated with the decommissioning of the Nabarlek mine. I will come to this matter later, but one of the things which economists on both sides of the House tend to ignore in their economic models is the end cost of disposing the waste.

The Alligator Rivers region is 220 kilometres east of Darwin and covers an area of 28,000 square kilometres. Much of it is Aboriginal land with many sites of great cultural significance to the Aboriginal people. It is of outstanding universal value as an area of unique natural beauty and includes examples of an enormous range of ecosystems. The Alligator Rivers region includes Ranger, Jabiluka and Koongarra.

Anyone who doubts the devastating impact of uranium mining and the environmental damage caused by the mining of uranium needs only to look back at what the mining at Rum Jungle inflicted on the environment. The mining created major pollution by heavy metals, sulphate and acids which leached into the East Finniss River. The rehabilitation cost was in the region of $16m.

The Office of the Supervising Scientist can monitor Ranger but it cannot prevent accidents. For example, in February this year about 10 cubic metres of contaminated treatment material overflowed into a drainage system and from there into a waste retention pond. The problem is that the Office of the Supervising Scientist can monitor but cannot prevent that sort of thing from happening. The Office can tell us when such an incident occurs, but once the damage occurs it is too late. Since 1981 there has been a legacy of spills of radioactive waste, diesel oil and contaminated water at the mine. Numerous tailing pipes have broken down. Between 1981 and 1986, 24 incidents relating to water management have been of concern. Sixteen of those incidents involved pipeline failure.

The situation became so severe that the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy, who is hardly known as a rabid conservationist or a rampant greenie, ordered the company not to use the tailing pipes until they were repaired. I would not have terribly much confidence in mine management, either in its ability or intentions, in terms of environmental protection. This places a great burden on the Office of the Supervising Scientist. Under the environmental protection legislation, a company must take the option that produces minimal environmental impact within reasonable economic constraints. The question is: what is a reasonable risk? Ranger appears consistently to have avoided seriously examining wider options which are more expensive, such as more storage dams, which would be the better option. Ranger prefers, as does any other large economic enterprise, the cheapest option.

In the past the Government has been prepared repeatedly to compromise its environmental integrity. Last year it decided to allow periodic contaminated water releases in direct opposition to the report of the then House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment and Conservation. That Committee was highly critical of some of Ranger's operations, such as the high number of spillages, the sulphur dump state, the exposed chemicals around the place and the unfenced tailings area in which animals were seen to traipse through continually. Even the House of Representatives Standing Committee described the company's operations as warranting criticism and said that the number of failures was alarming. We have yet to see just how much more mining will be allowed in this environmentally sensitive area-for example, in Coronation Hill, where there is gold and platinum, and the conservation zone of Kakadu stage 3. It is simply not enough to trust the platitudes of the industry or the technology that it will employ. We are talking about the World Heritage wetland area in which the risks are just too great.

It is of concern that the Office of the Supervising Scientist is expressing views on water release which are in direct contradiction of the wishes of the Aboriginal custodians. I believe that the wishes of the Aboriginal custodians should be predominant over the current scientific advice; that the traditional owners' points of view should take precedence. This raises a thorny question, which I will not avoid: that of Aboriginal support in the Northern Territory for uranium mining. I believe that the choice should rest with the traditional owners, even if that choice is to mine uranium. I would seek to dissuade them from such a decision. I would seek to present points of view to them, but, in the final analysis, I believe-I have campaigned strongly for Aboriginal sovereignty-that the decision should be theirs. However, the Aboriginal people do not have much choice. With an independent resource base, a fair and equitable access to this country's resources and reasonable alternative resource options, I do not believe for one minute that the Aboriginal people would opt for the uranium industry as the source of their income.

Once again we see the importance of land rights. Once again we see the importance of justice for the Aboriginal people. In my view, the Aboriginal people have been, if you like, economically manoeuvred into a position of supporting the mining and export of uranium. I will go no further than that. But the royalties accruing to the Aboriginal people from the mining of uranium are probably the only benefits that may accrue from that mining. I do not believe that in the long term anybody benefits. However, in the short term uranium mining royalties offer the Aboriginal people who are fortunate or unfortunate to have uranium on their land one of the few independent resource bases they have. Warren Snowdon, in the other place, believes that uranium mining has a minimal effect on the Northern Territory economy. He agrees also that the only real contribution from that mining is the royalties paid to the Aboriginal people.

During this debate and other debates we have heard members of the Opposition parties and some Government members saying that the increase in the tariff is an unnecessary fetter on the uranium industry. The reason for that being the case is that there is a decline in demand for uranium. Uranium is attracting such a low price that the industry needs to export more to make some sort of profit. The Opposition claims that the industry should not have to fund the Office of the Supervising Scientist because that is putting a burden on an industry whose export potential it wants to maximise. Senator Stone is not in the chamber, but I would like to ask him something. We hear so much about the free market and market forces, yet whenever an industry looks as though its profitability is going out the window it seems to demand subsidies and tariffs. Asking the taxpayer to fund the Office of the Supervising Scientist is asking the taxpayer to subsidise the profitability of the uranium industry. If the uranium industry is not profitable, let it close down. That is what is being done to other industries. That is what is happening to the car industry and to the textile, footwear and clothing industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us get back to the subject.

—This is the subject. Other industries are being asked to accept a reduction in tariffs and protection and the amount of subsidies being paid to them. Yet here we have an Opposition demanding subsidies for the uranium because it is in a parlous state. It is in a parlous state because there has been a decline in reactor building since Chernobyl and Three Mile Island. An Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development report showed that between 1973 and 1986 the nuclear fuel industry revised its estimated needs downwards by 78 1/2 per cent. The same report showed that uranium production will continue to outstrip non-military demand until at least 1995. What that suggests to me is that we are putting more uranium on a market in which there is already a glut. When we do that with wheat, sugar or any other commodity, prices go down, marginal profits become smaller, we need to export more and there are fewer safety measures. We end up with an industry either going bankrupt or not being able to afford the sort of protection for the environment that is required. If we need any authority to show that uranium is in increasingly less demand, we can look at the words of Peter Bradfield, the Chief Executive of Energy Resources of Australia Ltd, who says:

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment there simply isn't enough world-wide demand to justify bringing onstream mines like Yeelirrie, the CRA Rudall River project in Western Australia, in addition to the huge Roxby Downs project and the huge Ranger project, and the Queensland Mines project (Nabarlek) which is a terminal project but is nevertheless very important. There's plenty of scope for Ranger and Roxby Downs to supply worldwide demand from Australia in the next 15 years and I don't think it's wise to see another coal industry developed in this country where, for example, we have roughly forty mines and ten are profitable . . . It frustrates me-
that is, Peter Bradfield-
that we can't sell any more (uranium), but here again . . . it's a buyers market . . . that's the reason why a three mine policy is defensible.

The coal industry is a salutary lesson. We have more coal than we can sell and the prices we get for the coal that we do sell are continually less than are hoped for by the industry. The proliferation of coal mines and of coal makes the whole industry a lot less profitable than it could be. I would suggest that the same will happen with uranium. If we open more mines and mine more uranium, it will become less profitable and we will have another coal industry situation on our hands.

The Opposition seems to take the approach that we have a moral obligation to export uranium, to provide energy for the Third World and to feed the hungry. It speaks about mining uranium, nuclear energy and nuclear power reactors as if they were foreign aid, as if by creating a light switch in a Third World country that somehow or other manages to feed the poor. Third World countries with nuclear reactor power generators tend to produce electricity for the wealthy who can afford it, and they do very little for the poor, many of whom do not have a home, let alone things to plug into electric power sockets.

The Office of the Supervising Scientist should not have to exist, because we should not have a major uranium mine in one of the most beautiful areas of Australia, and we should not be mining uranium at all. The reason we should not is this-and I alluded to it earlier: we have ignored totally the cost to the environment of uranium and the whole nuclear industry. When this uranium is not being used in the military cycle to create plutonium for weapons, it is creating electricity. But the end product of uranium mining is not energy, it is not electricity, because that is just a by-product of the whole industry. What we are producing is nuclear waste. When we produce electricity from uranium we create nuclear waste which we will have to manage for thousands and thousands of years, for longer than the human race has existed.

There are so-called intelligent people in the United States, professional communicators, who sit around in think tanks trying to dream up symbols for `danger: radioactivity', which will still be recognisable in 200,000 years time-because that is how long some of this waste will be around and how long someone is going to have to protect and monitor the waste. Long after these uranium mines, the mines we are talking about today, have closed down there will need to be a body such as the Office of the Supervising Scientist, not to monitor the mining, but to monitor the waste. Who is going to pay for it? Obviously, it will be the taxpayers, not only those here in Australia but also those in the United States, Canada and around the world. For the next hundred thousand years they will be paying to look after the waste product, the end product of uranium mining. I make the point again: the end product of uranium mining is nuclear waste, as are the bombs that are produced-which hopefully we will make obsolete very soon.

Once disarmament has been achieved and we have dismantled nuclear weapons-and I am pretty hopeful that in the future we will decide to do so-and once the nuclear power generators have been closed down, there will still be the end product of the mining of uranium: rods of radioactive waste which someone is going to have to pay to look after. It is my view that we should take a responsible attitude to this matter and see that any profit that may be made from the export of uranium mining is not a profit at all, because the cost of monitoring way into the future is going to be astronomical. So the people who are profiting from the mining and export of uranium are profiting from a transient phase in the nuclear cycle-and the costs are something we cannot calculate.

I support the proposed amendments of the Australian Democrats because of the reality of the political situation in this country and because the alternative to the Democrats' amendments is the Government proposal-and the Democrats' amendments are preferable to that. But the ideal would be to raise the tariff so that we take out of the profits of uranium mining the future costs of monitoring uranium waste, of dismantling nuclear reactors and nuclear weapons and of repairing the environmental and health damage that is inevitable. If we do the right thing and, instead of just privatising the profits and socialising the costs, we privatise the costs as well, there is only one clear answer-namely, that the mining of uranium is unprofitable and costly, that no amount of levy could pay for the damage that it will create, and that therefore we should leave it in the ground.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, also, will be supporting Senator Coulter's amendment to ensure that the mining industry pays for the Office of the Supervising Scientist. I think that that is the least we can expect it to do. I support my colleague's comments; taxpayers should not be footing that bill, because we are already paying an inestimable amount in terms of environmental costs and human health costs. As Senator Wood has just pointed out, at the moment we can but guess at what future costs will be, which matter must be taken into account if we are to take a responsible position in relation to the uranium industry in total and the future consequences of it on the environment and for the people of this planet.

SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting to note the comments made by Dr Hans Blix, from the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), when he was in Sydney and Canberra last week. They back up what the anti-nuclear lobby has been saying for a long time-namely, that there can be no adequate safeguards on uranium from Australia or anywhere else. He made the comment several times over that there was no guarantee that Australian uranium would not end up in nuclear weapons. He also said that the Australian Government, while it wanted to believe that it had very strong safeguards in place, was not actually prepared to pay enough to ensure the monitoring of those safeguards. This is from the Director-General of the International Atomic Energy Agency. He said that, although most of the countries that are supplying uranium believe that it will not end up in nuclear weapons programs, they are not prepared to pay enough to ensure that that in fact is the case. The IAEA also promotes the nuclear industry. It has a very important dual function, although an absolutely contradictory one, to monitor and to promote the same industry. It is a bit like putting the fox in charge of the chicken coop. However, Dr Blix said that there are insufficient monitors to go around the various plants that are operating at the moment and that not enough is being paid by the suppliers of uranium to the IAEA to ensure that it can do a creditable job.

It is important to realise that the international nuclear lobby, its chief spokesperson being Dr Blix speaking on behalf of the IAEA, is on its collective back foot since the Chernobyl reactor disaster-and we are just commemorating the second anniversary of that dreadful accident in the Ukraine. We need to learn the lessons from Chernobyl, many of which cannot yet be fully estimated, due to the cancers and leukaemias that will develop in the next 10, 15 or 20 years, to say nothing of the personal stress caused to the people of the Ukraine, who were kept in the dark by their own Government when the accident occurred and who then suffered enormous stresses when they were evacuated hastily, coming to the realisation that their evacuation had taken place too late as they had already been affected by the radiation that was floating around the atmosphere. Not only that, one must consider the long-term consequences for those people and for the people of the whole of Western Europe, whose food chain has been affected by that disaster.

Obviously the world's people are learning the lessons of Chernobyl faster than is the world's nuclear industry, which still wants to promote itself and which still feels that it has a role to play. As Senator Wood so eloquently pointed out, the end result of the nuclear industry and uranium mining is the production of radioactive waste. That is the final statement that has to be made on this subject-and that is quite apart from the matter of nuclear weapons, which are one of the intermediate results of the mining of uranium.

It is important for Australians to be better educated about Australia's role in the nuclear industry. Last week I was very fortunate to be able to help promote and launch a new documentary on Australia's nuclear responsibilities, called `Cold comfort'. I think it could very easily have been subtitled `Costs and consequences of Australia's involvement in the nuclear industry'. It is an excellent documentary, put together by a team of film-makers who got footage from all around the world. They show the nuclear industry actually promoting itself; they gave the proponents of the nuclear industry a fair go to put their own position, and that was very instructive indeed. They also have footage of the consequences of the Chernobyl reactor disaster which have not generally been seen before. Also, they show the politicians at their pragmatic worst, with table thumping stuff from Bob Hawke and Bill Hayden at the Australian Labor Party conference in 1984, talking about the moral obligation that we have to supply uranium-and the practical obligation. It really is quite sickening stuff.

We can also see in that documentary scientists who, when asked about what are safe levels of exposure to radiation, answer, `Well, that is a political question; it is not a scientific question.' This highlights something else which came out of the meeting that was held in Sydney last week-namely, that there is no internationally recognised safe level of exposure to radiation. It is something about which the experts disagree quite vehemently. To say that it is a political question rather than a scientific one is evidence to the fact that politicians and the proponents of the industry will impose on their workers and on the general public as much radiation as they think they can get away with. That is why a scientific expert can say that it is a political question rather than a scientific question.

I would like to remind people that the Labor Party conference to be held in Hobart in early June will be a forum at which the Labor Party will again be discussing this whole question of Australia's involvement in the uranium industry. The least we can expect out of that conference is a reimposition of the ban on uranium sales to France. But I hope that it will go further than that and that the conference will reimpose Labor's more sensible policy of phasing out the three mines that already exist, rather than substituting new mines. It is most important that people in the community lobby the delegates to the Labor Party conference on this subject. There is a great opportunity here for a breakthrough on this matter, in the light of the scams--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: I make the point that we have allowed a very free-ranging debate on the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region, but moving on and making a special plea to the delegates to the upcoming Labor Party conference in June is taking it a little too far. I do not mind a general discussion on the matter but it really has gone a little off at a tangent.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, that is about all I wanted to say, except that I reiterate my support for Senator Coulter's amendment that the funding attached to the Office of the Supervising Scientist should be paid for by the industry and not the taxpayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable senators for contributing to the debate on the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1988. The Government will not be accepting the Opposition's second reading amendment. With regard to the second limb of the Opposition's amendment, the Government does not accept that the export levy will significantly affect the competitive position of companies mining uranium in the Alligator Rivers region, as the amount raised is small compared to the amount of money made on uranium already mined pursuant to the existing contracts. The amount raised is a small price to pay to protect a part of Australia's heritage that is of international significance.

SPEECH.PARA: The first limb of the Opposition's amendment, relating to the supposed need to limit the role and functions of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, is also rejected. As to the role and duties of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, I would like to emphasise that the Government is determined to pursue the following points to ensure the highest standard of protection of the Alligator Rivers region, which includes Kakadu National Park, and to be confident in the assurances that it gives to the world that the whole region is in fact being protected. Accordingly, some form of independent and credible scientific advice continues to be required. The Office of the Supervising Scientist is a key element in the environment protection arrangements put in place by the Government.

The legislative functions and responsibilities of the Office of the Supervising Scientist have been determined by the Commonwealth as being the minimum necessary to enable the Government to assure this Parliament and the public that a sufficiently high standard of environment protection in the region is being achieved-a region of national significance. The structure of the Office of the Supervising Scientist-and its research program in particular-is based on the program endorsed by the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry. Its programs have been reviewed and endorsed on a number of occasions, including by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, scientists, and by the Australian Science and Technology Council. The research program of the Office of the Supervising Scientist is directly related to the practice of environmental protection, assessment, control and monitoring and to the provision to the community of technically sound advice on the state of protection being achieved in the region. The high level of protection of Kakadu National Park from any pollution from any of the uranium mines which have been achieved to date testifies to the success of measures and standards being developed and applied by the Office of the Supervising Scientist.

Prominent research activities of the Office of the Supervising Scientist include water and tailings management; geomorphological studies that provide information necessary to ensure that tailings can be contained and isolated from the environment for thousands of years; and the development of strategies for the revegetation of decommissioned mine sites. The Office of the Supervising Scientist work has helped keep radiation exposure of the public and workers well below the national and international health limits. Thus, the Office of the Supervising Scientist program has been strategically applied to major potential environmental impacts arising from the uranium mining both during operation and even more particularly in the long term. The present emphasis is on problems arising during the operational phase of mining in the region and on long term environment considerations. This is entirely consistent with the statutory role of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, and with the research directions envisaged by the Fox Commission.

There has been no change in the central role of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, which is to ensure, through continued environmental assessment, control and monitoring, that the unique environment of the region and Kakadu National Park, one of the world's great national parks containing internationally significant wetlands, is fully protected from the effects of mining operations. This is a continuing task. To disband or transfer some of the functions of an internationally renowned scientific operation that is already in the field and doing the job to an infant university college that, as the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) conceded during the second reading debate in the House of Representatives, does not have the expertise or size to perform the job would be to walk away from Australia's moral obligation to protect this region. I see no cogent reason, nor has any been given in this debate, in any way to alter the role of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, nor change the arrangements by which the Office of the Supervising Scientist is ultimately responsible to this national parliament.

There is one further minor matter raised in debate that I should like to comment on. Both Senator Lewis and Senator Tambling were critical of the fact that one-third of the staff of the Office of the Supervising Scientist is established in Sydney. Two-thirds of the staff of the Supervising Scientist are located at Jabiru in the Northern Territory. Only staff who perform tasks that can be conducted efficiently in Sydney, such as administrative support or the preparation of the Office of the Supervising Scientist scientific journals, are based there, the cost of paying the Northern Territory allowance, extra leave and extra fares and the higher cost of basing people anywhere in the Northern Territory, including the cost of providing adequate housing and the cost of goods and services, are such that it is cost efficient to base these staff in Sydney.

The amendment proposed by the Democrats is also rejected by the Government. As Senator Lewis has said, the increase in the export levy is a Budget measure, forming part of the 1987-88 Budget, and thus should not be subject to change. Indeed, this measure already proposes to raise from uranium mining companies 75 per cent of the uranium-related costs of the Office of the Supervising Scientist during 1987-88-up from 50 per cent in 1986-87-thus raising the amount collected by the levy in the order of 25 per cent in one action. It would be inappropriate to burden an export industry with a further unannounced, unexpected duty at this time. Any future amendments to the levy will be made having regard to prevailing budgetary circumstances.

Those were the only relevant matters raised in the debate. To catalogue all the irrelevancies, the sidetracks, and the refighting of world war III, going into all Senator Sanders's tawdry allegations again, would be absolutely pointless.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even your side has admitted they are facts.

—Senator Sanders's views of facts are that if one person on this earth, one of the four billion people, makes an allegation it is automatically a fact if it accords with his prejudices and biases. Fortunately, any approach to these matters will not be done on such stupid criteria as Senator Sanders applies to what he regards as truth and fact. Nor am I going to go into all the byways. Senator Sanders had the chance to debate flag swapping and all the rest of it last week and, as always, failed to come up with the goods. He has had to have a second go today to try to get back the ground. We are not interested in redebating those issues today.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Lewis's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
(1) Page 1, clause 2, lines 9 to 11, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
``2. (1) Subject to subsection (2), this Act commences on the day on which it receives the Royal Assent.
(2) Subsection 3 (1) shall be deemed to have commenced at the hour of 8 o'clock in the evening by standard time in the Australian Capital Territory on 15 September 1987.''.
(2) Page 1, clause 3, at end of clause, add the following new subclause:
``(2) Section 6 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting from subsection (1) `1.02' and substituting `1.36'.''.
(3) Page 2, clause 4, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
``4. (1) Notwithstanding the amendment made by subsection 3 (1), the Principal Act as in force immediately before the commencement of that subsection continues to apply in relation to:
(a) Alligator Rivers Region uranium concentrate loaded on to a vessel before the commencement of that subsection for export from Australia; and

(b) Alligator Rivers Region uranium concentrate loaded on to a vessel after the commencement of that subsection for export from Australia as part of a consignment of Alligator Rivers Region uranium concentrate for export from Australia the loading of which on to that vessel commenced before the commencement of that subsection.
``(2) Notwithstanding the amendment made by subsection 3 (2), the Principal Act as in force immediately before the commencement of that subsection continues to apply in relation to:
(a) Alligator Rivers Region uranium concentrate loaded on to a vessel before the commencement of that subsection for export from Australia; and

(b) Alligator Rivers Region uranium concentrate loaded on to a vessel before the commencement of that subsection for export from Australia as part of a consignment of Alligator Rivers Region uranium concentrate for export from Australia the loading of which on to that vessel commenced before the commencement of that subsection.''.

The purpose of the amendments is to ensure that the full cost of the Supervising Scientist is borne by uranium miners in the Kakadu World Heritage area, and this is based on the user pays principle. We have the example of another uranium mine in Australia-the Roxby Downs venture-which is not in a World Heritage area. The Australian Democrats believe that if the Ranger operators, Energy Resources of Australia Ltd (ERA), choose to mine uranium in a very environmentally sensitive area such as the Kakadu World Heritage area then the necessary cost of protecting the environment should be borne by that operation. That places the Ranger operators on a level playing field with those in South Australia operating at Roxby, which is in an area not so environmentally sensitive.

The amounts are small. As I indicated during the second reading debate, it involves 1.5 per cent of the floor price of uranium which is $US31 per pound or $A91 per kilogram; and $1.36 is 1.5 per cent of that. I agree with Senator Collins's interjection yesterday that the uranium mining operation in the Northern Territory at the moment is well capable of meeting that impost. The uranium industry, contrary to the indication in the Opposition's proposed amendment, is not in dire financial straits and likely to collapse due to this imposition.

Another argument in support of the amendments is that the costs associated with protecting the environment will persist long after the mining operation has ceased. We are simply asking that uranium miners meet the year on year costs. Significant costs will still have to be borne by the general public in the future so one could easily justify a much greater increase in duty, but we are not asking for that. Last night I pointed to the situation which obtains at Rum Jungle and the pollution of the Finniss River and the fact that in the last Budget the Government put aside $7m-an amount far in excess of the cost of the Supervising Scientist-in one year out of the public purse as partial redress for the environmental damage which occurred from uranium mining at Rum Jungle more than 30 years ago.

One could also point to Port Pirie where uranium processing occurred in the 1950s and very large unprotected tailings dumps were left behind. Until a few years ago children were playing in those dumps and in less than half an hour were exposing themselves to more than a year's worth of radiation, mainly due I believe, to, thorium contamination in those dumps. As a consequence, the South Australian Government-in other words, the taxpayer-has had to pick up the enormous cost of covering those dumps, fencing them and ensuring surveillance virtually in perpetuity. Moreover, as a consequence of the years when those dumps remained unprotected the public has had to pick up an enormous cost to clean up the area around the city of Port Pirie, to cover large areas of soil so that radiation contamination does not return to the air by way of dust and children playing in back yards and school grounds do not pick up radioactively contaminated material. Many houses and buildings have had to be substantially reconstructed as a consequence. These costs have been and are currently being borne by the general taxpayer as a consequence of uranium mining in the past by miners who did not pay the full cost of the consequences of their actions. My amendments merely seek to ensure that uranium miners in this very environmentally sensitive area, which is recognised as such and as a World Heritage area, bear the year on year costs of the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS).

The point was made, I think by Senator Lewis during the second reading debate, that the Office of the Supervising Scientist may not be functioning as efficiently as it might and that it may be engaging itself in research which is not relevant to its particular task. It is strongly argued that these are two separate issues. The costs associated with the Supervising Scientist should be recovered from those who involve the Australian community in that expense. If that expense is excessive because the Office is running inefficiently, that matter should be addressed. I am not admitting that that is the case, but if it is it should be addressed, and if the costs are reduced then perhaps as a consequence the duty could be reduced. At this point in the debate there is no relationship between the duty which is payable and the principle that that duty should cover the full cost of the Office of the Supervising Scientist on the one hand, and whether the Supervising Scientist is conducting research, all of which is totally relevant to that operation, on the other.

Finally, I point out that the other sections in the Australian Democrats' amendments deal with the timing of the imposition of this increase from $1.02 to $1.36. The Bill that we are seeking to amend backdates the increase in duty from 80c to a $1.02 to 15 September 1987. As the Australian Democrats are not in favour of retrospective legislation, we would not seek to increase further that duty from $1.02 to $1.36 and make that increase retrospective to 15 September. Thus, there are clauses in our amendments which mean that the further increase would be payable only from the date on which the amended Bill received assent. The consequent clauses on page 2 are simply to cover the Government and the OSS in the interim period so that no holes are created into which the legislation might fall. I recommend these amendments to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall indicate very briefly why the Opposition will not support the amendments put forward by the Australian Democrats. In moving these amendments, Senator Coulter said that they were to provide for additional revenue to cover the full cost of the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS), which was to be borne by the miners operating within the World Heritage listed area of the Kakadu region. The first point I make is that in many respects the Opposition does not believe that the full costs of the Office of the Supervising Scientist are entirely justified. Senator Lewis and others on behalf of the Opposition have indicated our concerns about the cost of the operation of the OSS and the sorts of steps that should be taken, not simply to fund that cost but indeed to reduce it.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, Senator Coulter has indicated that it is a matter of principle that the user should pay. I have no objection to that principle-indeed, I think it is very commendable. However, the miners are not the sole users of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. There is a public benefit derived from the work of the Supervising Scientist. There are benefits which flow from the research grants and which are given through the Office of the Supervising Scientist to people who are not directly connected with the uranium mining industry and there are also community benefits which flow through the imposition of taxation. So there is a whole series of areas in which there are public benefits. If it is a question of the user paying, the user in terms of the Office of the Supervising Scientist is in fact a far wider group than simply those people involved in the uranium mining industry.

The next point I make is that the Opposition has already indicated its concerns about raising the levy in the principal Act from 80c to $1.02. As a result, it would be quite unreasonable for us to be expected to support the further imposition from $1.02 to $1.36, as proposed by Senator Coulter's amendments. In our second reading amendment we drew attention to what we described as the struggle on the part of the industry to remain competitive on world markets. It is not simply a matter of the impact of domestic taxation, there are a whole series of impacts upon the competitive position of the Australian uranium miners. I cite, for example, the development of the USA-Canada free trade arrangement which puts Canadian uranium producers at a considerable advantage over Australia producers. The disadvantages suffered by Australian producers which are involved in those bilateral arrangements are simply compounded by this additional impost by way of levy.

Finally, I draw attention to the fact that the budgetary process is involved here. The reason we do not oppose the legislation is that it is a Budget measure. In the past the Democrats have indicated that they would not interfere with the Government's budgetary processes. They are now saying, `Well it is all right not to interfere with the budgetary process if it means depriving the Government of revenue, but it is perfectly all right to interfere with the budgetary process if it means increasing the Government's revenue from a piece of legislation before the Parliament'. For those reasons, I simply want to indicate that the Opposition will not support any of the amendments to this legislation moved by Senator Coulter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps this is the appropriate time for me to indicate that, for the reasons canvassed by Senator Robert Ray at the end of his second reading response, the Government cannot accept the amendments proposed by the Australian Democrats.

—I totally reject the double standards of the Government and the Opposition, which call for total `user pays' in the aircraft industry and the general aviation and airline industries-they want a full cost recovery on everything that the aviation industry is involved in-yet on an issue such as uranium mining they want to subsidise the uranium miners. It does not make sense; it is inconsistent. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), who is sitting in this chamber, must admit the inconsistency of asking for full cost recovery in one area but not in another. If the uranium industry wants to mine uranium in Australia it has the responsibility to pay the full cost of that mining. Furthermore, the Office of the Supervising Scientist will be asked to supervise gold mining at Coronation Hill for which it will gain no additional revenue. It is absolutely ludicrous that this Government will not demand that these miners in a national park-a World Heritage park-pay the full cost of their operation. It shows that the Government is not serious about its fiscal policies or the environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall speak very briefly to answer Senator Puplick who mentioned the `user pays' principle and argued that the uranium producers were not the sole users of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. There is a great deal of research which is publicly funded. I think Senator Lewis yesterday mentioned research which is carried out by the Northern Territory University and I also mentioned the work which is carried out by the northern division of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. A great deal of that work is relevant to the Office of the Supervising Scientist. So, to the extent that it is work that would be necessary within the Kakadu World Heritage area in relation to uranium mining but which does not have to be carried out by the Office of the Supervising Scientist because it is carried out somewhere else at the public expense, the public is already picking up part of the cost of that research work. It is simply not sufficient to say that there are other public benefits flowing from the Office of the Supervising Scientist beyond those which flow to the uranium miners. That may well be true but there is this counter-flow from other publicly funded institutions towards the uranium miners. Moreover, we must not forget that the Office of the Supervising Scientist was initially created solely for the purpose of looking after that environmentally very sensitive area. It came directly out of the report of the Fox Committee-the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry. The Office would not have been created in the first place had that operation of uranium mining not begun. For those reasons, I believe the $1.36 impost is entirely justified.
