SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As it is some time since the Student Assistance Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 was introduced, I will take the opportunity to refresh the memory of honourable senators and interested members of the public of what the Bill is about. According to the long title, it is a Bill for an Act to amend the Student Assistance Act 1973, the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940, the Social Security Act 1947 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, and for related purposes. The Student Assistance Act 1973 actually gives the statutory basis for Austudy and for postgraduate awards schemes. This Bill seeks to amend the Student Assistance Act by including a package of measures to facilitate the prevention of fraud and the recovery of overpayments under these schemes. The proposed measures are comparable to the existing provisions of the Social Security Act 1947.

SPEECH.PARA: Specifically, the Bill amends the Student Assistance Act to do a number of things, including to require individuals and organisations to provide information needed to verify entitlements and to require debtors to disclose their financial situation. Secondly, it makes it an offence to give false information in relation to an application for assistance. At present this offence is dealt with in the Student Assistance Regulations. Substantial penalties for offences under the Act and Regulations are provided. I note that the Australian Democrats will seek to move some amendments to those penalties. I indicate that the coalition will not support those amendments. The Bill will enable the Department of Employment, Education and Training to recover overpayments from money held for a debtor. Further, it will enable an overpayment to be written off or waived or for agreement to be given to the overpayment being repaid by instalments.

The Act currently enables the Regulations to provide for offences with a maximum penalty of $100. It is proposed that the maximum penalty for offences under the Act should be a fine of $2,000 and/or 12 months imprisonment, or $10,000 for corporations, and for offences under the Regulations, a fine of $1,000 and/or six months imprisonment. Those are the purposes of the Bill.

I have some general comments to make. If one can paraphrase the purposes to which I have just referred into one sentence, they are to maintain the integrity of delivery of financial assistance through Austudy. It is important to maintain the integrity of any system of government activity. That is obvious. It is particularly important to do so when that activity distributes taxpayers' funds. A common view is held by many in the community that taxpayers predominantly are an unidentified amorphous blob of middle-class, relatively well off Australians. Of course, that is not so. Many thousands of taxpayers earn not very much above the tax-free zone or, if they earn above that, certainly well below average weekly earnings. Some are full time low income earners and many are part time income earners, especially women. Many do not pay much tax in the relative sphere of things, but they are entitled, as are those who pay a lot of tax, to expect that what they do pay is spent well. Madam Acting Deputy President, I think you would accept that we have a greater obligation to those who earn less to ensure that the taxes they pay are spent properly. These amendments seek to provide the bureaucracy with the means to ensure just that, and consequently we support the Bill.

Greater power given to an individual or a bureaucracy requires greater responsibility. The powers in the legislation must be used responsibly and with great care because they are extensive powers. A power given to assist in maintaining the integrity of a system demands that the responsibility, to which I referred earlier, is carried out. It also demands that every step is taken to ensure that a system's integrity is not damaged from within. There are two ways in which the integrity of such a system can be damaged. One is by external fraud. However, internal bureaucratic bungling can also damage a system's integrity. If the bureaucracy seeks a greater power, as will be given to it by this Bill, I put forward the argument that the bureaucracy has a greater obligation to ensure that the system's integrity is not damaged by its own internal bungling.

The implementation of Austudy last year was a case study par excellence of bureaucratic bungling. I am sure that honourable senators present will remember that on many occasions senators on both sides of the chamber raised their concerns with the then Minister for Education, Senator Ryan. The maladministration of Austudy was a fiasco. The stories of hardship that emanated from honourable senators and honourable members are far too great in number for us to go through today, but they cannot simply be ignored as the complaints of a minority. There was an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 17 June last year entitled `50,000 students awaiting money'. That appeared six months after Austudy was launched in a blaze of publicity-a blaze of publicity that we are accustomed to seeing with the launch of any government initiative.

Senator Ryan was particularly complacent in this chamber in response to the concerns that were raised, but her complacency did not disguise or in any way alleviate the distress caused by delays which were due, in part, to malfunctioning of a computer system. The canvassed defence that delays were inevitable, as that was the first year of operation, did not hold much sway when students were being forced to get emergency cash to meet the necessities of life. After all, the fact that a program is in its first year of operation is not an excuse. The implementation of a program should be sorted out before it launches into its first year. Another article entitled `Delays in Austudy payments have emptied the loan fund of the University of Western Australia's student guild' appeared in the West Australian of 5 March 1987. That shows how bad the situation was. At that time, Austudy officials were saying that a further eight-week delay in payment was likely. Still we had from the then Minister, Senator Ryan, comments such as, `There is no truth to the rumour that the system has malfunctioned'. If that was not serious, it would be a joke. Every student who was desperate to get his or her Austudy payment was stunned in disbelief at the Minister's response. Whether or not one believes that there was a malfunction of the system depends on one's view of the truth and what a malfunction amounts to.

On 20 February last year in this chamber I quoted from a telegram sent to Senator Ryan from Elaine Darling, the Labor member for Lilley. I will repeat the words in that telegram to indicate that both sides of the chamber acknowledged what a fiasco the maladministration of Austudy was:

Crisis situation developing in south east Queensland as social security benefits have been cut while Austudy has not come through. Young people in flats with no rent allowance could end up in the street.
A month after the matter was raised by not only Elaine Darling but also me, Senator Ryan was still unrepentant. She refused to acknowledge the disaster she was sitting on top of. She commented:
. . . the system is working well and I am pleased to assure the Senate that there have been no hardware malfunctions.

That was something of a misleading statement because a hardware malfunction is simply a technical problem. The allegations of problems within the administration of Austudy related to software malfunctions. In June, Senator Newman, my colleague from Tasmania, informed Senator Ryan that students who were seeking emergency relief were confronted repeatedly with a recorded message or an apparently continually engaged telephone. Senator Ryan still ignored the bureaucratic disaster by saying that most delays had been substantially overcome. I think that that makes the point.

I note that the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan), when closing the second reading debate in the other place, referred to the coalition as having said that the problems with Austudy funding were, in large part, the result of Government maladministration. His response in February this year indicated how things had improved. No-one denies that they have improved, but they are not perfect yet. One can only be grateful for the improvements that have been made, but that does not permit a coalition simply to turn a blind eye to the problems that are still there. I think that Minister Duncan's speech indicated that there is still a problem with 15 per cent of the deliveries. That is a very substantial improvement on the position of last year, but it is of no help to those 15 per cent to know that things have improved for everybody else but themselves.

This Bill contains provisions similar to those in the social security legislation. When the Minister responds I would be grateful if he or she at the time could give some indication of the effectiveness of the guidelines that have been established to implement that legislation and whether the same sorts of guidelines will be used with respect to this legislation. It is important to understand the manner in which the Government seeks to control the use of the power that the bureaucracy is to be given by this legislation. I note that in the October 1987 Legal Services Bulletin there was an article entitled `Australia Card by stealth?'. That article detailed that in New South Wales more than 50 per cent of appeals to Social Security Appeals Tribunals were upheld. I realise that to infer that may be the case in regard to allegations of mistakes by Austudy administration involves a cross-departmental and cross-State comparison. Nonetheless, the fact that that is the case with social security payments in New South Wales points to the fact, if it needs to be pointed out, that bureaucracies make mistakes. Of course, the more bureaucracies deal with, the more mistakes they make. That is why it is very important, this legislation giving substantial power to the bureaucracy, that a bureaucracy seeking greater powers to maintain the integrity of its system accepts with those powers the obligation to clean up its own house at the same time.

I think a few other points need to be raised. I have canvassed the question of the maladministration of Austudy in terms of the delivery of benefits and the problem that that created. However, there are still other problems in regard to Austudy that need to be addressed. Hopefully, the Minister responding will take the opportunity to address them. The main point I wish to raise is the much publicised loophole for New Zealand students. This matter was raised in February this year by a Queensland backbencher, Mr Wright. Mr Wright was alleging that New Zealand students living in Australia can get more than $4,000 each, regardless of their parents' income. The report of Mr Wright's allegations indicates that Federal Government officials were at that time working on the loop- hole and that the loophole may have been netting New Zealand students in Australia $1.3m. There is no anti-New Zealand sentiment being expressed by Mr Wright, or, indeed, by me in raising this matter; nonetheless, it is an administrative problem that needs to be addressed.

The second point I would like to raise in terms of the administration of Austudy is the question of fraud-how broad the problem is and what the Government is doing about it. I note that a commissioned study done by Price Waterhouse, which my colleagues Mr Reith and Mr Carlton had to get under freedom of information because the Government was not prepared initially to release it, found that Austudy fraud was substantial and that departmental prosecution and investigation had not been a high departmental priority. Despite the giving of extra power to the department to maintain the integrity of its system, this report indicates that, if the motivation there at the time of this investigation is at the same level today, perhaps these powers will not be used as they ought to be. The Price Waterhouse study also found that proposals for an inquiry into the extent of fraud had been deferred. I ask the Minister in his response to detail what the Government is now prepared to do with respect to the allegations of fraud in the Price Waterhouse report which referred to Austudy not only for undergraduates but also for masters and doctoral students and to fraud in regard to research grants across the board.

I noted also in the Minister's response to the second reading debate in the lower House a comment that the Government had now closed the gap between unemployment benefits and Austudy, reducing the incentive for young Australians to study rather than go on unemployment benefits. No-one denies that improvements have been made. However, there are anomalies. Later in this debate my colleague Senator Patterson will be referring in some detail to those. At this moment I choose simply to refer to one which was raised by Valerie Farfalla in an article in the Age newspaper headed, `Study too good for them'. Ms Farfalla referred to someone going by the pseudonym of Jennie Jones who, along with many other supporting parents with children over 16 years, lost her widow's pension last year. The Government indicated that it was going to alleviate the problem that that would create by encouraging such people to retrain and re-enter the work force. When the alleged Mrs Jones was accepted into a two-year welfare training course, she was delighted and assumed that the Government would be as well. Of course, what she found out was that the program that had been developed would allow her to take a short term training course of up to 12 months. The sorts of courses available for a 12-month period are waitressing or clerical work courses under the adult training program for the unemployed. The situation is that, if Mrs Jones wants to go into tertiary education, she will have to switch to an Austudy allowance of approximately $91 a week whereas on unemployment benefit she would receive $173 a week, including a $30 training allowance. She now faces the difficult choice of surviving on a $91.20 Austudy allowance while she takes the course of her choice longer than one year or remain on the unemployment benefit.

This is a difficult area. It is important that people in receipt of pensions and benefits are encouraged to become self-sufficient, but it is also important that, in moving towards that goal, account be taken of the anomalies that can be created, albeit short term, and that something be done about them. I will be interested to hear the Minister's response to this because that particular move hurts women more than it does men. While not denying that changes need to be made to encourage people to become more self-sufficient, this appears to be quite a substantial anomaly which the Government could address in some way. I have no more to say other than that the coalition supports the second reading of the Bill. I move a second reading amendment:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for its disgraceful mismanagement of the Austudy scheme, causing distress and financial embarrassment to thousands of students and their families who have had to wait for lengthy periods before receiving their entitlements.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone has outlined the purposes of the Student Assistance Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. I would use the second reading speech of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), when introducing the Bill into the Senate, to remind the Senate of these words:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill seeks to amend the Student Assistance Act 1973 which is the legislative basis for the provision of student assistance under Austudy and for the grant of post-graduate awards.
The Minister went on to say:
The proposed measures are designed to facilitate the prevention of fraud and the recovery of overpayments under student assistance schemes.
Furthermore, he stated:
to bring it-
the Student Assistance Act-
into line with the Social Security Act in matters relating to the gathering of information, and the recovery and write-off and waiver of overpayments in relation to the schemes.

As Senator Vanstone says, it is important that we maintain the integrity of the student payments system. I believe I am using her term fairly accurately. But I think we very much need to balance that against what we are doing here in this legislation in the light of what has previously been done in this area of prevention of fraud and the recovery of overpayments under the ambit of the Social Security Act. Whilst it is important that where income support is available, in this case for people engaging in both secondary and post-secondary studies, those payments are made to people who are entitled to them, it is also important that any systems which are set in place take into account the rights of people in the community. Recent legislation has given the Department of Social Security new powers to collect and divulge information and to recover debts which are really more extensive, for instance, than the proposed information collection powers for the Australia Card, and which are also more extensive than those given to any other authority or department, for instance, to catch criminals and so on. These changes to the treatment of people alleged to have been overpaid by the Department of Social Security are extraordinarily harsh and punitive. It concerns the Australian Democrats very much that this Bill intends to go down that path as far as the Student Assistance Act is concerned.

The rationale cited in the case of the amendments to the Social Security Act was that there is extensive fraud in the Department of Social Security, but statistics have not really shown extensive fraud. The annual report of the Department of Social Security revealed that in 1986-87 only 0.6 per cent of the total social security population was prosecuted for fraud. I think Senator Vanstone referred to the fact that 50 per cent of social security appeals are in fact upheld. She then went on to refer to the difficulty of transposing those sorts of statistics across from State jurisdictions and across various government departments. We would have to believe that there is some kind of guidance to our thinking in those figures, because the powers which are given under the Student Assistance Act in this legislation, are as the Minister mentioned in his second reading speech, the same sorts of powers as are now available to the Department of Social Security. They are based on a premise of extensive fraud. The implication which underpins this is that the administering department, in its accusation of fraud or overpayment, whichever it is, is going to be correct. It is the case, as Senator Vanstone pointed out, that 50 per cent of appeals in New South Wales and 57 per cent in South Australia show that there has been substantial departmental error.

I think it is important to look at the sort of scenario which has been created in the social security area and which is being proposed in this legislation in the area of student assistance. For instance, the power to recover debt before proof of liability for that debt, and even before proof of any debt, from the payments or, in the case of this legislation, through court action or a combination of both, and the sorts of powers which are given in the legislation for access to information from third parties about recipients are all powers which need to be looked at quite closely and which the Australian Democrats believe are really beyond what is defensible in terms of people in receipt of, in this case, student assistance funding. The demands can be made of virtually anybody for virtually any purpose without the necessity for, as I say, the requirement to produce proof or the requirement for consent, and information can be divulged about recipients without their consent or knowledge. These are the sorts of issues which very much concern the Australian Democrats about the social security legislation and this legislation in relation to the Student Assistance Act.

At the same time, we would emphasise, as I did earlier, that we believe it is important that the payments which are available are made to people who are entitled to those payments. On that point, I point out that, while the Government from time to time makes great moment of its policy to retain more students and have them complete their secondary studies, and to have more students enter into and complete tertiary or post-secondary studies of various kinds, and while in the May statement last year there were various rises in the allowances and some bringing together of questions of Austudy and the unemployment benefit and so on, when we look at the whole picture we see a contradiction in the Government's stated position and its actions with questions of who can and who cannot, fraud and overpayments aside, actually qualify for Austudy payments, and how much there is available through Austudy payments for those people that the Government says it wants to retain in education at various levels.

In the Budget Papers of last year under the heading of `Students Assistance Schemes' we see that the change between 1987 and 1988 in the area of tertiary recipients is put at a 2.7 per cent increase. But when we look at the increase in 1987, the preliminary figure in these Budget Papers, in the numbers of students in universities and colleges of advanced education, we see the figure is 2.6 per cent. So the Government cannot claim that at that level Austudy payments are being extended, that more students are being assisted by more Austudy payments. Indeed, looking at the overall cake in terms of how much is available, we need to be reminded that the May statement reduced the forward estimates for student assistance by $27.6m in 1987-88, which is close to $60m in a full year. That is a clear indication that not only are we not getting Austudy to more students, but the actual cake for student assistance has not grown, even in the face of a Government policy which says that the Government wants to have more Australians in tertiary education and education at all levels. The Austudy living allowance and eligibility for Austudy altogether also raises a very important question when we are talking about the sorts of policies which affect young people in our community, and particularly the students. The living allowance is subject to income testing and is of course taxable, and students are classified as either dependent or independent. Last year's Budget Papers state:
The entitlement of dependent students is assessed on their family income, the maximum allowances being reduced if that income exceeds certain levels in a year.

The qualification for independent status has been moved to 25 years, marriage or participation in the work force. This whole issue raises a question in the minds of the Australian Democrats. We wish the Government would put its mind to the conflicts in Government policy and actions by answering the question: When is an individual considered, under the whole range of income support systems that are available, as an independent functioning adult? There is enormous conflict in this because in the same year the Budget took away from young people under the age of 18 the entitlement to the unemployment benefit. There are differences in the rates of unemployment benefits paid, all the way up to the age of 21. The age of 25 is set for the tertiary allowance before an individual is seen in his own right to have independent status.

The issue of the family is bruited around a lot in politics. Certainly, no-one denies that the family is an integral and very vital unit in our society. But many families at the moment are suffering a great deal, particularly in terms of stress, not to mention economic suffering, over the sorts of anomalies that exist in questions of their growing young people's futures and how families can cope with them. It is quite anomalous to be saying to a young person between the ages of 21 and 25 that he is not an independent adult individual unless he can get married-which I suppose is trying to push along the family unit in our society. I suggest that that is hardly the best way to do it. That is another anomaly that ought to be addressed. Either we are individuals or we are not. All too often, questions of where young people fit in their families mean that assumptions are made by decision makers which may not be accurate.

As a sideline, I have mentioned the difficulty of qualifying for Austudy. For another group of young people, the young homeless, there are similar difficulties. The young homeless allowance is almost totally unavailable because of the restrictions placed on it. Again, it is part of the whole question of what we are doing for young people and whether we are forcing them and their families to remain together at a period of their lives when forcing them to remain as a unit is causing enormous conflicts. Some of these policies may very well mean-and I have seen case studies-that simply having to stay to qualify for these various entitlements has caused such stress that a young person has left home, become a burden on society, and has lived a miserable life. Usually such a person drops out of education. This major question is raised by this and every other piece of legislation which relates to student allowances.

I go back to the point I have been making about the nature of this legislation. In the end, what the Australian Democrats say now is what we have always said: really the only answer is to see education not as a cost in the community but as an asset-and policy decisions should be made on that basis, that by investing in education we are investing in our future. We should not make the sorts of policy decisions which restrict access and which, as I believe this legislation does, determine that people are guilty until proven innocent rather than the other way around. We could mention the tertiary education fee of $250, a fee which has now risen. It is indexed, whereas many of these payments and income tests are not. This again was another contrary decision from a government which purports to believe that access to education should be open and available to all people.

I also have to make the point that that decision and that legislation were supported by the Opposition by way of vote, with only the Australian Democrats opposing them-as we continue to do because we believe that education is an investment and that it ought to be free and available to all people. We say liberalisation of Austudy student payments and postgraduate research awards and indexation in accordance with the consumer price index movement ought to be done to encourage access to and utilisation of the education system, in the interests of the economic, social and cultural future of this country.

Because we are so concerned about the increase in the powers of yet another government department along the same lines as the powers that have been given now to the Department of Social Security, the Australian Democrats intend to oppose this legislation. My colleague Senator Macklin will move amendments at the committee stage of this Bill which relate to penalties involved in the legislation. In recent legislation on customs and tariffs, Senator Coulter moved amendments, which were successful with the support of the Opposition, to bring into line the sorts of penalties which are now in legislation. We have got to the rather ridiculous stage where the financial penalty and the so-called equivalent penalty of imprisonment are absolutely out of kilter. We will be moving similar amendments to this legislation and we urge the Opposition, which was willing last time to support those amendments on the basis of rationality, to consider seriously doing that again.

In the general area of Austudy-and I now refer to the Opposition's amendment to the motion for the second reading-the Democrats, as were members of other political parties, were inundated with complaints and distress calls from students as a consequence of the mismanagement of the introduction of the Austudy scheme, particularly at the beginning of last year. The terms of Senator Vanstone's amendment are terms with which we can agree, because many students and their families, as Senator Vanstone said in her amendment, had to wait a lengthy time before receiving their entitlements. As I have said, entitlements are not readily available and are not generous. They are not indexed to the extent that they ought to be; nor are the tests related to them. To compound that problem with the inefficiency which occurred at that stage, and which still occurs from time to time, is insupportable by the Democrats. Therefore, we are happy to support the amendment to the second reading motion moved by Senator Vanstone.

I reiterate our deep concern about giving another government department the sorts of draconian powers to engage in information dissemination and gathering and also debt recovery without the need for proof and without sufficient redress for the individuals involved. So we intend opposing this legislation on the basis that while we believe that fraud should be dealt with and that payments should be made only to those people who are eligible, we also believe that there is a very one-eyed view of this in the Government and probably also within the Opposition, otherwise it might oppose this, along with us. I point here to the absolute paranoia about fraud that we have seen-which resulted in the social security amendments and this legislation-amongst people who are receiving government payments, a paranoia which is not matched by a similar concern about another group in the community which we, the Democrats, do not believe is quite playing the game as it ought to be played. This, of course, is the corporate sector, whose contribution to our tax take has been falling over the past decade and whose taxation activities are now, fortunately, under review.

In the past 12 months many organisations in the corporate sector had a pretty good year of it. I do not know whether the fact that 50 per cent of appeals in the Department of Social Security in one State and 57 per cent in another have been upheld really motivates anyone to thinking that people receiving Government payments are perhaps getting a raw deal. However, when looking at the documentation of how people in the corporate sector have been going in the past 12 months, one notes the situation in that regard, as I have pointed out to the Senate on other occasions. The Adelaide Steamship Co. Ltd was able to pay tax at something like 25c or 26c in the dollar in the 1986-87 financial year, and in 1987 it staggered up by only 0.18c in the dollar. Industrial Equity Limited has managed to keep its tax payout at about 4 per cent; Westfield Corporation has managed to stagger to 4 per cent; Bond Corporation Pty Ltd is paying about 8 per cent; Elders IXL Limited, headed, of course, by the National President of the Liberal Party of Australia, 10.48 per cent; and News Limited, 12.22 per cent, down from 15.42 per cent. This makes one wonder why equal zeal is not shown elsewhere as regards what is going on. I hope that that zeal is shown in the Government's tax review. If legislation should come before us to enable us to tidy up that little lot, I would certainly not oppose it.

Senator Vanstone mentioned the individual taxpayers who in the end, as we would all admit, have to pay costs arising from fraud. In recent times taxpayers have shouldered more of the tax burden. In 1965 personal tax was levied at the rate of 33.4 per cent of the tax take, while by 1985 it had risen to 45.1 per cent. However, overall, the rate paid by the corporate giants has fallen from 16.2 per cent to 9.2 per cent. That is a significant fall. In talking about who is taking what from whom, in a debate like this one would be quite remiss to not point out that fact. Some of these companies that I have mentioned are involved, as businesses and individuals, the most notable among them being Mr Elliott, in very heavy lobbies to further reduce their tax liability-which, of course, they are not meeting anyway. They also involve themselves in all sorts of student bashing, politician bashing and welfare sector bashing-but one must point out that people who live in glass-houses should not throw stones. The Government needs to open its other eye and ascertain where fraud or, at the very least, sleight of hand, whether legal or not, is taking place.

The Government must present us with ways of preventing that from happening. As the Democrats have consistently said, it should begin by doing away with the possibilities of negative gearing, transfer pricing and the various other mechanisms that are available to these people involved. Some of these loopholes are being plugged, and the Government deserves credit for that. However, the Democrats are not prepared to support another knee-high jerk, anti-fraud, draconian, search and destroy type piece of legislation in relation to another Government department, and we consider that the Government ought to come up with some initiatives in these areas.

As to issues that have arisen in the community, the Democrats have noted the kind of attitude that the Government, and indeed the Opposition, has to groups such as student bodies. The Government is unable to accept the fact that, for instance, the imposition of a $250 fee has reduced access for a significant group of people in the community to tertiary institutions. These are groups that I consider are significant, such as those involving mature age women who want to re-enter the training system. They, of course, have been encouraged to do that by the new labour market programs of this Government, programs such as that abolishing the widow's pension and that which has dramatically reduced access to sole parent benefits. These people then have a fee slapped on them, considered by the Government not to be too much. It is considered that it is only, say, a couple of days travel allowance for a politician, but it might be an awful lot for a woman who is at the beginning of a study course. She might be a sole parent or perhaps be part of a single income family and dependent on her husband for support, or it might involve a woman who is trying to combine part time paid work with part time study.

To have to come up with that fee at the beginning of a course, together with all the other start-up payments, is a disincentive that is in-built in the system, and students are not prepared to take it. All senators would be aware that, after a fairly quiet decade in this regard, student militancy is on the increase again-and so it rightly should be. The voice of students needs to be heard at a time when the cake is getting smaller, when access to payments is being reduced and when further impositions are being placed on the student body in our community. At this time students need to exercise their voice, and the Democrats support the students in what they are doing.

The second stage of the anti-fees campaign is now under way. I understand that the students have resolved to lobby the Australian Labor Party and the unions before the ALP conference. I would suggest to them that they also need to look very closely at the policies and the actions of all the political parties and, as they have done before, recognise that in this instance the Australian Democrats consider that the provision of education is not an extra cost on the community but the development of a resource. Unfortunately, what is ahead of them is probably the same as what has occurred previously-namely, that getting a policy through the ALP conference is fine, but the next thing is that it has to go through the ALP Cabinet, and very often the Executive Government has not shown itself to be sympathetic to the policies of that party.

On the other side of Parliament there is the Opposition, which is prepared to withdraw from exercising its responsibility as an opposition and to say that it will never oppose anything that is part of Budget legislation. However, a smart government opposite can say, `Righto, we have two sitting sessions a year so we will have two Budgets a year, and that will deal with them'. So, the students have very much an uphill battle when it comes to the major conservative parties in this place. They do, however, have the very strong support behind them of the Australian Democrats in policy and in action in this Parliament, as well as out in the community.

As I have said, we do deplore the fact that the cake is not increasing, although the Government, mouthing the words, might say otherwise, and that access is constantly being tightened-and the figures show that. It is not the case that more students are getting Austudy payments. Here we are faced with a piece of legislation which is assuming guilt and which is proposing the implementation of draconian measures, such as those that already exist in the Department of Social Security. The Democrats support the Opposition's second reading attachment. We will move some amendments in committee. At this stage I indicate that we oppose the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Vanstone has pointed out, the coalition supports the Student Assistance Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, the basic aim of which is to prevent fraud and to recover overpayments associated with student assistance provided under the Austudy scheme. Senator Vanstone also referred to a report prepared by Price Waterhouse, which was obtained by my colleagues the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) and the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) under the freedom of information legislation. The report indicated that there is evidence of extensive abuse of the student assistance schemes, referring, for example, to post-graduate students undertaking full-time jobs while in receipt of a student's allowance and under- graduate students who withdraw from studies without informing the Education Department.

SPEECH.PARA: The report further indicates that there has been no detailed review of applications processing since 1982 and that no anti-fraud work has been done in the Department. It is alleged that the extent of the fraud is in the range of tens of millions of dollars. My colleague Senator Watson, in an attempt to clarify the extent of this fraud, asked a question in Senate Estimates Committee C on Tuesday, 19 April regarding the estimate of loss through fraud and overpayment of student assistance allowances since 1982 and, understandably, is still awaiting a reply. So it is not possible at this time to estimate exactly the real cost of this fraud, but one would believe that it is very extensive. This legislation is well overdue when one thinks how much more effectively the money obtained fraudulently would be used if properly directed to students in genuine need.

I took some umbrage at Senator Powell's suggestion that the Australian Democrats have a monopoly on student interests. As a former teacher in a tertiary institution, I am very aware of issues confronting students and believe that as a member of the coalition I have an obligation to point out to my colleagues some of the problems and issues faced by students under current situations. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the situation faced by students in receipt of full Austudy, and I am speaking here of some 60 per cent of students receiving assistance. Brian Pitcher, the student welfare office at La Trobe University, in a paper presented to the Australian and New Zealand Student Services Association in Auckland in January of this year, refers to a handout provided by the Department of Education to prospective overseas students which states:
A single student will need about $8,000-$9,000 a year for living expenses.

The Department is indicating to overseas students the level of finance that it believes is a minimum required to sustain a student throughout a full academic year. On the one hand, the Government is telling one group, the overseas students, that they need $8,000-$9,000 and, on the other hand, eligible students receiving full Austudy by implication are being told something else.

Students on full Austudy receive $4,768 and are allowed to earn up to $2,000 before their Austudy is reduced. The student pays $400.32 tax if receiving full Austudy plus earning $2,000, and is left with $6,367.68, which falls short of the recommended amount that overseas students are asked to have if they are to support themselves throughout a year of academic study. To get close to the target suggested by the Education Department for overseas students, a student needs to earn $6,000. Students receive $2,768 in Austudy, having had their Austudy reduced by $1 for every $2 earned over $2,000; they pay tax of $880.32 and are left with $7,887.68, getting close to the recommended amount for overseas students. These figures are given by Mr Pitcher in the paper to which I referred earlier.

The $2,000 income allowable before a reduction in Austudy has not been reviewed since 1981. Had it been reviewed or indexed to the consumer price index, it would now be $3,500 and put the student within striking distance of the income recommended for overseas students. Maintenance of this allowable income at the $2,000 level has, I believe, forced a number of students into the black economy-that is, going into jobs, being paid under the counter, and perhaps even being ripped off in the system. Many of us know of students who are working under not ideal conditions to earn money to put themselves through university. As a former undergraduate student in receipt of a scholarship who supported myself fully, I feel great sympathy for students, as I was subjected to this limit. Many of my colleagues thought of all sorts of ways to try to get around it. I do not suggest that we should increase Austudy, but a review of the allowable income could be one way of ensuring that students are not forced into the black economy or forced out of the system.

When this Bill was before the House of Representatives, I decided to make inquiries of people closely associated with students who receive assistance. I refer to the student welfare officers at some of the major institutions in Victoria. I received a very extensive reply from the student welfare officers at a number of institutions, including Monash University. I would like to present to the Senate some of the issues that they raised as anomalies that occur with the implementation of Austudy. First, they claim that overseas students who are permanent residents but whose parents earn income in an overseas country are eligible for the full Austudy allowance as their parents' overseas income is not means tested. Essentially a student can have wealthy parents working overseas and still qualify for Austudy.

The student welfare officers point out another problem which occurs in the area of spouse income. If a student's spouse earns less than $16,000 a year, the maximum Austudy allowance is payable. However, the allowance is reduced by $1 for every $2 by which the spouse's income exceeds $16,000. However, the parental income test differs. When adjusted family income is payable, the allowance is reduced by $2.50 for each full $10 by which the adjusted family income exceeds $16,000. Another anomaly which is pointed out by these student welfare officers is that students whose parents are separated or divorced can apply for Austudy supplying only the mother's taxable income, which may be minimal. This would entitle the student to full Austudy even if the father is earning an enormous amount and may still be supporting the applicant and well able to afford to do so.

Another anomaly that is pointed out is that a student classified as full time for the whole year so far as university status is concerned but who has an unbalanced workload across two semesters may lose Austudy benefits for six months. An example is a student who takes 12 points in first semester and 8 points in second semester. While this workload constitutes 83 per cent of the full time workload over the whole year, it represents only 66.6 per cent for the second semester. For the sake of one point in the second semester students have in some cases been denied Austudy benefits. This seems inconsistent with the requirement that only 50 per cent of subjects must be passed in order to qualify for ongoing Austudy payments. These two student welfare officers pointed out an individual case involving a student who passed three second-year subjects with high distinctions but $1,400-worth of Austudy payments was confiscated from the next year's allowance because her second semester workload had dropped to 66.6 per cent, while the total workload for the whole year was 85 per cent. It seems anomalous, as they point out, that another student with a slightly more balanced workload could continue to receive full Austudy having barely passed two subjects and failed two others. They go on to say that the list of anomalies is endless and that they are sure that they have not covered them all. I am sure that, if they were to sit down and think about more, they would be able to generate them. They indicate that they would be happy if some investigation of Austudy were to take place. I have listed only some of the anomalies they have pointed out. I seek leave to table this letter so that the Government may examine it in more detail, especially since it is from people who are closely associated with students who are receiving student allowances.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Opposition supports this legislation, which aims to reduce fraudulent activity associated with student assistance schemes. However, I would ask the Minister to address some of the problems associated with the administration of the scheme. Senator Vanstone has pointed out some of the problems associated with the introduction of the scheme last year, but I have been advised by the student counsellors and student welfare officers that the processing of Austudy applications has been reduced to about four to six weeks, which the students now accept as realistic. However, I would like to point out that there is one other problem associated with applying for Austudy, that is, it is almost impossible to contact Austudy offices at the beginning of the year. I have had complaints from constituents, and when one of my staff members sought to obtain information about Austudy the final resort was a visit to the office. That is all very well for students who live in the city, but it is an impossibility for rural students who want to know about Austudy. I would ask the Minister whether the problem of the peak traffic jam of inquiries at the beginning of the year could be addressed so that we do not have the problem of students being delayed, not being able to get their applications in by 31 March, and therefore being denied Austudy for some time because their application was not in because they were unable to obtain the information that they required. I would also ask the Minister to address the anomaly of the suggested $8,000-$9,000 required by overseas students and the problems associated in achieving this when the allowable income for Australian students receiving Austudy has not been reviewed since 1981. I would also ask that the Government investigate the anomalies in the scheme, examples of which I have given as provided by the student welfare officers. It is important that student assistance schemes are administered equitably and effectively because the cost to the community, both socially and economically, of students withdrawing from courses, although difficult to quantify, is unacceptable if it can be avoided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Student Assistance Legislation Amendment Bill, which amends the Student Assistance Act 1973 to include a package of measures to facilitate the prevention of fraud and the recovery of overpayments. The proposed measures are comparable to the existing provisions of the Social Security Act which have been labelled as `search and destroy' provisions. The Bill amends the Act in order to require individuals and organisations to provide information needed to verify entitlements and require debtors to disclose their financial situation. It also makes it an offence to give false information in relation to an application for assistance. It also provides substantial penalties for offences under the Act-a fine of $2,000 and/or 12 months imprisonment instead of a maximum of $100. The Bill will also enable the Department of Employment, Education and Training to recover overpayments from money held for a debtor and it will enable an overpayment to be written off or waived, or to be repaid by instalments.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to proposed section 31c, which will allow an overpayment to be written off or waived, it is reasonable that these powers be exercised by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) rather than the Minister for Finance, and when I say that I mean no disrespect for Senator Walsh. I do have major concerns, however, about three sections: the size of the penalties, the powers of authorities and the abrogation of a person's protection against self-incrimination. Proposed section 31d, which requires individuals and organisations to provide information, would permit an authorised person to obtain information about a recipient of student assistance. This may be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties, since the power is to be exercised `for the purposes of the Act'. Yet a person from whom information was required would not necessarily know what those purposes were. Nor would that person necessarily know his or her rights as to whether the authorised person was justified in seeking information. The Minister has advised that this information cannot be used in criminal proceedings against the person; nevertheless, there remain very real concerns about the potential abuse of personal rights and liberties. Proposed section 31e would repeal a person's protection against self-incrimination. It does not prevent the use of information obtained indirectly from the documents produced being used in evidence. Once again, it may be considered to trespass on a person's rights and liberties. The Minister claims that it is desirable for the Student Assistance Act to follow the provisions of the Social Security Act in this respect, but, just because legislation is based on precedent legislation of search and destroy, it does not mean that it is beyond reproach.

I am horrified at the level of the penalty and I cannot believe that it was decided on deliberately. I hope that it was an accident and that the Minister will allow it to be amended, because the penalty is $2,000 or 12 months imprisonment. Something does not seem to add up when a fine of $2,000 is made equivalent to 12 months in prison. It occurs to me, and this seems to be obvious, that if people request Austudy because they feel that they need the absolute pittance that it provides obviously they will not be able to afford a fine of $2,000. So anyone who is convicted of an offence under this section will obviously go to gaol for 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't mean that. That is the maximum fine.

—The maximum term of imprisonment is 12 months, but the maximum fine is only $2,000. I suggest that that is inequitable, and in my view the term of imprisonment should be reduced to about one month. As an aside, I believe that in general the equivalence between fines and imprisonment leaves a lot to be desired in the sense that I would much rather see it based on potential income so that people are fined an amount equivalent to their earning potential. I think that that would be much better. I would certainly support an amendment to this provision and, in fact, I believe that the Democrats will move an amendment during the committee stage. I have much more to say but, given the time, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to bring before the Senate a matter of extreme importance and to make good, honest and decent Australians aware of the dangers associated with the Australian League of Rights, which is often described as an extreme right wing organisation. The Australian League of Rights was first established in South Australia in 1946 and became a national network in 1960. Its founder, Eric Butler, is still the National Director and until recently he was assisted by Mr Jeremy Lee. The League has exercised varying degrees of influence over Australian politics. It has been both vigorously defended and attacked over its policies and methods of operation.

SPEECH.PARA: At times it has reared its head, and at other times it has gone to ground. It has been enduring and elusive. It has been claimed that the League is responsible for printing and distributing more political literature than all the other major parties put together. The League attacks elected representatives from all parties and denigrates a democratic system of government, while at the same time running its own organisation on a strictly autocratic basis. The League thrives wherever there is discord, dissension, frustration, fear, resentment and financial hardship. It flourishes in times of drought, low commodity prices, high foreign debt, and high interest rates, and recent events have led to an unprecedented expansion of its powers, influence and number of supporters.

My message today is that we-that is, every senator, member, elected representative and community leader, and every citizen of Australia-must take the trouble to be aware of groups like the League of Rights, to investigate what their real policies and motivations are, and especially to understand how they operate. The League should no longer be dismissed as harmless for its subtle pressure is becoming more widespread. Indeed, the League of Rights should be exposed no matter what its degree of influence because it does nothing to advance the rights or welfare of Australians. To the contrary, it sows dissension and preys on people's fears, exploiting and manipulating target groups as tools to promote the League's policies.

Let me say from the outset that, because of the way the League operates and the plausible policies it starts with, many Australians have understandably become sympathetic to the League. Because of the League structure and its myriad of front organisations and offshoot associations many people are not even aware that they have become tools and puppets for the League. These ordinary Australians are seeking only to become more involved in community affairs. There is absolutely no blame to attach to them. They come from all walks of life.

I personally was briefly an innocent vehicle. On 11 March the Courier-Mail carried a headline `Nats boss tackles League of Rights'. The League responded by replying that I had asked the League to man polling booths. I subsequently made a statement to this House in the affirmative. I also may have launched a book for it, although the invitation to do so did not come from the League itself. I found later the book was published by Veritas Press, which my research has shown to be closely connected to the League, so that now I assume it may have been a League publication.

At that time, Madam Acting Deputy President, I, like many other decent and well-meaning Australians today, was under the impression that the League of Rights upheld many of the values my Party espoused. I have since learnt a lot more about the League and have devoted the resources available to me to find out the truth about the League and what it really stands for. My response was then to bring this matter to the attention of my colleagues, which directly led to the letter from Sir Robert Sparkes which was mentioned in the Courier-Mail and to my stand here today. I know from personal experience that the League's outside appeal is strong and real, but I say to all those who may be connected with the League or its offshoot groups: `Do not be used, do not be made a fool of, do not become a pawn in what is really a very dirty game; for the League of Rights is not what it appears'.

Australia is a true democracy; one of the very few. I am the first to concede that extremist organisations, whether they be the League of Rights or the Communist Party, have a right to exist and not to be driven underground by legislation. To do otherwise is to deny freedom of speech and assembly to our great Australian democracy. My concern is that the League is not open about what its objectives are. Its members do not tell the people the history of their organisation or what their underlying motives are. They will not tell their followers that they are racist, anti-Semitic and neo-nazi. That is the essence and the dark side of the League of Rights. It is a side that few people are aware of, for naturally the League hides from such a socially unacceptable agenda.

The League's public face is for God, Queen and country and support for State rights, free enterprise, the Constitution, the family farm and small business. It is only natural that many decent men and women are attracted to these objectives, which are laudable and noble. However, the more extreme side of the League is introduced insidiously by degrees through its extensive network of organisations and with the aid of offset printing presses to produce masses of literature; now cassettes and videos are the new weapons in its armoury.

League speakers travel to targeted groups, hiring halls where necessary. Though seldom flaunting the League's name, they are skilful and articulate speakers and speak with authority on local issues, national and international economic and political issues.

Years of experience have taught them how to identify and lock in on local prejudice and resentment. The League's approach is firstly to enlarge on the distressful situation of a particular community; then to describe in elaborate details some conspiracy theory as to how this has happened; and thirdly to propose nice sounding but impractical solutions; a simple method but one which works extremely well. Madam Acting Deputy President, the League of Rights is the pied piper of Australian politics. It draws upright, hardworking men and women closer to its inner circle and hidden agenda.

The League of Rights is not fussy about who it targets. Its directors are sophisticated strategists; they promote League ideology to small business groups, churches, women's organisations and many other disaffected groups. The emphasis is not on attracting League members per se but on getting those groups to use League thinking, arguments and literature. In order to reach such a variety of interest groups and to keep their more subversive policies hidden in the background, the League uses a number of front organisations or, if necessary, it will set up a new local organisation on the spot.

I should mention that another key part of its structure is the creation of elector policy associations, particularly in targeted electorates. Its most established front organisations have been the Institute for Economic Democracy, Ladies in Line Against Communism, the Christian Institute for Individual Freedom, the Australian Heritage Society and the Conservative Speakers Club. These are only a minority of the groups the League has fostered and I seek leave to have a figure showing the League's structure and a table outlining the front organisations incorporated into Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of these groups run school seminars and meetings and issue regular publications such as Enterprise, Intelligence Line, On Target, New Times and Ladies Line. Other reading material and tapes receive wide circulation throughout the supporters community. They are taught to bombard politicians, candidates and the media with letters, telephone calls and meetings in carefully orchestrated campaigns. Instructions on what to do and what to say and how to say it come from an unelected, unopposed, centralised hierarchy, far removed from the supporters and certainly not from the supporters' own initiatives or thoughts.

SPEECH.PARA: This results in a type of passive coercion on political candidates to gain a more vocal voice at the expense of alternative views. Effectively the minds of Jeremy Lee and Eric Butler feed and control and hence distort the voices of many. The voices of these supporters are themselves trained to be more vocal than the other members of the community and this is certainly not democracy. Over the last 12 months I have seen an alarming escalation of the League's activities. It has made inroads into the churches, the charismatic churches, the fundamentalist churches and established churches. Many are being used as innocent vehicles to spread the word of the League of Rights.

While openly admiring the administrative facilities of the churches Jeremy Lee sanctimoniously suggests that the churches need to create a new ministry to inform and educate their members on the terrible conspiracies which threaten their very existence and to learn how to work against them. He adds, in a worried tone, that he does not know where the churches will get their information from or how they will do it. Could it be that the League's printing presses will be galvanised into action to help out? In the particular address that I am referring to Mr Lee then leads a group in prayer before introducing the notorious Peter Sawyer.

Before enlarging on the Peter Sawyer connection I would like to cite another example of the League's most visible recent target. As all senators would know, I have vigorously opposed World Heritage listing on the grounds of its intrusion into State rights, the loss of jobs, the effect on family life and the general negative economic impact on small towns in the area. I have visited the area on eight or nine occasions. Now I am in almost daily contact with the people up there. I have been alarmed at the reactionary activity of the League of Rights members who moved in to take advantage of the unrest almost as soon as this Government's intentions were known. They are extremely active up there and are attracting as many as 450 people to their meetings.

The League of Rights offers the bewildered timber workers a fascinating theory on why their jobs are being sacrificed. These decent, honest men and their families are told of a plan by Jewish bankers to take over their forests and lands to add to their own equity base under an international treaty. International treaties and organisations are generally equated by the League with one world government conspiracy. While this breathtaking plan may seem ridiculous to senators in this House you must put yourselves in these people's position; that the area is divided and under threat of economic hardship and uncertainty. These convincing League speakers are there on the spot, encouraging the fears and resentments of the local communities.

The people are listening to a voice that is a lone cry in the wilderness. The League's original policies and theories were based on Social or Douglas Credit economic policy, which has been soundly thrashed by recognised governments and by recognised economists. This has been done worldwide. Simply put, it states that if only a government would print more money and lend it at token rates of interest, then all problems would be solved and everyone could live in a virtual Utopia.

The theories go further than this, however. They contain a strong anti-Semitic content, saying that the economic crises were deliberately engineered by the banks as a result of these institutions being in the control of the Jews, intent on world domination. This is the common theme pushed by the League in its conspiracy theory. The history of the League's anti-Semitism is well recorded, beginning with Butler's venomous anti-Semitic book, The International Jew, which blames the Jews for nearly every calamity in mankind's history and claims that Hitler was Jewish and his policies were part of a Jewish policy aimed at world dominance. The Holocaust is refuted. Butler denies that six million Jews were exterminated. He accepts only that the conditions in concentration camps deteriorated as the war caused difficulties in obtaining adequate food supplies. He says that there may have been isolated acts of barbarism; he concedes that.

Butler explains that there was certainly a lot of typhus around and, unfortunately, the crematoriums were inadequate to house all the corpses. The League bookshops are stocked with titles like, The Diary of Ann Frank-a Hoax, Debunking the Genocide Myth and, Non Dare Call it a Conspiracy, in addition to the numerous other racist covers. Should anyone be interested in finding out more about nazism I believe the League bookshop stocks most of the Nazi Party's recommended reading list. Naturally the League tries to distance itself from such strong anti-Semitism, particularly Butler's work, The International Jew, since it was published some time ago.

Butler has stated comparatively recently that those views are still his views and the League has never publicly disociated itself from any of his statements. In addition to being the deputy national director of this organisation which disseminates anti-Semitism and racial hatred, Jeremy Lee also publicly defends Butler and as late as October 1987 Lee chaired the annual League dinner in Melbourne. (Extension of time granted) Lee chaired the annual dinner in Melbourne at which David Irving was given a standing ovation.

Honourable senators will no doubt recall that Irving was the author of Churchill's War, a book that blamed Churchill for extending the war and botching the Allies' efforts. Mr Irving also claimed that Hitler was innocent of issuing any orders for the Holocaust; that he was not responsible for the annihilation of some six million Jews. Churchill's War, needless to say, was rejected by mainstream publishers worldwide, only to be picked up by Veritas Press in Western Australia, a company that publishes and distributes material strikingly identical to that of the League's Conservative and Heritage bookshops. That the League's heavies should give a man like Irving a standing ovation and actively assist in his promotional tour of Australia shows that essentially nothing has changed in the League's core doctrine of anti-semitism, neo-nazism, and its hate-filled accusation of a Jewish conspiracy to enslave the world.

The League's dim view of World War II events should also not come as a surprise if one turns back to a Commonwealth parliamentary board of inquiry in 1946. Mr Justice Reed, who headed the inquiry, compared Butler's writings with those of the British traitor, John Amery Jr, and with nazi propaganda. The inquiry arose as a result of Butler's supporters protesting loudly about the measures being taken to further the Australian war effort. In its examination of Butler's writing, the Reed report concluded:

Certain similarities will be observed with Nazi propaganda . . . anti-Semitism and the alleged activities of the international financiers have been prominent points of Nazi propaganda . . . Some of the propaganda used by the enemy coincides with many of the arguments used by those interested in social credit and monetary reform and attacks our institution of government, on wartime measures and on the present monetary system of the nature to which we have referred, may be exactly what the Nazis would desire.
I doubt that many service clubs and associations, which have invited Butler and Lee to speak to them in the past, are aware of this commission of inquiry or its findings.

A fundamental tenet of the League's policy is to denounce the party political system and its form of democracy. The League engages in smear campaigns against all politicians. Let me quote from an address by a past assistant director of the League, Mr Edward Rock, as reported in the New Times of March 1972:

Party representatives, irrespective of their demand for increased salaries, are no more than highly paid slaves of the bureaucracy. They are highly paid to keep them docile, content to serve and fawn, dependent upon the power of the bureaucracy to provide all the answers to our growing problems. They have abdicated their responsibility and, in abdicating their responsibility, they have committed the cardinal sin. We have erected a party political system, through which we are selling our freedom for a mess of pottage.

People who listen to too much League propaganda will lose all respect for their elected representatives and the parliamentary institution and all confidence in the parliamentary system of party politics. Their conservatism will turn to frustration and angry radicalism. Australia is one of a minority of countries operating in a democratic system of government. In this year of our Bicentenary our democratic traditions are our proudest achievement. Let us not allow it to be undermined by subversive groups and destructive groups like the League of Rights.

Most of the people of this world point to us with envy and admiration. Certainly no system is ever perfect and elected representatives must continually be challenged to work to the best of their ability in the interests of Australians. Such challenges are part of what makes democracy the best form of government. But the League goes much further than this, attacking the very roots of our parliamentary democracy. League publications argue that the `function of parties is to keep people arguing and obsessed with matters of little relevance'. Butler has written that the party system of government can play very little part, if any, in the struggle for real democracy. In principle, it is the antithesis of democracy.

This comes from a man who dictates to his supporters what they are to say and feel about political issues; a self-styled and self-declared leader with no democratic support. With this in mind, we must be careful to examine in great detail any proposals backed by the League which alter the present shape of our parliamentary political system. One such proposal was the Swiss voter referendum, which has been strongly advocated by the League, among others. If initiated, it could be exactly the type of tool most useful to the League. It could enable them to use their massive propaganda machine even more effectively to become closer than ever before to setting the political agenda in Australia. As a committed Christian, I find it particularly repulsive that the League has recently chosen to penetrate the churches, particularly as the League, through Butler's writings, has promoted the heretical belief that Jesus Christ was not a Jew. He wrote that the Gospel of John indicates beyond all reasonable doubt that Jesus Christ was not regarded as a Jew, or as having been born in Judea, which is a great contradiction to the Bible.

The same organisation that this Eric Butler heads, sends its speakers into churches, not to teach the word of God, but to fascinate Christians with talk of economic conspiracies and political intrigue in the context of end-time events. The League's ideas of the Jewish world conspiracy are cleverly interwoven with prophecies from the Book of Revelation, incorporating references to many current issues, such as the ID card, the stockmarket collapse, and so on. Mr Butler has spoken against what is contained in the Bible on more than one occasion. For example, he claims that one of the most destabilising myths of this century is that the Jews are descendants of the chosen people of the biblical times. Yet Butler's deputy, until earlier this year, Mr Lee, has had numerous invitations to speak to church groups. He also stands up in front of church congregations and preaches, all despite the fact that the essence of the League's policies and philosophies is an anathema to the Christian ideology.

I warn all pastors and ministers not to allow their churches to be used as a platform for organisations which relish denigrating parliament, and promote a world conspiracy theory and Social Credit as the panacea to all the worldly problems. As for Mr Peter Sawyer of Deakin Centre fame, who has been responsible for senators and members being inundated with calls from distraught constituents with the most outrageous allegations, I am not sure what his underlying motives are. He is also pushing the League line. As Sawyer's allegations become more eccentric, more lurid, Jeremy Lee has begun to disclaim him and to distance the League from him.

Lee has also vacated his official executive position with the League, but is still an active member. It is the same Mr Lee who said this about Mr Sawyer when he introduced him at a church speaking engagement:

I believe it is a privilege to be able to come round with Peter, he is new in this field, but he is a man with enormous courage. I suppose you could say he is a rebel. I think we need rebels at this time. He has a stark story. I think it is a frightening story. He's got to tell it dogmatically, because if you spend the time documenting each of these things he has been saying, we would be here for five or six hours. But I want to tell you this documentation is there, and it fits in with my own experience. So all I can do is ask you to listen to Peter.

Again on 25 November at a Gold Coast church, Jeremy Lee took the stage and introduced Mr Peter Sawyer, saying that he had invited Sawyer to do a series of meetings and words to the effect that he was concerned and convinced about what Sawyer was saying. From September 1987 to January 1988 Sawyer issued the Inside News which received wide circulation. In addition he distributed thousands of tapes, all carrying the same line as the League, throughout the churches and other organisations. (Extension of time granted) There is neither time nor need to go into all of Sawyer's allegations here. I would, however, seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a list of his predictions, numbered one to 64.
Leave granted.
