SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the contribution of Senator Boswell on the League of Rights is an important contribution to the Senate and to public debate and I would want to acknowledge that and hope that other honourable senators would share that sentiment. His comments have been detailed, documented, accurate, and therefore important and they are timely. It is not necessary to rehearse the details of the matters which Senator Boswell has brought before the Senate today, but there can be no doubt that the League of Rights espouses values inconsistent with the liberal democratic traditions to which so many of us are committed.

SPEECH.PARA: These ideals emphasise truth, tolerance, generosity; these ideals value diversity and they seek and promote the empowering of individuals. Those ideals which I just read out are not consistent with a social control paradigm, nor with intolerance, with prejudice, nor with the incitement of hatred. Liberal democratic traditions sit poorly with the authoritarian social control approach of the League of Rights. It is not surprising, indeed it is almost inevitable, that serious political leaders should find the League of Rights message to be anathema to them. Nor is it surprising that the same political leaders should respond so savagely to the League of Rights and to its representatives. The League of Rights is malevolent; it is malignant and it is destructive to people and their values

The League of Rights spreads hatred, discord and dissatisfaction. It weakens society rather than strengthening it and the League of Rights hides its activities. As Senator Boswell has laid out, the League of Rights operates not openly but through a myriad of front organisations whose links back to the League are always murky and are constantly changing. Its operations are covert. It is hard for the citizen to know with whom he or she is dealing or to whom they report.

The funding of the League is hidden as well. I do not know where the funds come from. I do not know whether a mass of small donors provides the funds or whether some eccentric millionaires do their part as well. Much of the literature which emerges from the organs of the League does not bear its name. So that in its operations and in its practises it is a deceptive organisation. It practices deception on the community within which it operates; on the victims who are subject to its assaults; they never know clearly by whom they are being attacked. It practises its deception, too, on those who join one or more of its organs in good faith. Not only this, but the League of Rights operates within a special and vulnerable constituency.

It works on the fears of people rather than on their hopes. It works on their insecurities. It works on their uncertainties and it works on their ignorance. The League of Rights seeks out and finds people as Senator Boswell has said, people who are insecure, fearful, uncertain or ignorant and it finds those people to be fertile ground for its message. Honourable senators would have heard already that the League preaches an anti-immigration line and would know that the League preaches especially an anti-immigration line which is opposed to non-white immigration into Australia.

This League of Rights line rests squarely and depends squarely upon those human weaknesses and failings I have already mentioned. It requires that people be ignorant, fearful, uncertain, threatened and insecure and it thrives only because there are people who feel in that way. Saying all this about the League of Rights only brings before us the dilemma-the League of Rights highlights the dilemma-faced always by democrats in an open society. That dilemma is how we deal with those who misuse the arrangements that we make in a democracy or how to deal with those whose agenda might be undemocratic or even antidemocratic.

It is not unlike the problem which Israel has had to face in the last few years in dealing with the likes of Rabbi Meir Kahane and the interests which he represents. The answer certainly is not to outlaw them. Israel has certainly not sought to outlaw the activities of Rabbi Kahane. I seem to recall we made that error here in 1951 at the height of the McCarthy years when we in this country attempted a referendum which sought to outlaw the Communist Party. The anticommunist referendum in 1951 was one of the low points of Australian democratic practice.

The late Alan Missen saw it for what it was. He, among others, worked tirelessly for the defeat of that referendum. He was successful but he was suspended from the Liberal Party of Australia for his efforts. The answer to the dilemma for liberal democrats, for those working in the liberal democratic tradition, is not to attempt to outlaw or to suppress the enemies of democracy. In its own way the League of Rights is an enemy of liberal democratic values. To outlaw it or to suppress it would itself destroy the values on which the democracy rests. That is why that is not the approach to take, never has been and never will be.

Senator Boswell made that point in his address. Of itself such an action-suppression, proscription, banning-would give the enemies of democracy an immediate and lasting victory. Neither is the answer to the dilemma we face to ignore the enemies. To do this, as we have too often done, and as we have done too often with the League of Rights, is to surrender the field without a fight and to lose the battle by inaction. The fact is that bigots, haters, racists, extremists, psychopaths and liars are all citizens, too, and the rights we have developed and which we protect so jealously, we protect for them as well. That is our dilemma. None of us wishes to suppress the League of Rights. None of us wishes to limit its right to operate within our democracy just because its values and its aims and its methods are so offensive to most of us.

Our object is different. Our object, and I am sure the object of Senator Boswell today, has been to inform, to expose, to disclose and to reveal the web and the aims and the activities of the League of Rights. This has been a courageous undertaking by Senator Boswell, not without its risk to the honourable senator. Senator Boswell has had some contact previously with the League of Rights, as has his party, and he cannot expect to escape criticism and abuse from the League and from its fellow travellers following his speech today. That makes what he has done all the more courageous and emphasises even more just how deeply he feels about the priority which this exercise requires.

This exposure which he has carried out today is necessary. It is necessary to allow more Australians to know more about the League of Rights, to understand more about what it is and to understand more some of the things for which it stands. This exposure will allow existing and intended dupes of the League to assess their positions. I hope that the ministers of the Christian denominations in Brisbane will read and digest the appeal which Senator Boswell has made directly to them about the invitations which they might make to League speakers to occupy their pulpits or to speak in their churches. This exposure will allow citizens to prepare responses within themselves to the blandishments of whichever of the front organisations of the League of Rights they are unfortunate enough to come into contact with.

Mr Acting Deputy President, it is likely that a more informed clientele, a more informed public is a more powerful and a more autonomous clientele and, of course, if we can provide more information and make people more informed, we are achieving one of our liberal democratic ideals, which is to empower people everywhere. A policy better able to make reasonable and reasoned individual decisions is a more powerful agent for the preservation of democracy and if that can be the outcome of what Senator Boswell has started today, we will all be well served and better off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to congratulate Senator Boswell on his detailed exposure of the evil and covert activities of the League of Rights and I rise to support him for what I believe to be a most courageous speech, as indicated by Senator Peter Baume. This century has seen a massive increase in propaganda. With hindsight, we can see that one of the major causes-perhaps the major cause-of the disastrous First World War was propaganda which built up national pride in Europe prior to 1914 to such a degree that many came to believe that a war was inevitable and, in fact, desirable, as if it was some great sporting contest. Of course, history's greatest example of the evil use of propaganda occurred with the rise of the Third Reich when Dr Goebbels and his Ministry of Public Enlightenment and Propaganda manipulated the thoughts and the emotions of a whole nation.

SPEECH.PARA: The nazis exploited the German people with demagoguery and jingoism and successfully discouraged the sober analysis of facts. The nazi propaganda stratagems involved monopolisation of the media; the displacement of guilt onto others using the Jews as scapegoats, the presentation of Germans as morally superior; the denigration of political opponents and the coordination of propaganda with violence and bribery and charges of conspiracy against all those who were seen as a threat to their aims.

Those stratagems have a great deal in common with the stratagems now being used by the Australian League of Rights in this nation. Charges of conspiracy were an important element in nazi propaganda, directing attention away from the truth by manipulating half-truths and exploiting the people's fears. In those days prior to the Second World War in Australia these extremist views were usually confined to such places as the Yarra Bank in Melbourne, Hyde Park in Sydney or similar venues in other cities. In fact, I can remember with great joy going to the Yarra Bank as a young child with my parents and listening to people who, in today's terms, would be described as nutters, but they always provided great fun. I was very young and my father used to explain to me that they were talking about the end of the world being nigh, new religions and new philosophies. Indeed, many of them were con men. What they were talking about was all nonsense and we used to enjoy the afternoon out in the sunshine.

Nowadays, of course, with the massive facilities available for communication, with printing machines able to produce thousands of copies of articles, with video cassettes and radio cassettes, these nutters are able to have a greater reach in the community and therefore their extreme and indeed crazy views on many occasions are able to reach a much wider audience.

The principles involved by the nazis in generating their propaganda have been subtly refined by the Australian League of Rights utilising these modern technologies that I have referred to and also modern marketing techniques. It is involved in a most sophisticated operation. In Australia back in 1934 a journal called the New Times was launched to popularise the Social Credit theories of an English economist, Major C. H. Douglas, who blamed the banks and Jewish financiers for the 1929-32 World Depression and his writings were violently anti-Semitic. The half- truth employed was that there were some prominent Jewish bankers. That was translated into a conspiracy by Jewish financiers in which it was claimed that they were responsible for the World Depression. The New Times also asserted that the nazis were being maligned by reports in other newspapers of indignities and persecutions being aimed at the Jewish population. It referred to `Those who can always be relied upon to froth at the mouth over the treatment of Jews in Germany and elsewhere, but show little sympathy for the victims of Jewish financiers in many other places'.

Until the outbreak of World War II the New Times was markedly pro-Axis, supporting the Japanese invasion of China, the fascist regimes of Germany and Italy and the claims of Hitler in respect of Poland. One Eric Butler was a major contributor to the journal through these years and was a spokesman and organiser for the United Electors movement which was linked with it. The nazi-Soviet pact was hailed as a sign that the power of international finance would soon be crushed and Winston Churchill was attacked as being a tool of the Jews. In 1944 attempts were made by the New Times to undermine the war effort by attacking war loans campaigns and such measures as meat rationing. This culminated in 1944 in what became known as the Dean affair, which ended up with a conspiracy action being alleged by certain people associated with Eric Dean and the League of Rights.

A parliamentary inquiry was ultimately set up to investigate the allegations contained in certain circulars and Eric Butler appeared as a witness to that inquiry. The inquiry concluded that the authors of the circulars were not in any way motivated by a bona fide desire to protect the interests of justice, but their objective was to attack the present system of justice as being fraudulent and illegal and a good deal of their opposition to the present financial and monetary system was found to be based solely on anti-Jewish sentiments.

The Australian League of Rights was founded by Eric Butler, the author of those extremist anti-Jewish sentiments, and he is still the national director. Until recently he was assisted by a Mr Jeremy Lee. The thread of conspiracy I have outlined has developed into a pattern which continues today. The League has exercised varying degrees of influence over Australian politics since its inception. It is responsible for printing and distributing more political literature than the major Australian political parties. The League attacks and denigrates elected representatives from all parties and points to alleged flaws in our democratic system while at the same time running its own organisation from a strictly autocratic system.

Its modus operandi is to operate principally through front networks, using five or six separate organisations or indeed more, if necessary, thereby capitalising on the disaffection of various groups within the community on single or specific issues. The League thrives where there is discord, dissension, frustration, fear, resentment or financial hardship. Such things as drought, low commodity prices, high foreign debt or high interest rates are soon very much the subject of the League's writings.

Recently events have led to an unprecedented expansion of its attempted power, influence and the number of its supporters as the League and its front networks through propaganda and half-truths have exploited the concerns of ordinary, decent citizens and especially of ordinary decent Christian citizens. Every State and Federal parliamentarian, every member of local government, every community leader and every Australian citizen should be aware of the extremist and racist views of this dangerous organisation. It can no longer be dismissed as a harmless organisation of a lunatic fringe. Its insidious penetration of all walks of life through front networks is dangerous because it seeks to manipulate target groups to promote racist and undemocratic policies.

It uses its extensive front organisations and with modern technology is able to mass-produce pamphlets, literature, sound cassettes and videos. Front speakers travel to targeted groups, hiring halls when they are unable to penetrate local community organisations. The speakers are skilful and articulate and speak with authority on local, national and international issues. Their propaganda exploits local prejudices and resentments and expands them. It then proceeds to describe in elaborate detail some conspiracy theory to justify its arguments and focus attention away from the half-truths or the small element of truth in their arguments. They then apportion the blame, usually racially based, and propose a simple sounding but, in fact, totally impractical solution.

Let me say that the League is very skilful in hiding its real agenda behind a screen of what it describes as community concerns. Such community concerns attract a ready audience and most people attending such meetings would be unaware that they are being manipulated by the League. These are ordinary, decent concerned people and they are sucked in by clever, devious manipulative rhetoric.

Senator Boswell has told the Senate how he became involved with the League and how he launched a book for it through Veritas Press, which his research indicated subsequently was closely connected with the League. He has told us that, like many other decent and well-meaning Australians today, he was under the impression that the League of Rights upheld many of the values that his Party espoused. It is only when researching the philosophy and writing of the League's director, Eric Butler, that one discovers the carefully hidden agenda of the League, which is extremist, anti-Semitic, anti-democratic and neo-nazi.

The hidden agenda is where the danger lies. Members of the League carefully hide their origins, their underlying objectives, their racism, their neo-nazism. They hide this hidden agenda with their claims to stand for decency, God, Queen and country, and support for State rights, support for the Constitution, free enterprise, the family, the farm and small business. These are the covers for their hidden agenda. The League is not fussy who it targets. Its directors are sophisticated propagandists of the Goebbels mould. They promote League ideology to small business groups, churches, women's organisations, service clubs and political parties. The emphasis is on a soft-sell using modern marketing technology and sophisticated propaganda.

The League's front organisations range from newly formed specific issue groups to established Australia-wide organisations such as the Lilac League, the Christian Institute for Individual Freedom, the Australian Heritage Society and the Conservative Speakers Club. Senator Boswell in his speech has detailed the extent of these front organisations which issue regular publications such as Enterprise, On Target, the New Times and Ladies Line. Other reading material and tapes receive wide circulation throughout the community, targeting groups such as school teachers, parliamentarians and candidates. I currently have one such set of tapes in which a Mr Peter Sawyer details an alleged conspiracy to which I shall briefly refer in a moment. This conspiracy theme is an essential element in the League's propaganda.

The League appears to have made inroads into the fundamental churches, not only charismatic but also Presbyterian, Baptist and Lutheran churches, which are being used as innocent vehicles to spread its propaganda. Jeremy Lee suggested that the churches need to create a new ministry to inform and educate their members about the terrible conspiracies which threaten their very existence-shades of the Third Reich and the attempted and partially successful nazification of the Christian churches in Germany. Tens of thousands of tapes of these talks have been purchased by concerned citizens and circulated throughout Australia.

The League has recently targeted small towns throughout Australia with concerns about World Heritage listing. I am running out of time, Mr Deputy President, so I had better move onto my conclusion about all of this. The secret agenda of the League and its front organisations should be anathema to all Christians who believe in brotherly love but I doubt whether many churches, service clubs and associations which have invited Director Butler, Jeremy Lee or Peter Sawyer to speak are aware of the covert racist, anti-Semitic and neo-nazi principles of the League. Among its objects for the purpose of raising concern and hatred have been multiculturism, Aboriginal culture, Asian migration, non-British migration, the Negro race and even former Prime Minister Fraser's selection of Sir Zelman Cowen as Governor-General on the ground that he was Jewish.

The League also appeared to have unlimited funds and the question that must be asked is where it is obtaining the funds to operate such a costly propaganda machine through front organisations. The latest conspiracy theory advanced by Peter Sawyer has gone so far and is so unreal and unbelievable that even the League has backed away from it. Amongst some 60-odd predictions Sawyer alleged that the new Parliament House is to be the centre of a one world government; that Rockefeller has 22 grand mansions in the Australian Capital Territory to house the new rulers; and that the dynamic Rhodes scholar duo of Mr Hawke and Senator Stone are co-conspirators, together with other prominent parliamentarians.

The danger is that such far-fetched conspiracy theories can lead to the League being dismissed as an organisation of right wing extremist lunatics. The truth is that the League has cast its tentacles wide. It is divisive and subversive and it is exploiting the fears and concerns of ordinary, decent, concerned people to peddle the League's neo-nazi philosophy through numerous front organisations. Unexposed, the covert neo-nazi philosophy of the League poses a real threat to democracy and thousands of ordinary citizens are unaware that they are being manipulated.

In the Third Reich, thousands of Germans were manipulated in the same manner in the early 1930s and, too late, they became aware of the evil of the demagoguery of the nazi philosophy. All Australians should be on their guard to ensure that they are not the victims of this evil organisation, the League of Rights.

The speech read as follows-

Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1987-88, together with Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), which I shall introduce shortly, comprise the Additional Estimates for 1987-88.

In these Bills, Parliament is asked to appropriate moneys to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures additional to the appropriations made for 1987-88 under Appropriation Acts (Nos 1 and 2) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act.
These additional appropriations are required to meet commitments that have been approved by the Government since the Budget as well as requirements of an on-going nature.

The principal factors underlying the requirements include certain unavoidable cost and price increases and other parameter changes since the Budget was prepared. Although the Budget figuring contained allowances for prospective wage and salary increases, those amounts were not then appropriated, and funds are now required to meet the impact of the $6 per week national wage case decision and the Australian Public Service Office based second tier pay agreement, the latter two constituting a total of some $65m of the Additional Estimates in Bill 3.

No provision is made in these Bills in anticipation of the negotiation of other second tier increases. Any additional funding required for this purpose will be met under the separate appropriation provisions in section 6 of the Appropriation Act (No. 1) and section 5 of Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act, 1987-88.

Of the additional appropriations in the three Additional Estimates Bills totalling $654.7m, $501.0m is sought in Appropriation Bill No. 3, $153.4m in Appropriation Bill No. 4 and $0.3m in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill No. 2.

These amounts are offset in part by savings in the appropriations made by Appropriation Acts (Nos 1 and 2) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act 1987-88, reflecting the Government's continued determination to improve the efficiency of ongoing programs. These savings, amounting to $566.1m, are detailed under the relevant appropriation headings in the document, ``Statement of Savings Expected in Annual Appropriations'', which has been distributed to senators.

After allowance for prospective savings, the appropriations now sought represent a net increase of $88.6m in expenditures financed from annual appropriations. As a proportion of total estimated outlays-encompassing both annual and standing appropriations-this increase amounts to 0.1 per cent.

I now outline some of the main areas in respect of which the Government has found it necessary to seek additional provisions in the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) to meet expenditure for the ordinary annual services of the Government.

With regard to the Defence portfolio, gross Additional Estimates of $250.6m are sought in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) significantly offset by savings of $141.2m, giving a net increase in Consolidated Revenue Fund expenditures of $109.4m. The increase reflects price and exchange rate variations since the Budget, together with a number of rearrangements of appropriations to reflect costs associated with the sale of Williamstown Naval Dockyard ($24.8m for which revenue of $100m is recorded elsewhere), the one time costs of arrangements for the takeover of the management and operations of the Government Aircraft Factory by Aerospace Technologies of Australia Pty Ltd ($78m), the proposed acquisition of additional live-in accommodation for the Royal Australian Navy in Sydney and Cairns ($30.5m), and additional funding for the Defence Housing Authority, the bulk of which is to enable the capital program to be advanced from later years ($51.4m). Also included is an amount of $32.0m for the Defence Force second tier wage increase, largely offset by savings against a number of appropriations. Taking account of special appropriations, the unappropriated provision for defence salary increases and other transactions contributing to the defence function, total defence outlays are estimated to increase by $83.1m; $64.0m is included for the Australian Trade Commission to meet a higher than expected level of claims under the export market development grants scheme; $30.0m is included under the Department of Veterans' Affairs for:

A shift in activity from the repatriation hospitals to public and private hospitals mainly due to under achievement of the nurse recruitment targets for the former and cost increases since the Budget for the latter; and
A reallocation between appropriations necessitated by a delay in implementing the link with the Health Insurance Commission's payments system.
$13.7m is sought for the Department of Social Security primarily to cover the national wage case and second tier increases.

In addition, a total amount of $1.825m has been provided under the Department of Aboriginal Affairs for the purposes of consultation with the Aboriginal community and costs associated with the establishment of the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. Of this amount, some $0.7m has been provided as supplementation to the running costs of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs for the establishment of the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. This amount has been offset from the amount of $2.4m provided to the Department for a national consultative program. It is anticipated that $0.525m in savings will be realised from that provision.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 1.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications and relates to the fact that a number of owners of television stations are in actual or potential breach of the law relating to concentration of ownership. Will the Minister assure the Senate that all owners of television stations will be required to remain within the ownership limits in the manner prescribed by law, that the provisions of the law will be applied and enforced and that no special deals will be done for media mates of the Labor Government seeking to establish a television oligopoly in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the Government will ensure that the law that applies to ownership restrictions is enforced very rigorously by the proper body to do so-that is, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, not that the Tribunal needs any guidance from the Government in performing its duty pursuant to that law. It knows the law, it honours it and it has performed admirably in the past within the limits of the legislative regime that we have given it to do that particular job. In fact, the current controversy was, in a sense, triggered off by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal doing just that-setting a very tight time constraint within which Mr Holmes a Court had to divest himself of his Perth television channel if he wanted to retain ownership of his West Australian newspaper. It set 31 March as the last possible target date by which that decision had to be made and it made it clear that that date would be rigorously enforced. In doing so, it created a situation in which Mr Skase was a buyer of that channel rather earlier than he would have liked. Undoubtedly, he would have much preferred to let the policy debate on these issues sort itself out, as it would have, without his being intruded into the forefront of it.

ANSWER.PARA: I take the occasion yet again to make clear-as I have done on innumerable public occasions in the last few weeks-that there is no question whatsoever in this or any other instance of the Government acting in a particular way to advantage or favour any particular media proprietor. We have approached this in a thoroughly even-handed way with a very careful and keen regard for the public policy issues that are involved. We articulated those issues with a great deal of precision and vigour in the middle of last year when the issue arose-not in the context of any particular player, but just in the context of the general policy issue. On that occasion we made clear that 75 per cent of audience reach was an appropriate limit to set for each of the three commercial channels, that it did enable the achievement of economies of scale and that it did enable the cross-subsidisation of the smaller capital cities which would otherwise be denied the financial base on which to produce the kind of programming that commercial television viewers want. We articulated that case then and we continued to do so over subsequent months after the legislation had been forced into a narrower mould by some rather opportunistic pressure in this place from other parties.

We continued to make it clear that if there seemed likely to be any change of heart at any stage on the part of the Opposition parties, making possible a more rational ownership limit, we would be only too pleased and delighted to review the situation and the legislation. It was on the basis of that totally consistent Government position and on the basis of a perceived change of heart on the part of the Opposition as being imminent that the particular course of events developed so far as players such as Mr Skase were concerned. Mr Skase's great problem was to place as much credence as he did on the authority, credibility, reliability and, indeed, integrity of the Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Howard, and the shadow communications Minister, who led him to understand, as indeed they led other proprietors to understand, that a change of heart on the part of the Opposition was imminent. Mr Skase has found that he cannot rely on the credibility or the authority of Mr Howard. The whole community is now witnessing the debacle that flows from the Opposition for those reasons alone.

I reject absolutely any suggestion that this Government has reacted as it has on any policy issue involving the media, and this one in particular, as a result of any considerations of that kind. The policy reasons are clear. They have been clearly articulated by us over many months and they have been articulated in a very consistent way. That kind of consistency, clarity and understanding of the economic issues involved and that kind of authority and government leadership are all attributes that have been conspicuously absent from the Opposition's performance over the last few weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the Government's reforms of the Australian road transport industry. Can the Minister comment on the Government's current progress on its fast track package of reforms designed to give the road transport industry in Australia a new deal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not so dramatic, but it is another demonstration of good government at work. The December 1987 meeting of the Australian Transport Advisory Council, involving Federal, State and Territory transport Ministers, agreed to a further package of reforms for the road transport industry to be implemented during 1988. This second stage package of reforms which has now come forward for implementation, together with the initial fast track package of reforms which was introduced in January 1987, provides a comprehensive new deal for the road transport industry.

ANSWER.PARA: The reforms are aimed at providing a realistic and uniform operating environment which will enhance domestic and export competitiveness of Australian goods. The agreed second stage package, which was announced in detail by my colleague Peter Morris yesterday, consists of an increase in the heavy vehicle speed limit, enhanced driving hours arrangements and revised registration charges for Federal interstate registration scheme vehicles. These arrangements will also include new categories operating at higher mass limits. The heavy vehicle speed limit is to be increased from 90 to 100 kilometres per hour from 1 July this year to improve road safety by reducing speed dispersion. The eastern States will introduce uniform hours of driving regulations in the latter half of this year. The new regulations will be enforced by revised log book arrangements and will more realistically reflect current industry conditions. Western States will be reviewing their arrangements in the light of these developments. Mr Morris recently announced-again, I think it was yesterday-the registration charges for vehicles registered under the Federal interstate registration scheme to apply from 1 July. These charges include new categories allowing Federal vehicles to operate at uniform national mass limits. The charges are a further step towards a uniform approach to land transport cost recovery arrangements.

These are very far reaching reforms. They have been the subject of debate, discussion, argument and endless controversy at State and Federal ministerial meetings over many years. It represents a major achievement and one of very great economic importance for the nation for that particular package of reforms to come together under Commonwealth Government leadership in the way that it has.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to his answer to a question on 20 April regarding capital gains tax. During his long response the Minister implied that the Chief Executive of Elders Resources Ltd was involved in a shonky scheme to avoid taxation. Is the Minister aware of the provisions of section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, and other provisions, which make it clear that income earned through shares issued under an executive incentive measure is fully assessable as part of the taxpayer's income, although maybe on a deferred basis? In future, will the Minister desist from using Question Time as a forum to accuse erroneously taxpayers of fraud of which they are quite innocent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not remember precisely what I said on 20 April, but I did on that occasion quote, as I had quoted before, Mr Terry McCrann, who, on 15 April 1986, had an article published in the Age which said that Mr Elliott had picked up a huge tax free gain through setting up a shonky share deal. If that is inaccurate in either of those respects, I am surprised that Mr Elliott has not taken it up with the Age, if not with his lawyers. To the best of my knowledge, he has not done so. I have also pointed out before that Mr McCrann would be offended if anybody described him as a friend of this Government or a friend of the Australian Labor Party. So it was not one of Mr Elliott's political enemies having a pot at him when Mr McCrann wrote that.

ANSWER.PARA: I also gave details of the mechanism that Mr Elliott used to effectively defraud the other shareholders of a company as, indeed, according to recent Press reports, the Chief Executive of Elders Resources, Mr Geoff Lord, has recently done-that is, to issue shares with a face value of 50c paid to 1c in the expectation that a takeover offer will be made to the company for shares at a price above their face value, at which time the executives who have been issued with the shares paid to 1c in the dollar fully pay up the shares and then pick up the premium that the takeover offerer is bidding, effectively, of course, thereby devaluing the other fully paid up shares held by other shareholders. It is a bit like putting a bet on a racehorse with a bookie by telephone and paying the bookie only if the horse wins. It is very similar to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what Askin did.

—I did not know that Askin used to do that. I am grateful for that piece of information. It is extremely similar to ringing up a bookie and saying, `I want to put $100 or $1,000 on this horse' and, if the horse wins, one pays the bookie $100 or $1,000; if the horse loses, one does not.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know why Senator Watson has asked this question. Perhaps he is toadying to the de facto leader of the Liberal Party in the hope that he will be able to advance a bit further--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. I ask the Minister to withdraw that offensive statement.
—The word `toadying' has been asked to be withdrawn in the past. I ask the Minister to withdraw it.
—I will withdraw `toadying'.
—Mr President, my point of order goes beyond that. The Minister has cast doubts as to the motives of the honourable senator and he should withdraw unconditionally the slur that he has placed on him.
—I have asked the Minister to withdraw.

—I withdraw the reference to Senator Watson but I do not withdraw the reference to Mr Elliott being the de facto leader of the Liberal Party. He is not a member of the Parliament and he is the de facto leader of the Liberal Party. Right now, I expect, given the shambles of the present Liberal Party and the Opposition leadership, he is beavering away to get rid of Mr Howard and get himself a safe seat in the Parliament so that he can become the real, as opposed to the de facto, leader of the Liberal Party.

ANSWER.PARA: I will refer the question about section 26 (e) to the Treasurer, who I expect will refer it to the Commissioner of Taxation. There is, of course, the caveat that the Taxation Commissioner is bound by statute not to reveal details of individual taxation assessments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Minister aware of a statement issued by Mr Julian Beale on the eve of the Port Adelaide by-election in which he alleged that the port was dying? Can the Minister say whether there is any substance to this claim and can he provide the Senate with the facts concerning the port, particularly in light of the further prospects for the port consequent on Premier Bannon's new shipping arrangements with Japan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the statement that Senator Crowley refers to. I always treat with a little suspicion Press releases which are put out immediately before by-elections. Given the hype and excitement of the time, shadow Ministers tend to float through the electorate, throw out a couple of outrageous Press releases and disappear into the sunset, never to be seen again. Usually, the veracity of those statements has to be questioned.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to inform Senator Crowley that Port Adelaide was in fact a very vigorous and prosperous port last year. It turned over 12 per cent more imports and 9 per cent more exports than in the previous year. For instance, live sheep exports rose by 8 per cent. There is every indication that the port will continue to thrive. Direct calls were made by international shipping lines from all over the world. Last year the ANRO Line introduced a fortnightly South East Asian service and special calls were made by lines servicing the Middle East and the Gulf countries. I am pleased to inform the Senate that as from July ships from Japan will double the frequency of their calls into Adelaide, thus reducing the need to land freight South Australian produced goods for dispatch to Japan from other ports.

I also acknowledge the very active role that John Bannon has played. What I have just said is not an indication that there will be an early South Australian election or that I am warming up for that event. He has played a very positive role in getting more ships into the port of Adelaide. Mr Julian Beale, as the shadow transport spokesman-and his role in this has been very shadowy-has again been caught out by a fairly cheap Press release before a by-election. It is just a pity that these things get a run without any critical analysis being made at the time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. By what authority is the Government continuing to collect the so-called administrative fee of $240 from applicants seeking a review of status through the immigration review panels? Is the Minister aware that there is at least some legal opinion that the fee itself is illegal? Approximately how much has been collected since the introduction of the fee? I refer to the then Minister's answer to my question of 15 December last year, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the Government must come to a view about the continuation of the current administrative based system . . .

In the light of the fact that the Migration Amendment Bill was amended in this place to ensure that no fee be paid by appellants to immigration review panels, has the Government `come to a view' about ending the imposition of this fee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs advises me that the fee, as its name would suggest, covers administrative costs associated with the reconsideration of certain decision made under the Migration Act. The fee charged is actually less than the full administrative costs involved. In answer to the second part of Senator Jenkins's question, it is not unusual for lawyers to have differing legal opinions on the complex issues of law. In this case, the Department has a senior Queen's Counsel's opinion that the fee is quite lawful. The only legal challenge to the fee has in fact been withdrawn by the litigant.

ANSWER.PARA: As to Senator Jenkins's third question, in relation to how much has been collected, I am advised that as of 15 April this year an amount in excess of $1m had been received. During the Senate debate on the Migration Amendment Bill 1987, a clause intended to provide legislative entitlement for the reconsideration of certain decisions and a mechanism for the collection of fees for this service was in fact deleted from the Bill. It is my understanding that in opposing the clause, the Opposition did not intend to make invalid the current administratively based appeal mechanism. In actual fact, I understand that comments to this effect were made by Mr Cadman in the House of Representatives. It is also my understanding that the Opposition supports the continued collection of the administratively based fee for the review of decisions under the Migration Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of what the Minister has just said, is it going to be the practice of this Government to act as though legislation has been passed on a promise by the Opposition? As we all know, the Opposition can change its mind. Does the Government intend to continue to act on legislation that has not yet been passed?

—As Senator Jenkins points out, if the Government based its actions on whether the Opposition was going to change its mind, it would be following a very tenuous path in respect of policy implementation. I have nothing further to add to my comments other than to say that if Senator Jenkins wishes to have any further information I would have to take her question on notice.

—Can the Minister for Resources elaborate on an article in the Australian Financial Review of 22 April which outlined his call for a forest accord between timber companies, unions, conservation groups and governments? In what way would such an accord resolve recurring conflict over logging of Australia's forests and ensure that returns from Australia's timber resources are maximised?
—Don't beat around the bush.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus has just said, by way of interjection, `Don't beat around the bush' in my answer about a forest accord. That is his humour, not mine. I propose not to beat around the bush because the response to a speech I gave to the National Association of Forest Industries (NAFI) last Thursday night has been very positive from both the forest industries side and the environmental side of the argument in terms of all those who are interested in forests. Indeed, as well as both the industry and the environmental views being put, I have had an opportunity to hold discussions with my reciprocal Minister in Western Australia, Barry Hodge. He too expressed some sort of confidence in the proposal. Yesterday morning I took part in a radio talkback program on 3LO in Melbourne when a Mr Ian Penna of the Australian Conservation Foundation and a Mr Steve Guest of the National Association of Forest Industries said that on behalf of their groups they supported the idea of a forest accord and, while they would reserve their rights on what content would go into such an accord, the idea had a great deal of appeal for them. This morning in Albury I spoke to the Forest and Forest Products Industry Council (FAFPIC), which is a combination of unions, employers and State governments that advise on forest policy under the aegis of the Australian Manufacturing Council. That body also expressed a positive response to the proposal.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposal for an accord has been advanced because it is quite clear that, in terms of forest issues, there is an endless fight between, on one side, developers and, on the other side, conservationists. That fight is epitomised by exaggerated argument on both sides, calls of defects in the arguments, wrong statistics and arguments about whether a particular coupe should be cut or not and whether a particular stand of trees should remain or not. There is a need for an overarching policy which begins to lay down the basic principles on which we as a nation will manage our forests, and that needs to be through an accord so that all the major players in forest politics are party to it.

I believe that an accord would need to look at the $1.5 billion current account deficit that timber products detract from our balance of payments. It would need to address the issue of a value added component for our forest products. At present, woodchips exported from Australia are valued at about $60 per tonne. If we were to export pulp instead of woodchips, the return would be between $300 and $800 per tonne of pulp. Better still, if we were to export paper, the return to us would be between $11,000 and $22,000 per tonne for paper products exported. So one can see why an accord ought to contain as a major feature the value added component which I have identified and which has been supported widely by both environmentalists and the industry. There is also a need to synchronise some of the research that goes into forest technology and to do so at a national-that is, through the Commonwealth Government-and State level and with industry research bodies. There is a need to concentrate on high value furniture so that we have an industry in which we add value to forest products by furniture.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know the conservationists want to--

—As a matter of fact, a Tasmanian company to which I have referred is a shining example of an innovative designer and high quality furniture manufacturer out of Tasmanian forestry products. Senator Newman may not be interested in knowing that, even though she is supposed to be a Tasmanian senator. There is a need to develop local and regional pulp and paper mills, as well as world standard mills, and to streamline issues of land access.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said, I have been heartened by the response to the speech I made to NAFI. I regret, given the Opposition's interjections, that the Opposition has not seen fit to indicate what its policy is on the issue. It seems that there is a gaping, yawning gap. There is absolute and endless silence from the Opposition. It seems that its policy, if it were to have one, would be to sell out to the highest bidder. The accord proposal should come down with a coherent and comprehensive forest policy aimed at increasing investment and employment-not just more jobs; better jobs of higher quality and with state of the art technology-which would improve our current account deficit, guarantee forest management policies, which are universally accepted, and protect the environment for future generations. I know that the objectives of that accord are probably too big and too sensible for the Opposition to grasp, but I do urge it to lend it some support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. In November 1986, I asked the then Minister representing the Minister for Health whether the Government had considered the possibility of screening visitors to Australia for the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) virus. At that time the Minister said that it would be neither practicable nor affordable to screen those people. In view of the dramatic increase in the spread of the AIDS virus, I ask the Minister the following questions. Has the Government reconsidered establishing a screening requirement for immigrants and visitors such as that which was conducted for tuberculosis? What community education programs has the Government planned, other than telling everyone that if they wear a condom they will not get AIDS-programs to alert all high risk groups and their partners? What commitment will the Government make to doctors and operating theatre staff to protect them against the disease?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the first part of the honourable senator's question concerned whether we are going to do more than encourage people to wear condoms.
—Screening.

—I think that the Government's position on that is clear. We do not propose to screen visitors to Australia. However, if there is a need to enlarge on that point, I will add to it by putting that part of the honourable senator's question on notice. My understanding is that there is no intention to screen visitors to Australia to see whether they have AIDS. The idea that has been promoted in that quarter with respect to migrants ignores totally the fact that if AIDS is being introduced into the country by visitors all tourists would have to be screened as well. I do not think that that is practical, nor do I think that the screening of people coming into this country as migrants is a practical or reasonably humane proposition. If I need to add to that answer, I will do so after I discuss the honourable senator's question with the Minister, Dr Blewett.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the honourable senator saying that the only thing we are doing is urging people to wear condoms, if she had followed what Dr Blewett has been doing and what the National Advisory Committee on AIDS promotes, she would know that a key aspect of their promotion in terms of AIDS is not exclusively that a person must wear a condom. They also promote abstinence and faithfulness to a sexual partner as well as condom wearing as the three most effective ways in which to deal with the spread of AIDS.

As I understood it, the last part of the question echoed some views expressed by Dr Bruce Shepherd in a television interview yesterday when he asserted that all surgical patients should be tested for human immuno-deficiency virus (HIV) so that surgeons could take protective measures where necessary. If I am right in identifying that part of the honourable senator's question, I can say that the Government's underlying position is that testing for HIV infection should be voluntary, undertaken only with the consent of the patient and always accompanied by pre-test and post-test counselling. It must also be pointed out that the New South Wales doctors' recommendation is at odds with the recommendations of the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons, which has recommended against routine pre-operative screening for HIV. It has also recommended that consent for testing should be obtained. Mass screening would be expensive and time-consuming, particularly where the results necessitate confirmatory testing. Existing sources could not cope with the demands that would be imposed by widespread testing of all surgical patients. Obviously, testing would not be practicable in emergency cases. The best solution is to treat all patients so as to minimise the risk of HIV infection. Whether they are tested or not, the adoption of proper infection control procedures makes the risk of infection minute for most procedures. Doctors have a duty of care to treat all patients, including those infected with HIV. Of course, the Government accepts that, in procedures which carry a significant threat of injury to the surgeon, knowledge of the patient's HIV status may be relevant. The decision whether to test the patient in these circumstances needs to be made in the light of all the relevant information and should be undertaken only in conjunction with the informed consent and counselling of the patient.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. His title is in fact longer than my question. Will the Minister please outline the progress and the objectives of the Aussie Sports program of the Australian Sports Commission? What response has there been from the educational and sporting communities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Aulich for his question. I will do my best to answer the question. The Aussie Sports program has been a resounding success. At this point in time there are more than 1,700 schools participating in the program.
—How many?

—There are 1,700 registered schools and more than half a million Australian children taking part. In addition to that, last month over 200 sporting clubs subscribed to the join a club project, which has received support from Telecom Australia, a body sometimes maligned in this place but one which is taking its rightful place in Australian sport. On 30 March I had the pleasure of launching the educational material for the Aussie Sports program entitled `Sport in Australian Society'. The material has three main themes. The first one is Aboriginal sport, the second is colonial sport and the third is twentieth century sport. The program offers children the opportunity to examine--
—Twentieth century sport!

—Obviously, some honourable senators do not take much of an interest in sport. Sport, of course, has played a very important part in the development of the Australian identity in the last 200 years. That Senator Puplick would not be aware of that fact should be a surprise to no-one.
—They are champion log-rollers over there.

—Senator Puplick is a champion log-cutter, rather than a log-roller. The material to which I have just referred has been fully endorsed by the National Aboriginal Education Committee and the Aboriginal Education Advisory Committee. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs has already purchased 5,000 copies of the Aboriginal sports material to which I just referred, for distribution around Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: At this point in time all State and Territory education departments have a full time Aussie Sports coordinator. The Aussie Sports coaching program has begun. Most importantly, given the concern expressed by so many parents around the country in the last few years, the Aussie Sports code of behaviour has now been adopted by most of our sporting bodies and, certainly, by five States. Hopefully, we will have all States and Territories signed up very soon so that we can emphasise better sporting behaviour. Overall, what we now have is better instruction in Australian sport. Most importantly, we have a program designed to enable children to enjoy it, to get a sense of participation and to get fulfilment from that, rather than just a sense of winning and intense competition. If Aussie Sports can do that for Australian children, it will be doing a great service for our country. I only wish that such a program had been around in the days when Senator Ray and I needed it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of all honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of a delegation from the European Parliament. On behalf of all senators I extend to the delegation a warm welcome and trust that their stay in Australia is a success.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Minister aware that the Ships (Capital Grants) Act which the Government introduced last year is very unlikely to improve the international competitiveness of Australian shipping? Is it not a fact that the first vessel with the new crewing levels has not yet come into service and that, with the present rate of replacement, the benefits of reduced crewing levels will not be felt until well into the 1990s? In any case, are not these crew levels still about 25 per cent higher than those of the major maritime nations? To compound this problem are there extraordinary rorts being worked over leave entitlements? Is the Minister doing anything to reduce these entitlements that comprise, for coastal shipping, six weeks on and six weeks off, with first-class air travel and accommodation for the changeover? Would it not cost more than $1m to raise a Swedish ship to Australian accommodation standards? Are not these conditions far more generous than those of any nation of comparable or greater wealth than Australia; indeed, are they not easily the most generous in the world? Bearing in mind that other maritime nations are further lowering the number of their crews, is it not urgent for the Government to take decisive action to bring conditions for our seamen into line with those of countries of comparable economic standing and to stop the rip-offs by the maritime unions, using their monopoly power, which are inflicting very serious economic damage on the whole Australian community?

—Senator Hamer asked me what I was doing about various matters in the shipping area. The short answer is that I am not doing very much at all because I have delegated responsibility to my learned and gallant colleague Senator Ray, to whom I now have a great deal of pleasure in flicking the question.

—We have a saying in Victorian football-the `ambulance hand pass'. It has just come to me. Senator Hamer asked up to nine or 10 questions. I think he abuses Question Time as such by asking so many detailed questions rather than going to the general issues, which is all I will go to here today. He referred to the Ships (Capital Grants) Act. The first major ship to come on stream is already on its way to Portland. I will be visiting there, I think on 5 May, to inspect the ship and to look at the new crewing arrangements. Senator Hamer would realise that under the Maritime Industry Development Committee (MIDC) proposals the manning of that ship has come down to 21 people on board.
—That is still higher than anywhere else.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator ROBERT RAY

TALK.START.PARA: —When Senator Hamer's Party left office five years ago there was an average of 38 people on board. When he starts preaching to us what we should be doing in the shipping area, he should realise that his Government did nothing. It did absolutely nothing in this regard. Honourable senators opposite talk about structural reform. They play a really good game in opposition. However, if their promises and desires for the future are ever to be measured one must look at past performance. In all these areas it has been pathetic. All they have ever sought to do is to create conditions of confrontation just for the thrill of it. They have never been into a rational structural reform of any Australian industries.

INTERJECT.PARA: This industry is one that requires structural reform. I make at least one acknowledgment to the Liberal Party; this reform began with the Crawford Committee on Revitalisation of Australian Shipping, which we had to put into action. It has continued through the MIDC process. That cannot be the end of the story. Australian shipping conditions must adjust to a stage where we are competitive with the rest of the world. As it is, the various Australian international ships are in a free and open market. They have to compete against the rest of the world. That is the environment they live in. That is the environment they will either live or die in. They must adapt to those conditions.

I will not go into some of the other issues that are floating around today, although I was surprised that I was not asked a question on the report of the Industries Assistance Commission. Senator Hamer asked about leave entitlements. These are determined by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. They have been negotiated by employers and employees and ratified by the Commission. Senator Hamer asked about the amount of money it takes to convert a ship. I think that Senator Hamer used Sweden as an example, which I acknowledge is a fair example. Swedish working conditions are among those most similar to Australia's working conditions. It does sometimes cost more to convert some of these ships. Some of the conversion relates to safety issues. I read from time to time of people saying that safety conditions on Australian ships are too stringent. It was only the other day that another ship broke up in the Atlantic and sank with a loss of 20 or 30 lives. While I have any responsibility in this area, I am not going to preside over a decline in safety standards. We have some of the best safety standards not only in shipping but also in the airline industry and other areas. I do not see why we should try to match the safety standards of the rest of the world. If we have the best, so be it; we should be proud of it. Senator Hamer today raised a lot of other issues and I suspect we will be debating them at another time-and fairly shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I refer to the joint Press release issued this morning by the Minister and his colleague the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, on new workers compensation arrangements for Commonwealth employees. What effect will Comcare have on the incomes of Commonwealth employees currently in receipt of workers compensation benefits? What are the reasons for changes in the level of benefits which current workers compensation beneficiaries will receive?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the second part of the question about what effect the new arrangements will have on Commonwealth employees currently in receipt of workers compensation depends on the level of compensation as a proportion of updated former salary that they are currently receiving. If they are receiving presently less than 70 per cent of updated former salary and no other government funded benefit, their payment will be increased to 70 per cent of former salary. However, if they are receiving from both compensation payments and Commonwealth superannuation scheme payments more than 100 per cent of their updated former salary-that is, 100 per cent minus the 5 per cent personal contribution to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme that such people would have had to pay were they still maintaining an employer-employee relationship-they will have their payments cut to 95 per cent of their updated former salary. The 95 per cent figure equates to a 100 per cent figure on a gross basis. The compensation component of the payment they are receiving will then be frozen in dollar terms until, as is conceivable, it falls to 70 per cent of updated former salary. New entrants to the scheme likewise will have a government financed limit of 70 per cent of updated former salary net of the 5 per cent superannuation contribution if they are long term claimants.

ANSWER.PARA: The scheme had to be changed because under the present arrangements it is possible-and I table one example demonstrating the arithmetic behind this-for people at reasonably low salary levels, if they are over 65 years of age, to receive 132 per cent, in the specific example given in that table, of the salary they would have been receiving were they still employed in their previous job, plus, and by definition people in this category have some entitlement, whatever employee financed benefit either in the form of an ongoing pension or a lump sum they receive or have received from the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust. In all the figures that I have quoted, entitlements accruing as a result of employees' own contributions have been excluded. So it is possible for somebody over 65 years of age who was on compensation before reaching the age of 65 and who also had a full Commonwealth superannuation scheme entitlement to have, in the case cited, 132 per cent of former salary.

If we look at people presently under 65 years of age and not on compensation, it demonstrates rather forcefully the reason the Government has taken this action. Imagine a Commonwealth public servant of 62 or 63 years of age. If he can get on compensation, and remain on compensation until he reaches retiring age, on reaching retiring age he could qualify, as I said before, for well in excess of 100 per cent of his salary in employment. If he did not get on compensation prior to reaching retiring age, he would get a government financed benefit of 50 per cent or, under certain particularly unusual circumstances, 52 1/2 per cent of his former salary. In other words, there is an enormous incentive, especially for people approaching retirement age, to make an effort to get on compensation before they hit the statutory retiring age of 65.

Given also the fact that there are doctors around who will sign anything that is put in front of them, and that it is difficult in any subsequent litigation or appeal proceedings to have an appeal body overrule any doctor's decision, some people might wonder why any relatively lowly paid Commonwealth public servants have retired at age 65 as employees instead of getting on compensation and qualifying for a double dip before having done it. The fact that that has not happened can be attributed only to there being more residual honesty around than some sceptics might have believed, or perhaps they just did not know about the lurk. But it is a lurk that could not be allowed to continue and a lurk which, if I may say so, the previous Government in its seven years of office made absolutely no attempt to close off.

There are many other details to the scheme. That detailed information has already been published, and I do not intend to give all of it here. But I anticipate two criticisms of the scheme which are likely to emerge. The first will be that the scheme does not adequately look after low income earners. There are two responses to that. The first is that there is a floor, a minimum payment, regardless of what the former salary may have been, which picks up people on relatively low salaries who have a number of dependants. The second point is that if people really want to push that argument they have to reject the whole basis of the new earnings related scheme and go back to some statutory rate of payment. But they cannot have it both ways.

The second criticism that is likely to be made is that it is morally wrong to reduce to the equivalent of 100 per cent of former salary payments presently being made to people who are on both Commonwealth superannuation scheme pensions and compensation payments. Some people will no doubt say that it is retrospective legislation, and all this sort of tear jerking nonsense. The answer to that is that it is a gross anomaly that such people ever received more than 100 per cent of their former salary. That being so, it would be an equally gross anomaly to allow them to continue receiving more than 100 per cent of their former salary. Indeed, it could be argued that that would be an even more gross anomaly, because they have already received payments to which, by any reasonable assessment, they had no reasonable entitlement. It would be even more anomalous to allow those people who have already received such excessive payments to go on receiving them in the future. I trust that the Opposition, even when adopting its normal opportunistic stance on policy questions, will realise that there will be much more to be lost by opposing this legislation-just in case it should contemplate doing so-because out there in the big wide world, when people find out that the present arrangements allow some people, and are presently paying some people, in retirement more than 100 per cent of the salary they received when they were working--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have let it go on for five years.

—I hope Senator Alston is listening to this. Out there in voter land people will be very angry. If the Opposition lot, in its typical opportunistic way, tries to stop this legislation getting through, there will be a big backlash against it. So I hope for once that the Opposition's opportunism, which is always there, will be intelligent opportunism.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and relates to the Minister's response to a question regarding the 20 per cent tax on film production which the Minister acknowledged yesterday is to occur from 1 June this year. Is it true that as reported in today's Hobart Mercury, this 20 per cent tax is also to apply to the video production costs associated with weddings, sporting events and company training films? Does the Minister consider it appropriate that this new tax should impose an additional financial imposition on newlyweds, sports fans and those companies which seek to improve the quality of their work force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no basis in suggestions that either of the sales tax rulings about which Senator Calvert has asked his question, that is, on video production or sound recording, will impose a tax on Australian films. I just want to get that on the record. Feature films are excluded specifically. What we are going to debate is whether it has an effect on the industry in so far as advertising or something else is concerned. That is a matter about which I will have some discussions with the Treasurer. However, on the question of newlyweds and sports fans, I would hate to do anything to upset them. I cannot claim to be a newlywed: I have been married for 15 years, but I think I am still a sports fan and I would not want to be upset. Having said that, I hope that in looking at this question it is realised that I do not believe it appropriate that I give answers on tax. That is better left for the Treasurer. That being the case, I intend to refer some of this question to him.
—Particularly since he has suddenly become a sports fan.

—I am not quite suggesting that, yet. I will believe Keating's conversion when I see the honourable senator's. I will refer those matters to the Treasurer and get back to Senator Calvert as soon as I can.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. What scope is there in Australia for a fourth television channel or for new players to enter the television industry in some other way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been spectacularly evident for all the world to see in the last few days, the Liberal-National Party leadership has impaled itself on a large two-horned dilemma. I only wish that James Thurber were here to record the scene. On the one hand it says it wants to expand the number of players in the television industry in pursuit of what it describes as diversity. I am not sure whether Mr Nixon's or Mr Blunt's motives are quite as high-minded as that. It is indicating a willingness along those lines to regulate like crazy to set a 60 per cent or less audience reach limit in order to achieve that result. On the other hand, it seems to want, and Mr Howard seems to need these days to demonstrate, an attachment to freedom from unnecessary business regulation, to try to recover some of the respect from the business community which it and he manifestly have lost. It knows that the kind of regulation that is involved in setting a 60 per cent limit has no rationality and no intellectually or economically credible base. If there is any doubt about that honourable senators need only refer to what the former Minister for Communications, Neil Brown, said on commercial radio at lunchtime today.

ANSWER.PARA: The only way out of that dilemma seems to be for the Opposition-and Mr Howard has been struggling with the hapless Senator Messner in his tow to articulate this in the last couple of days, not so far with much success, but we may see about that later today-to say, `Do not set limits on how much ownership you can build into any one network or any one commercial channel system, but create new avenues for new players to drive down'. In particular, the argument seems to be, `Let us open up the airwaves to one or more new commercial channels in each of the major capital cities and perhaps in the community as a whole'. Let us explore the credibility of that option. The short answer is that a fourth commercial channel, in the foreseeable future in Australia, is a palpably nonsensical option. I say that for a number of reasons. First of all, overseas comparisons make it very clear that in terms of the broadcast channels-and I will come back to cable and pay television in a few moments-Australia is very well--

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you think you have some explaining to do to the public.

—Senator Chaney will have some explaining to do after this. In terms of any rational overseas comparison Australia is very well served with its two national-in the traditional sense of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS)-channels and three commercial channels. The National Party is doing its best to deny those three commercial channels to large swags of the rural community but so far as the metropolitan areas are concerned, we have five channels to choose from around the country. In that respect we are spectacularly well served by any international comparison with countries of roughly comparable size. Canada has only two national networks-a government and a commercial one, together with some independents in the larger population centres. Holland, with 13 million people, has just two channels with some access to new satellite services coming on-but at the moment there are only two. Scandinavian countries, each with populations similar to or less than Australia, have just one or two government stations-and that is all-with some prospect of one or two commercial stations in the future, but not yet.

ANSWER.PARA: In countries with populations much larger than Australia's, the range of broadcasting networks, if we look around the world, by and large is less than or certainly no greater than is the case in Australia at the moment. West Germany, for example, with 60 million people, has three services. Italy, with 50 or 60 million people, has just one national service plus a limited range of independent stations. There are just a handful of stations in France, with a population of 50 million. In the United Kingdom, with 60 million people, there are just four services-two British Broadcasting Corporation ones and two commercials. In the United States, there are only three national commercial networks with, of course, a whole miscellany of cable services to supplement that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort of ownership?

—There is a 25 per cent maximum audience reach which, in the United States population context of over 60 million people, involves an ownership base, for each of those networks, of the top 10 or 12 major cities in the United States. If Senator Chaney applied a 25 per cent limit in Australia, as even his arithmetic should lead him to understand, he would be caught with a population base of less than four million people and only one or one and a bit of major cities in the country being within that limit. That is why it is absolutely nonsensical, against the framework of economies of scale and capacity to cross-subsidise, to use raw percentage figures which are extracted in that way from incomparable jurisdictions. The other point which makes the four-channel idea nonsensical in Australia very simply is the revenue base upon which such a fourth channel would have to be built.
—What has that got to do with it?

—It has everything to do with the viability of a fourth commercial channel as even the honourable senator ought to appreciate, although I know that is a tall order. The particular revenue base being confronted in Australia was acknowledged back in 1976 by the Australian Broadcasting Control Board to be insufficient to justify three commercial channels. It argued for two. But it happened and by 1985-86 we had a total revenue base of about $1.2 billion. That is the latest period for which figures are available. For the major cities, Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Adelaide, that represented a total revenue base of just $846m-per network, it was $280m each. If that total amount had to be shared by a fourth player, each would be receiving about $212m; and that is a reduction of something like $70m per network.

ANSWER.PARA: There may be room for some additional advertising around the margin in the context of ABC or SBS programming. That is being explored and examined at the moment. But it would only be marginal. It is beyond belief that the revenue base is there in the Australian population at the moment-or in the foreseeable future-to sustain a fourth channel. Let me reinforce that with some figures I have just been handed which make the point that the financial results for the existing commercial television stations are very discouraging.
