Twenty per cent of them made an operating loss in the year for which the last figures are available, 1985-86, and the trend has all been downward. Back in 1981-82, there were 45 stations making an operating profit and five making an operating loss. The trend line is such that by 1985-86, only 39 were making a profit and 11 were making a loss. The main reason for that declining profit is the increasing competition from all forms of media, the higher cost of Australian programs, the higher cost of imported programs-with devaluation-and, in particular, a very soft advertising market.

The reality is that expenditure over the years has been growing much more rapidly than revenue for the stations. That is why the whole point about networking, viability and economies of scale has assumed so much importance. The reality is that a fourth network would distribute an already soft advertising revenue among more players. It would particularly affect Australian production, which is the highest cost item for commercial television stations. Any approach to these issues which fails to come to grips with these matters would indicate a failure to understand the real world.

I make the point that this Government has no ideological objection to greater diversity in the broadcasting areas; on the contrary, we have been fostering that. We have been fostering it very assiduously in radio, and let me give some examples of that. After we came into office, by the end of last year there was a total of 139 radio stations, as compared with 108 a generation ago, in 1957. That is an increase of 23 per cent over those 30 years. By 1990, 175 commercial licences will be on issue. That is a 20 per cent increase in just four years. We have made it clear that we are prepared to license audio entertainment services of the Sky Channel variety-not really comparable to pay television but one example of an increasingly diverse electronic media environment. As I have just announced, we have been prepared to license, with multipoint distribution systems, a few days ago, much greater access by a greatly increased number of players to a whole variety of other forms of video communication.

The Government has announced already, again just a few days ago, a willingness to open up and explore the prospects for pay television in this country and to examine in a systematic and expeditious way the huge variety of policy issues that are necessarily involved in making any decision to go down that track. If we do go down that track-and at the moment I cannot see any reason in principle why we should not do so-we will necessarily open up a much more diverse electronic media and video entertainment environment for the future.

Let me finish by saying that there may well be scope for more players, for new players, in the context of the new emerging media forms of this kind, and we are very keen and very willing to explore that in a rational and systematic way. What we are not prepared to do is to react in the blind, aimless, random and fumbling way that has been characteristic of the Opposition's attempt to square the circle on its media policy over the past few years, and indeed over the past few weeks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications in response to a Question without Notice, asked by Senator Collins this day, relating to television licensing.

I do not wish to speak at length to the issue but I just want to make a single point. As to the 10-minute tirade, which could have been best handled by a ministerial statement and which was, of course, an abuse of Question Time, the simple point must be made that in the country across the Tasman, New Zealand, it was announced today that the television and radio industries will be deregulated to allow access for new people. Why is it, then, that this cannot occur in this country? Why is it that the Government cannot confer the same conditions? I leave that question to the Minister to answer. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that at 8.30 a.m. today, two senators submitted letters in accordance with standing order 64-Senator McLean, proposing a matter of urgency, and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney, proposing a matter of public importance. To decide which letter should be submitted to the Senate I determined the matter by ballot in the presence of Senator McLean, the Deputy Opposition Whip-Senator Knowles-and the Clerk of the Senate. In accordance with the result of that procedure, I now read Senator McLean's letter:

INTERJECT.PARA: In accordance with Standing Order 64, I intend to move today-That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Minister for Defence to be removed from his portfolio given that over the last three years he has presided over the decline in morale of the defence force indicated by low recruitment, high wastage of personnel, and an apparent inability to control senior departmental officers, thereby losing the confidence of members of the defence force, the Parliament and the public, and as a result of all these factors precipitating an unprecedented crisis in Australia's defence capacity.
Paul McLean, Senator for New South Wales
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Minister for Defence to be removed from his portfolio given that over the last three years he has presided over the decline in morale of the defence force indicated by low recruitment, high wastage of personnel, and an apparent inability to control senior departmental officers, thereby losing the confidence of members of the defence force, the Parliament and the public, and as a result of all these factors precipitating an unprecedented crisis in Australia's defence capacity.

I have proposed this urgency motion today because I feel very strongly, as indeed do all Australian Democrat senators-and, I believe, the Opposition-that the defence of Australia is now not being well served by the appalling attitude of the Government towards our defence and ex-service communities. This state of affairs must have come about because either the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, is not able to efficiently preside over the Department of Defence, or because his recommendations are not being taken up by Cabinet-and if the latter is the case, it is evident that the Minister is just not fighting hard enough for his Department in Cabinet deliberations.

Of course, this crisis is not entirely of the Minister's making; nor is it all the Government's fault. Although the crisis of confidence in Australia's defence forces has climaxed only recently, it has existed for several decades and is the product of several governments. Nevertheless, it is very real. The Government appears to have good intentions towards defence. In last year's defence budget the following statement was made:

This Government believes that our service men and women should know that they are members of an organisation that has clear cut direction, that they are at the heart of the most fundamental of national responsibilities, the security of the nation, and that the Government takes its responsibilities to defence seriously.

Of course, that is a fine sentiment; the Australian Democrats applaud it, but it does not align with the facts. A fact that is obvious to anyone with any interest in defence and veterans' affairs is that these two areas within our community are in crisis. The Government's answer to the defence crisis is to issue us with a series of ministerial statements. We have been treated to two recently, and there was a third one today. They amount merely to an exercise in the Government patting itself on the back.

Our defence forces are overwhelmingly and tragically demoralised. In the appropriation debate last year, I quoted a letter from Major-General John Whitelaw of the Regular Defence Force Welfare Association in which he listed the major concerns of service men and women and their families-and there were many of them. Many of those concerns have still not been addressed by the Government, including the matter of the continuing saga of 2 per cent discounting of Defence Force retirement benefits, an inordinate delay in establishing the Defence Housing Authority, the appallingly low repair and maintenance budget, resulting in the continuing deplorable standards of service housing, the unacceptable restrictions on the education allowance payable for children of defence personnel, and a prolonged delay before implementation of most of the recommendations of the Hamilton Review of the Effect of Service Life on Spouses. It was cheering to see today the ministerial statement which supports some progress in relation to the recommendations of the Hamilton report. I shall address some remarks to that ministerial statement later in the afternoon.

To these urgent problems can be added those that were cited by a serviceman who wrote to Senator Tambling earlier this year and whom Senator Tambling quoted in debate in this place on 22 March. That serviceman cited a number of problems, and I shall quote from the letter that he sent to Senator Tambling:
High incidence of managerial imposed turbulence affecting families.
Imposition of a strict code of discipline-
one would not find that surprising in the Services-
Exposure, during some postings, to varying degrees of arduous working and living conditions-
nor would one find that surprising-
Inability to effectively demonstrate dissatisfaction, other than by leaving the ADF-

Of course, that is what is happening in large numbers. The only way that servicemen can express their dissatisfaction is to leave. The letter also refers to the necessity to acquire service oriented qualifications, some of which attract a compulsory return of service period but which are not broadly transportable outside the Services. Finally, it refers to constant training and practising of skills which rarely, thankfully, are exercised in any real situation. That is not all, of course. After leaving the Defence Force, ex-service men and women can look forward to their entitlements as veterans being downgraded further and further as they get older, and therefore they are less able to overcome this sort of discrimination. Sadly, the neglect of the defence forces is paralleled by an erosion of veterans' entitlements, on which I shall elaborate later.

Unfortunately, the Government and Opposition appear to be in collusion on the subject of veterans' affairs. Their objective obviously is to eliminate that grouping of Australians known as veterans and to assimilate them into the social security system with no special identity. I have no other alternative but to arrive at that conclusion from the position taken by members of the Opposition in relation to a number of amendments that I moved in December 1987. Perhaps they have changed their minds-hopefully, they have.

All is obviously not well in our defence forces. The recent report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the management of the Australian defence forces, tabled in this place about two months ago, cited a number of major problems and deficiencies associated with defence establishments and with the policy process. That Committee made many reasonable recommendations, which I hope the Government is now studying in order to decide how fast it can implement the recommendations. Such notable defence experts as Air Marshal Evans, Commodore Alan Robertson, Air Commodore Tex Watson, Admiral Guy Griffiths and Major-General John Whitelaw have all recently reported in many varying publications and at meetings around the country that the defence forces, and consequently the defence of this country, are grossly diminished and inadequate.

The recent resignation rates, about which we have heard so much in this place, are a reason for great concern. We all know the figures over the last three years: 25,250 people have left the Defence Force, which amounts to about 12 per cent of the total Defence Force leaving each year-36 per cent in three years. In excess of 50 per cent of the Defence Force has been turned over in the last five years. In 1981-82, 8,200 people left the Defence Force. This figure dropped to a low of 6,700 in 1983-84, but last year rose again dramatically to 9,000. In the eight years 1975-76 to 1982-83 the average of male officer resignations was 502 a year. In the four years 1983-84 to 1986-87 the average was 610 and in the last two years for which we have figures, 1986-87, the average has been 675 commissioned officers a year-an extraordinary wastage rate. Obviously there is a problem in this category which must be addressed immediately. Officers cost the country a great deal to train, and with their experience and expertise they are not easily replaced.

Pilot resignations are one of the Government's main areas of concern, and rightly so. Here the figures are even more dramatic. These are also figures that we all know. For more than 20 years the average resignation rate of pilots was 47 a year. In 1984-85 that figure rose to 60, in 1985-86 to 70, and in 1986-87 to 107 pilots a year. That rather alarming figure is expected to be exceeded this year. Those pilots cost the country about $5m each to train to the stage where they resign and take their skills elsewhere. This looming critical shortage of experienced pilots means that there are not enough flying instructors to train the number of new pilots we now need to catch up, approximately 60 pilots each year; so this trend must be reversed, and soon. This is one area in which the Government has been shaken out of its complacency, and it is moving in a very positive direction. Qantas Airways Ltd has been asked to change its recruiting policies. The Government has announced that it intends to increase the service obligation from six to eight years. It does not improve the morale of those who remain in during those six to eight years. The compulsory retirement age of pilots of wing commander rank will probably be increased to 55 years. It does not improve their morale in the additional five years of service. We are assured that other measures are being taken.

While retirement rates are a problem, enlistment rates are still also worrying, although there has been some improvement in some categories. In 1981-82, when, it will be remembered, 8,200 people left the Defence Force, 8,500 joined. In 1985-86, 8,700 left and only 6,900 joined. I am advised that this situation has improved, but there are serious difficulties in the recruitment of junior officers, one of the most critical ranks of recruitment. We must ask ourselves why this is the case. Why are we losing Defence Force personnel in droves and not attracting nearly as many new personnel? Obviously Service conditions are a major factor; in many cases housing is deplorable. About half the Defence Force homes now in use fail to meet the requirements of service scales and standards of accommodation and about half are to be demolished as soon as possible. These are the houses in which Defence Force families live. In the last defence budget the allowance for defence housing repairs and maintenance was actually reduced.

The Opposition is not innocent in this respect. Most of these service homes were built under a Liberal-National Party government and have been allowed to run down to their present condition by the same administration. If a service home needs urgent maintenance, the problem must be reported by the Defence Force member, not by the spouse, who probably spends most of the time in the house. If the Defence Force member is away on exercises, the spouse is allowed to report the problem to the member's unit. In one case at Holsworthy about which I have been told, it took the New South Wales Housing Commission about six months to fix a leak in a pipe behind a bathroom wall. Defence Force personnel change locations on average every three to five years. This makes it very difficult for children, who have to change schools so often, and for spouses, who find it difficult to find steady jobs as prospective employers know they may be forced to leave in a couple of years. My own children went to 14 schools in 10 years while I was in the Regular Army. New schools mean new uniforms, new books and social dislocation, which the children find particularly difficult and disturbing. Every resignation in the Services today-there are each year literally thousands of them-necessitates a chain of movement, and every movement costs the family lots of money, easily $1,000 each time, and sometimes more per movement. Defence housing tends to be cold in winter and hot in summer, with little or no insulation and unfinished timber flooring. Condensation is also a major problem in most of the houses where there is inadequate ventilation.

Despite the very best efforts of defence families, much housing remains in a decrepit and demoralising state. When the Government introduced the Defence Housing Authority Bill last year, it told us that under a single authority there should be increased efficiency and higher standards of housing. We sincerely hope that this will be the case, but the Government is moving so slowly in implementing this Act that there is still very little evidence of improvement. The Hamilton report entitled Supporting Service Families is an excellent document which enunciates clearly the social, domestic and psychological climate in which the families of Australian service personnel live. Although it was released two years ago, there has been considerable delay in implementing some of its most important recommendations.

Is it any wonder, therefore, that morale in our Defence Force is so low? Morale is a complex phenomenon. As a former serving officer, I think that I can draw a fairly accurate picture of the social, domestic, working and psychological environment which has engendered this extraordinarily low level of morale. In the work environment in regard to the relevant aspects of pay and conditions, leadership, career structures, opportunities inside the service, a sense of relevance of serving and the organisation in which one is serving holding a sense of relevance to the community at large, appropriateness of training and a comparison with opportunities outside the Services-on all these dimensions service opportunities unfortunately do not rate highly. All this is a very depressing and the Government has every right to ask why we do not offer some constructive suggestions. The Australian Democrats believe that defence thinking in Australia today is basically flawed. It is based on conventional thinking; it is equipment biased, outdated and obsessed with the threat of invasion. This thinking is downright dangerous because it is so far removed from the realities of what we require in forward defence planning.

Clearly in a nuclear age in an essentially peace seeking country there is sense and great benefit in shifting emphasis in our defence, thinking, organisation and material from the offensive to the defensive and from the predominantly military to the predominantly civil defence model. This shift in emphasis is desperately needed. In this country we still fund our civil defence, our coastal patrols, our volunteer rescue groups, our bushfire brigades and other critical organisations by selling lamingtons on street corners; yet we resentfully spend billions of dollars annually on the inadequate maintenance of a clearly depleted and demoralised Defence Force. This is fair neither to ourselves nor to those who have chosen to enlist in these inadequate and grossly neglected services. I hasten to add that, having been there myself, I have great admiration for them and sympathy for their circumstances, but the reality is that we can and must do much better.

In the 20 years since the end of the Vietnam war the Australian community has gradually become enfolded in a warm blanket of security. Because we have not been forced to think of what it would be like if our forces were again committed to war we have not thought about it, and because we have not thought about it we have allowed our defence forces to run down and our veteran community to be treated as second and third class citizens by a society which should still be treating them as special and giving them a little more than first class treatment because they were prepared to make such enormous sacrifices for the rest of us and our children.

The Australian Democrats have not moved this matter of urgency today merely to criticise the Minister for Defence nor indeed the Government in general. We are not attacking Mr Beazley because senior members of his Department have lied to him or given him misleading information, and we are not accusing him of having deliberately misled Parliament. Of course, this is a very serious matter and calls for the sacking of the senior departmental officers involved, but certainly not Mr Beazley's resignation. That precedent is only for senior departmental officers who want to rid themselves of a troublesome Minister and remain immune from retribution. However, we could never again be sure of the accuracy of ministerial statements or answers. The question is much broader than that. We are concerned that Mr Beazley has been Minister for Defence for three years and in that time his Department has deteriorated steadily to a point where it is now facing a crisis unprecedented in Australia's history, with low recruitment, high wastage and very low morale. Mr Beazley no longer has the confidence of his Department, the confidence of service personnel or the confidence of the public in respect of the portfolio which he now holds. The Department of Defence needs a new mind, someone who will be innovative, bring a whole new perspective to the portfolio and begin a new era in Australia's defence, and perhaps it will be Senator Robert Ray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was one of the weakest efforts I have heard in this place. Senator McLean put a motion on the books and then tried to square off in his speech. It is pathetic! Let us look at the first two lines of the motion, because this is not a frivolous matter. Senator McLean has basically asked for the resignation of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). It is not a question of his being replaced in his portfolio. If he leaves that portfolio his political career is finished; that is it. That is what Senator McLean has asked for, yet nothing in his speech justifies that action. Senator McLean then tried to square off at the end of his speech by saying that he did not really mean to be critical of the Minister but that it is really just the Department of Defence and that it needs a new mind. As far as I am concerned, that is a weak effort. The only good part in respect of this motion, if it is carried, is that everyone will say, `Ho hum, the Senate has carried another motion', and we will add it to the list of hundreds of other irrelevant motions that the Senate has carried by way of matters of urgency, meaningless second reading amendments, and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this matter of urgency seriously and I rise to defend the Minister for Defence. To get the proper background I thought that because I am not a defence expert I should obtain the Australian Democrats' policy on defence, so I sent one of my trusty assistants down to the Library where there is a big file entitled `Democrats' Defence Statements'. It was empty-nothing has been put in it over the past few years. I wondered about that and decided that there were only two possibilities. First, the file had been pinched by some other person working here, and there can be only a few suspects among those speaking to this debate; or secondly, the Democrats have made no realistic comments about defence. So I went back a bit further and I looked at the Democrats' 1987 election manifesto and I looked for an extensive defence statement by the Democrats. The only thing I could find was a document headed `Nuclear Disarmament'. It makes some good points about nuclear disarmament, points that I am not here to rubbish, but the Democrats' defence policy is included in just a few points on one page. That is the Democrats' defence policy!

TALK.START.PARA: —You should have put someone much more thorough on the job and you would have found a copy of our defence policy; then you would be in a position to comment.

—We are waiting for a copy of the Democrats' defence policy. During the last election campaign did the Democrats feature defence as a major issue? The only coverage in the 1987 election was a six-line summary in the Age giving the Democrats' defence policy. That is the sort of impact that their defence policy has had in this country. As an ex-serving officer and someone who has a real interest in this area Senator McLean must suffer from schizophrenia. His colleagues are not interested. His stance alienates the Democrats' disarmament base. The groups that the Democrats pander to in terms of nuclear disarmament and the other myths that they put around are the groups that the Democrats appeal to, but they do not believe in conventional armament either; they would be in favour of unilateral disarmament right across the board. However, having some sense of responsibility Senator McLean cannot endorse that. The Democrats must downgrade their defence policy during an election campaign in order to pander the peacenik movement. That is the reality. The Democrats can never support defence strongly because, the moment they do, they blow the whole peacenik community, one of the groups they depend on to build their 8 or 10 per cent support.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McLean assures me that somewhere-not in the Library but somewhere else-there is a copy of the Democrats' defence policy. I look forward to seeing it and to rigorously analysing it, but it is one of the best kept secrets in Australian politics. During debate on a matter of urgency six months ago Senator McLean said:
. . . the Australian Democrats will be attempting in the next few months to put forward models which we believe address the long term problem of reversing morale in the defence forces.

Senator McLean said that six months ago but he did not include it in his speech today. Where is it? He promised it six months ago. We have not seen it yet. So the tablets to be handed down from on high by Senator McLean in an attempt to solve these problems are still missing. I refer to what I said at that time because I think it totally justifies what I am saying today. I described Senator McLean as a `harping critic' and I said:
I ask Senator McLean: How much of the gross domestic product should we spend on defence? What other Government programs should we take money away from to reallocate to defence?
There has been no response from the Democrats. I then said:

If I had $2 billion, $3 billion, $4 billion or $5 billion given to me tomorrow and was told that I could spend it on extras for the Defence Force, I would be absolutely delighted . . . Of course, Senator McLean is sitting there in the luxury of never having been in government, the luxury of being a carping critic and the luxury of appealing to every minority group in the community, without ever having realistically to outline the way in which he would raise the revenue, how he would carve it up and how he would deal with thousands of different priorities. That is an easy life. We do not have those sorts of easy lives.
What I said six months ago has the same relevance today.

There are, of course, other ways in which the Senate can address these matters-more sober and realistic ways. Since the early 1970s the Senate, quite rightly, has been proud of its committee system and, therefore, defence appropriations provide an opportunity for any senator who is concerned with the issues of personnel and materiel to get expert, on-the-spot advice. I just wondered when I read this urgency motion today whether it derived from the end product of Senator McLean's thought and reasoned investigation through the Estimates Committee. Then I said to myself, `Hold on! I am the relevant Minister who sat there the other night through five hours of grilling on the defence forces'. Of course, it suddenly came back to me! Senator Newman asked me many questions, so did Senator Hill and Senator Tambling. I could not recall seeing Senator McLean there. Here is an issue over which he has called for the resignation of a Minister and for which he is prepared to assassinate that person's political career, yet he could not spare the time to come along to the Estimates Committee, ask the basic questions and find out the answers like other diligent senators around here.

The whole question of separation rates and the other matters on which Senator McLean has bleated today were raised in that Committee. He claimed that these matters were problems yet, on the whole, he has not justified them statistically. He has never responded to some of the answers that have been given; he would never change his ideas. He just reasserts the same bleatings every time. No matter what the answer, he apparently never changes his views. Yet he had the opportunity to be here last week and to ask the officials in the Department of Defence, whom he criticises, what was going on and what they were doing about the problems. He could have asked them how they justified expenditure in this area, but not that area. But he was in the land of the missing. Today Senator McLean has come into the Senate and said, `We want Mr Beazley out as Minister'. He has suggested that Kim Beazley should commit harakiri, because as I said before, a change of portfolio is political death at that stage of the Minister's career. Yet Senator McLean will not even come to the Estimates Committee and ask the appropriate questions.

I want to give the Senate a broad overview of our approach to defence issues. My colleague Senator McMullan will deal with the strategy and capital equipment program of this Government and my colleague Senator Collins will refer to separation and recruitment rates. I will not deal with those issues in any detail because they will be covered later in the debate. On our general defence policy, I point out that this Government has established coherent defence planning for the first time in Australia's history. We have related strategic analysis to Budget realities to produce an achievable and effective mix of defence capabilities. This process requires careful allocation of priorities between capital equipment, facilities, operational costs and personnel.

The Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), criticises Mr Beazley for paying too much attention to capital equipment but he does not say which of the capabilities that we are currently acquiring could be dispensed with. In fact, his only idea on equipment involved more spending, not less. His equipment proposals include buying an aircraft carrier, nuclear powered warships and nuclear powered submarines. Of course, these would cost billions of dollars. So when Mr White makes his points on this matter he adopts an even more ridiculous position than Senator McLean does. He wants to spend billions more dollars but that would have to be funded from somewhere else in the Defence Department. Therefore, more would need to be taken from some of the areas that Senator McLean has raised today. I think the reality is that a coalition government would cut defence spending. Given the Opposition's commitment at the last election to take $11 billion off government expenditure, even if it took only a portion out of defence that would mean a $1 billion cut. That is before we add in nuclear powered warships, aircraft carriers and all the rest of the new ticket items that the Opposition wants.

Some reference has been made to whether Mr Beazley gets his way in Cabinet. The Opposition regards defence as so minor and trivial that its defence spokesman is not even in the shadow Cabinet. Probably the Liberal Party of Australia will vote for this motion today, yet it cannot even be bothered putting its defence spokesman in the shadow Cabinet. He is somewhere in the outer. If the Liberals were really serious and this was a big issue there would be some good news awaiting Mr White next week-he would be promoted to the shadow Cabinet. Or will the Liberals again speak with forked tongues and just ignore the situation?

Senator McLean's assertion that there has been a reduction in the operational capabilities of the Australian Defence Force is, in my view, incorrect. This Government has put in place a comprehensive build-up of the ADF that balances priorities, redresses the Opposition's neglect over past decades and is committed to improving the conditions of service for ADF personnel and their families. I will not refer to-and I am glad Senator McLean did not-to the statement currently being made in the House of Representatives by Mrs Kelly.

We should look at some of the Government's achievements. Under the Liberal Government capital spending fell to below 10 per cent of the Defence Force budget. We have raised it to over 30 per cent by efficient planning and a careful setting of priorities. The White Paper presented to the Parliament provides us with a strategy for self-reliance based on defence in depth and the main objectives for Australian defence policy that will take our defence forces into the twenty-first century. Our priorities on defence spending accord with that strategy. For the Navy, capital equipment initiatives include an increase in the major surface combatants to 17; construction of six conventionally powered submarines; development of a mine countermeasures capability; and the purchase of Seahawk helicopters. The Army will have a highly mobile force capable of rapid deployment as a result of the purchase of Black Hawk helicopters, new field artillery and an improved fleet of vehicles. For the Air Force the most significant purchase is the tactical fighter force of 75 FA18 Hornet aircraft. In addition, Australian defence industries are being stimulated to provide the skills and technologies required to support our defence capabilities by the construction of equipment in Australia. Rather than going overseas with a shopping list every year or two, more and more we are trying to get this equipment designed where possible and, if not designed, built in Australia.

The Hawke Government has recognised the problems in the conditions of service and has acted to do something constructive about them. Some months ago my colleague the Minister commissioned Sue Hamilton from the Office of the Status of Women to identify and report on the problems facing personnel and their families. Later today-not too late, I hope-I will present a statement which details the manner in which the Government will implement the recommendations in that study. Some of those proposals include a whole range of suggestions to improve conditions for Army personnel. On the question of pay, this Government has established an independent, expert, impartial salary fixing tribunal-the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal-which provides the ADF with a wage fixing system comparable to that enjoyed by other elements in the community. We have recently seen significant increases in the service allowance, the field allowance and a range of other allowances, including the flying allowance to pilots.

Separation rates is another matter which this Government is not only concerned about but also is doing something about. I again remind honourable senators that Mrs Kelly is announcing new measures in the House of Representatives. I am a little restricted because of the coincidence in timing of this and I do not want to go into those details concurrently with Mrs Kelly. Senator McLean talks about low recruitment rates, but the facts are that recruitment rates have been maintained in line with the 1987-88 targets. This Government has also given the reserve forces new responsibilities and has passed legislation to enable them to be called out to meet low level contingencies.

In his urgency motion, Senator McLean says that the Minister for Defence has an apparent inability to control his Department. In fact, Mr Beazley has undertaken major reforms of his Department. The defence factories and dockyards have been totally overhauled and the huge defence logistics organisation has been reformed-perhaps a few weeks too late, but nevertheless it has been reformed. Very large savings are being achieved. These problem areas in the Department had been subsidised for years under the Opposition. However, I have only briefly outlined some of the steps that this Government has taken in the defence area. One difficulty I had in dealing with Senator McLean's speech was that every old canard was dragged out, irrespective of the fact that many questions have been asked on this matter. Perhaps not all of the answers have been satisfactory but many questions have been answered. It seems to me that Senator McLean never takes account of those answers, he just continues to roll out the old complaints.

If it were not for a history of devaluing motions in the Senate, this motion would normally have to be taken very seriously. As I said earlier, one would not believe so from Senator McLean's square-off remarks at the end of his speech where he almost apologised to the Minister, where he almost acknowledged that the Minister is not doing that bad a job, but said that it is his Department, the Cabinet or something else that is letting the country down. The wording of the motion goes directly to the fact that Senator McLean believes that Mr Beazley should resign.

I have done a comparison with the Democrats' performance in the defence area. It is almost a black hole; it almost does not exist. In the last election campaign, none of the Democrat spokesmen got any publicity on the defence issue. Probably not even--

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't own the media, like you do.

—Senator Powell says that the Democrats do not own the Press. I thought at least their favourites, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the National Times, would have given them some coverage on these issues. But did the Democrats make any major defence statements in the last election campaign? Can I hear Senator McLean nodding or not? It is very hard to detect what his answer is. Where were these statements made? Where are the cohesive policy statements of the Democrats in the defence area? How would they pay for defence spending? What percentage of gross domestic product do they want to allocate to defence? If they want to increase defence spending, what areas of current government spending do they want to take money away from? The Democrats should answer the hard questions. Until they can do that, Senator McLean has no right to come into this chamber and say that Minister X should go.
—We have every right. We were elected to come here.

—No, the honourable senator does not. He has to earn that right. He has to prove intellectually that he can sustain arguments on defence and that he can put up a coherent policy. When he can do that he will have earned his spurs and the right to come in and demand that Kim Beazley get out of politics. That is when the honourable senator earns that right, and not before.

SPEECH.PARA: We totally recognise that, although this motion deserves to be defeated, it will probably go through as a result of opportunism in the Senate. Nevertheless, I think this is a pity because the Minister for Defence has contributed enormously to many of the defence questions in this country. He has brought a rigour and enthusiasm for the area that was long overdue. I say to Senator McLean and other honourable senators-in some ways, this is a vacuous thing to say and I know that we often say it: I am quite confident that when history is written Mr Beazley will go down as one of the better Defence Ministers in this century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion moved by Senator McLean on behalf of the Australian Democrats which reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

`The need for the Minister for Defence to be removed from his portfolio given that over the last three years he has presided over the decline in morale of the defence force indicated by low recruitment, high wastage of personnel, and an apparent inability to control senior departmental officers, thereby losing the confidence of members of the defence force, the Parliament and the public, and as a result of all these factors precipitating an unprecedented crisis in Australia's defence capacity.'.

The Opposition will support this motion. But I have one serious query: if Mr Beazley goes, who will replace him? I hope that it will not be Senator Bolkus, who is on the front bench at the moment. Frankly, if one looks along the ranks of the front bench of the Australian Labor Party, one sees that they are rather thin. That does not apply to Senator Robert Ray; I must say that they are rather thin in quality. I do not know who the Labor Party can produce to replace the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). The only sensible option is, of course, to replace the whole Government. But, in the meantime, the performance of Mr Beazley and the Labor Party on defence has been one that deserves the censure of this Senate, because it has not been satisfactory.

What we must establish, as Senator Ray pointed out quite justly, is why the Minister for Defence-the Minister responsible for his Department-should go. After all, he has had some successes. For instance, I agree with the strategic policy which he has announced. It is a line of attack in our defence policy which I have been advocating in public for more than 10 years-that is, that our defence strategy should be based on doing the things that the Australian Defence Force might have to do on its own, at the same time as making our Force interoperable with those of our allies in case something broader breaks out beyond the capability of our Defence Force to deal with. That I agree with. It is to the credit of the Minister that that has been achieved. As I said, I have been advocating this for more than 10 years. In fact, as a member of the joint planning staff of the Defence Force, I was advocating it as far back as 1959. That recommendation, to my regret, was rejected by the then Government. I have been a long term advocate of this and I respect the Minister for having achieved it.

But it is one thing to have a strategic policy; it is another to carry it out administratively. The first task of a Minister for Defence in particular is to persuade his colleagues to give sufficient financial support to the Defence Force to achieve the strategic policy which he has got the Government to agree to. In this respect, the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, has been a conspicuous failure. For instance, in his White Paper on defence he announced a 3 per cent real growth over five years to implement his capital equipment program. But he could not persuade his colleagues to give him the resources to make that effective. In fact, there has been a one per cent decrease in real terms in the amount spent on defence.

This has happened at a time when he should have had the support of his colleagues and the support of the Australian public. A recent survey shows that 80 per cent of the Australian public are very concerned or somewhat concerned about our defence; and 47 per cent think we spend too little on our defence, as opposed to 16 per cent who think we spend too much. There is overwhelming public support for a proper defence effort. This requires the Minister for Defence, as the representative of the Defence Force in Cabinet, to see that the Defence Force gets the appropriate shares so that it can implement the strategy, the equipment program and the personnel requirements which have already been agreed to by the Cabinet. In that respect, Mr Beazley, the Minister for Defence, has conspicuously failed.

Faced with these diminishing resources, what has the Minister done? He seems to have a total hang-up on capital projects. Rather like a small boy with electronic toys, he likes playing with them. But he does not recognise that, although an effective defence force needs proper capital projects, it also must have a support structure, high morale and highly trained forces. If one is totally hung up on the things that look good in the shop window, the new defence capital projects, and does not have a proper balance within the Defence Force as a whole, one will finish up with a very unsatisfactory Defence Force. That is what this Minister has failed to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which of them would you cancel?

—I would not cancel any of them. I would do what this Minister should have been able to do, even in these harsh economic circumstances. He should have been able to persuade his Cabinet colleagues to provide the proper resources for the strategic policy which that Cabinet had already agreed to. In that persuasive task, the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, has totally failed.

SPEECH.PARA: The result of this hang-up on capital equipment is that we have high wastage of personnel because of what they perceive as poor pay and conditions. If one looks at recent submissions on wastage in the Defence Force made to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, one can see what is happening. I will take just one example. There is a 12.6 per cent wastage a year in the Navy. Under the present system, the Navy is 1,200 people short of the numbers it needs to do the task the Government has assigned to it. Why does the Navy have this very high wastage? When there is high wastage, more people have to be under training and, therefore, the effective force is diminished. This is one of the reasons why the Navy is 1,200 people short.

Let us look at the reasons given by the Chief of Naval Staff that have caused people to leave the Navy-and these reasons apply to all of the three Services: a lack of career satisfaction, and I will come back to that in a moment; insufficient remuneration for additional responsibility; reduced job satisfaction, especially for middle management officers who see themselves permanently posted ashore; dissatisfaction with frequent removals; change of schools; lack of career continuity for spouses; pay and allowances which are perceived as falling behind those of the rest of the community; poor defence housing and inadequate home loans; and a perceived overall deterioration of other conditions of service.

As usual with the emergency stopgap ways in which the Government seems to approach these things, it produced a system to stop the drain of highly trained Air Force pilots, or pilots in all three Services. An Air Force pilot probably costs about $2m to train to operational standard. Obviously, it is very unsatisfactory for those pilots to be drained off by the others. What has been offered, just to those people, is $70,000 if they stay for another six years. That might keep some of them in, but when looked at for the Defence Force as a whole, why is this sudden increase in pay given to that particular sector of the Defence Force? That sector is no more important in Defence Force terms than people in other sectors who have less negotiable assets in terms of saying they will go somewhere else. They should be used as a criterion of what proper Defence Force pay should be. That is not the approach being adopted by this Government.

Senator Newman has been very articulate over recent years in explaining the great difficulties of pay and conditions. She might like to say something more on those subjects later in this debate. Not only are the pay and conditions unsatisfactory, but also there has been a cutback in the reserves, ammunition supplies and exercises being conducted, all of which reduce the career and job satisfaction of Defence Force personnel. It is not surprising that they are leaving the Defence Force in very large numbers, at great cost to the community and at great cost to the efficiency of our Defence Force.

I come back to the reason: the Minister for Defence has a hang-up on capital equipment, which is an important part but is only one part of Defence Force efficiency. I do not know why he is hung up in that way. Certainly one of the reasons is that he is not in charge of his Department. He is the ultimate Minister being `Yes Ministered' by what is going on among his subordinates. I do not think that Yes Minister is the right criterion. I think that he is rather more like The Last Emperor. Honourable senators may have seen that recent film where a figurehead emperor presided with great dignity and apparent diligence but, in fact, was not influencing what was going on under him.

The problem is that the Minister is not properly supported in a political sense inside his Department. He has a Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) but, without being rude to the Minister, I think that she is more decorative than useful. I do not think that she does much in any way to improve the efficient working of the Defence Department. What the Minister really needs, in my view, is at least three parliamentary secretaries to do the tasks that he cannot do-that is, to go round on the constant visits to defence establishments to get a feedback of what people's feelings and problems are and to look at the supervision of public servants to see that things are not suppressed and concealed from a Minister who is just too busy to deal with all the details of his Department.

This Minister-perhaps any Minister, but particularly this Minister-is unable to run the Department of Defence. He cannot do the tasks that need to be done. One of the reasons we will be supporting the Australian Democrats' motion is that this is of his own making. A scathing report, with which I entirely agreed, produced by the former Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on the management of Australia's defence, showed that the structure of the Australian Defence Department was radically unsatisfactory. The report was produced in 1975 when we amalgamated the three Australian defence forces into a single department. I agreed with that; I thought that it was right. But the way in which it was done was outrageous. It handed over control effectively to public servants. It subordinated military advice and gave second guessing and a confrontationist approach to the whole question of Defence Force planning. It set up a maze of committees so that decision-making became almost impossible. Years pass while things go round from one to the other.

What did the Minister say when he was confronted with that report? Did he say, `I must do something'? No; he said, `I am satisfied with the present structure. I am not going to change'. If he is faced with a report that says very accurately what are the problems with his Department and he ignores the report and does nothing, that Minister must go. We cannot have a department which is so inefficient, so cumbersome and so unresponsive to real defence needs as our present Defence Department. The Greeks had an expression about enemies: `Give mine enemy a golden sword'. A modern version might be: `Give mine enemy an organisation like the Australian Defence Department'. That is what the present Minister for Defence is determined to preserve and protect.

There are all sorts of other problems with which I do not have time to deal, such as the way in which the senior ranks of the defence Forces have been grossly overinflated because of this structure which the Minister is determined to preserve. When this single organisation was set up, the public servants gave themselves quasi-military rank. An assistant secretary was said to rate as a one-star officer-a brigadier; a first assistant secretary, a two-star officer-a major-general; a deputy secretary a three-star officer-a lieutenant-general; and so on. Each service had to introduce a commodore, a brigadier, and an air commodore, which was a grotesque inflation of senior ranks. The Navy has 41 people of the rank of commodore and above. The Army has 60 and the Air Force has 41. There are no proper operational jobs for those people. This is causing an incredible distortion of the whole Defence Force. It is all because this Minister refuses to face up to the reality that his Defence Department is wrongly structured and that the professional advice he is getting is not appropriate. In one answer I got, people were referred to as professional civilians-whoever they may be-giving him advice. He must restructure the Defence Department to make it efficient, responsive and working for the interests of the defence of this country. As this Minister refuses to do this, as he refuses to face up to the responsibilities of his job and to get the Department run efficiently, the only solution is to change the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will discuss in a minute some of the comments that Senator McLean made when he launched this debate. I am pleased to see that Senator McLean has come out of hiding from the desk under which he crawled when Senator Ray spoke. If ever I saw a senator in here during a debate obviously more profoundly embarrassed than Senator McLean-in fact, I have not seen a senator more profoundly embarrassed than that-it was when Senator Ray pointed out, quite correctly, the gravity of the wording of the motion we are debating today. I had not noted the distinction of the wording of this motion. When I picked it up, I accepted it as being a call for a Minister's resignation-a call for a Minister to end his parliamentary career, his political life-on the grounds that Senator McLean has alleged. But Senator McLean was kind enough, in his final few moments, trying to crawl out from under, to point out that that was not so; he was simply asking the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) to vacate his portfolio, not to resign. That would have to be a classic Australian Democrats motion. Not only was no substance provided for it; the Australian Democrats do not even have enough intestinal fortitude to simply come out and demand a Minister's resignation. They have to put some shyster legal interpretation on the words-that he is not being asked to resign from political life; he is simply being asked to vacate his portfolio. I will get on to Senator McLean's comments in a minute. First of all, I want to comment very briefly on something that Senator Hamer said.

SPEECH.PARA: I was looking forward with some interest to Senator Hamer's contribution because he had a very distinguished career as a serving officer in the military forces; but I waited in vain. The same arguments were run: the Government does not spend enough money on defence. Senator Hamer referred to a poll that was done. With the greatest of respect to Senator Hamer, he will get precisely the same answer from any public opinion poll on defence that he will get from any public opinion poll on taxation. It does not matter which government is in office, how much money is spent or how little people are taxed. If we ask people out there whether they are paying too much tax they will say, `Yes, we are'. If we ask people out there, from now for the next 20 years, whether Australia is spending enough on defence, they will say, `No, we are not'. They will say that forever. It is not surprising that, with 16 million people spread across 3 1/2 million square miles and with 12,000 miles of coastline to defend, people obviously would not think that enough money is ever being spent on defence. I concur with them on that. It is an enormous responsibility for any defence force to take on to defend this country, with our low population base and our enormous coastline.

Indeed, I agree with Senator Hamer when he says that the one thing that the Minister for Defence has done, and has done in a spectacularly successful fashion, in my view, is to develop a cohesive regional defence policy that recognises the strategic nature of our country. In fact, he has done it for the first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —He cannot get the money for it, can he?

—Let us get onto that. The honourable senator has said that he cannot get the money for it. Senator Hamer made another sparkling contribution. Senator McMullan interjected when Senator Hamer was speaking and said, `What would you do? Which program would you cut in terms of this criticism of yours that Mr Beazley has a preoccupation with hardware?'. Senator Hamer replied, `I would not cut any programs. I would persuade my colleagues to spend more money'. Senator Hamer is nodding in agreement with that statement. I just have to point out the obvious to Senator Hamer. Senator Hamer did say that he felt Ros Kelly was more decorative than useful-`with the greatest respect', he said. With the greatest respect to Senator Hamer, I point out that before he can persuade his colleagues to spend more money on defence he will have to take that fundamental step and persuade his colleagues to elect him to the Ministry. Before Senator Hamer can take the second step, he has an enormous step to take in achieving even the first.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a common argument that we do not spend enough money on defence-`We will not scrap any programs that are there now; we will simply spend more money'. However, the problem is that the Opposition has gone on the public record as saying that it will cut government outlays by $11 billion. Just on a conservative estimate, $1 billion at least of that amount will have to come out of defence spending. It is hardly speculation to say that whoever gets the defence portfolio in any future coalition Ministry will not be able to implement these grandiose plans that have been announced. One simply cannot run a government that way. One simply cannot say that the answer to all of the current Government's problems and deficiencies is that it simply does not spend enough money.

As far as Senator McLean is concerned, I have a few more problems with the substance of his delivery. Senator McLean himself cut out the final part of his motion as to the reason why Kim Beazley should end his political career. He was kind enough to say that he did not think that being misled by officers, and I think that, if in fact that is demonstrated to be true, it would be a contemptible action on the part of those servicing officers--

TALK.START.PARA: —I said I didn't think it was reason enough alone.

—I am happy to accept that correction. Senator McLean said that he did not think it was reason enough alone for the Minister to step aside. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that the major matters are the other two of the three matters mentioned in the motion-low recruitment and wastage of personnel. I sat here for 15 minutes with my pen poised, waiting to take notes of what Senator McLean said about the low recruitment. I waited in vain. I simply did not hear about it. He ignored it. It is no wonder that Senator Ray could find nothing in the Australian Democrats' defence file.
—You must not have been listening. I read out two pages of statistics. You did not write them down.

—I paid careful attention. The Hansard record will demonstrate-and, in fact, the figures I am going to cite will demonstrate far more conclusively-that Senator McLean said nothing about low recruitment. The only mention of low recruitment was in the motion. He talked about wastage. I will give Senator McLean the so-called low recruitment rates. I invite him to disprove them. They are official Department of Defence figures. Let us hear Senator McLean say that they are wrong. They are for 1986-87, the latest figures available. That is why, according to the Australian Democrats, the Minister for Defence should resign. I ask Senator McLean to listen to these figures because they may be instructive. As there is nothing in the Democrats' defence file in the Library, maybe Senator McLean can put these figures in afterwards. These are the recruitment figures for 1986-87. The budgeted figure for the Navy was 2,101. Enlistments were 1,909. That was 192 personnel short of the targeted budget figure this year. For the Army, the targeted budget figure was 4,577; the actual number enlisted was 4,752. This was 175 above the target figure set this year by the Army. For the Royal Australian Air Force the figure was 2,281; the recruitment figure was 2,167. The actual recruitment was 114 short of that figure for this year.
—How long do they stay?
—Before Senator McLean jumps in where angels fear to tread, I can tell him that there is an even better figure available.
—You put them in a married quarter and see how long they stay.

—I can understand Senator McLean's sensitivity on this point. There is an even better figure available. I will give the total recruitment figures for 1986-87. They are down, in terms of the differences, by 131 personnel out of a total of 8,828. That is resignation stuff, indeed!
—They will walk out in droves when their kids go to school.

—I will give Senator McLean an even better measure of how successful or otherwise current recruitment is in the armed forces of Australia. The better figure is the approved terminal strengths, that is, the total strengths of all the forces concerned. Again I will give Senator McLean the latest figures, which are those for 1986-87. For the Navy the total budgeted strength was 15,732. That was the target set by the service. The Navy recruited 15,803. In other words, it recruited 71 personnel above the targeted figure.
—How does that tie up with Senator Hamer's figure of 1,200?

—I will give Senator McLean the figures for the Army. I know Senator McLean realises that he is on a down slope, but I ask him to hang in there because there is a bit more to come. For 1986-87 the targeted recruitment figure for the Army was 32,000 personnel. The actual number recruited was 32,311-311 personnel above the targeted figure. For the Air Force the budgeted figure was 22,797. The actual recruitment figure was 22,647. The recruitment for one service of a total enlistment of 22,797-almost 23,000-was down by 150 personnel. Out of those total defence service figures, and I say again that these are the most reliable figures used by the Defence Department as a measure of success in enlistment-- Senator McLean-Look beyond the day of entry.

—I can understand why Senator McLean does not want to listen to this. The total target figure was 70,529. The number actually recruited was 70,761-232 above the target figure. It is no wonder Senator McLean did not say too much about half his reason for calling for Mr Beazley's resignation. They are the official figures. I challenge the honourable senator to prove otherwise.
—How many of these recruits are replacing drop-outs?

—I hope that my colleague the good senator from the Northern Territory has not got the hide to stand up here this afternoon and attack this Government for defence spending because this Government has made the greatest commitment to the Northern Territory, in terms of personnel and money, of any government since Federation. It has made a spectacular commitment of funds. In fact, only a few weeks ago we visited Tindal air base. In terms of total commitment that base is to have $1 billion of public money spent on it by the time it is completed. The 16th Cavalry Regiment is already on its way. In fact, I must say that to the great relief of some private contractors in Darwin they will have a very considerable amount of work on their plates very shortly.
—What is morale like?

—I challenge Senator Tambling to start bucketing this Government for its defence commitment on the Northern Territory. He will live to eat his words. I would like to get onto Senator McLean again, before he dives back under the desk. He used the same old furphy-`Let us talk about the separation rates'. That is the only thing he talked about. He said that 12 per cent of the total Defence Force had resigned and what a disgrace it was. The problem is that Senator McLean has gone back to that empty folder in the Parliamentary Library. He has simply picked up the figure that was used by the Opposition in the House of Representatives and he has not bothered to analyse it at all. It is a question once again of lies, damned lies and statistics.
—You give us your lies, damned lies and statistics.

—I know that the honourable senator is naturally ignorant. Prepare to be instructed, Senator. Have a look at the analysis of the 12 per cent figure. The honourable senator should do himself a favour. The 12 per cent figure is made up not only of the two major areas of genuine retirements, that is superannuated and non-superannuated retirements, but of people going on maternity leave, anyone leaving the defence forces on unpaid leave for more than three weeks, and cadets, that is, the entire cadet force, young people leaving school and trying to decide whether they want a career in the defence forces and in fact leaving at a rate more than double the expected average rate of people leaving the Services. All of those people, those on maternity leave or unpaid leave over three weeks and cadets, are all included in the 12 per cent figure.

SPEECH.PARA: I will tell the honourable senator what the real figure is. In the two main categories of separation of full time serving personnel that I mentioned, those that qualify for superannuation and those that do not, those who are eligible for pensions are leaving at the rate of 5.9 per cent. That figure is in fact up by 0.8 per cent on what it used to be. This compares with a 10-year average of 5.1 per cent. So there has been an increase in that area. The figure for those people who are superannuated and who are leaving is even lower than that.

A couple of furphies were delivered about rates of separation from the Services that I will not have time to go into now. But I tell the honourable senator to do himself a favour. If he is asking people to resign on the basis of recruitment rates which are in fact more successful than the target figures set by the Services themselves, the honourable senator should eat his words and should withdraw this motion. If he is asking people to resign over a separation rate of 5 per cent, he should do the same.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we have once again heard the same old tired defence from Senator Ray, and I do not intend to give much time or attention to it because we have heard it all before. We have had a more interesting bombast from Senator Collins, but I feel it is only a diversionary tactic once again designed to distract attention from the very reasonable matter of urgency proposed by Senator McLean. I have too much ammunition to use this afternoon to waste time dealing with tired old noises from the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw your attention, Madam Acting Deputy President, to the fact that the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), the subject of this urgency motion, just one month ago, on 22 March, told the Parliament-and I quote him precisely:
Those who see the grey suited mandarins of Russell Hill as regiments of Sir Humphreys, should realise that in fact they are some of the toughest and brightest managers in the country.

The Minister said those priceless words himself. Those mandarins must be tough and bright because they have clearly been very effective in managing the Minister for Defence. I wonder just who wrote that speech for the puppet that we call the Minister for Defence. Those very same grey suited mandarins, of course. The sad thing is that, as one who was regarded with such high hopes by the Australian Defence Force, what a terrible disappointment Minister Beazley has been. Firstly, for three years he has been interested only in his equipment purchases. I do not intend to labour that point because Senator Hamer has already covered it well. Secondly, either he is in the total control of his grey suited mandarins or, and this could be an alternative we have to speculate on, he is fully prepared to dump the responsibility for his own inadequacy in the laps of those same mandarins. I do not know what it is. We can only speculate.

He has been totally unable to find the money to satisfy the requirements of his own White Paper that he so triumphantly brought to this Parliament not very long ago. It is all very well to ask what the Opposition would do about defence spending. We believe that the Minister made claims that he was very quickly quite unable to live up to, and for that he must be condemned. He was very proud to stump the country talking about his White Paper and his commitment of 3 per cent of gross domestic product to defence spending but he has not had success with his Cabinet colleagues or his Party, and quite clearly because so many of them are left wingers who do not seem to want to protect this country. That is one of his problems. He has been very ineffectual in probably the most important way for any Minister to win his battles in Cabinet-for the money.

But we find that he has been unable to get honest advice from his own Department as well. We are all aware of the very serious findings of the Auditor-General that were announced last week on the safety of explosives. I think the findings of the Auditor-General have demanded that scapegoats be found. I ask whether the Minister's defence is a conveniently leaked document which allows the blame to fall on his advisers, or whether we should assume that the advisers are either corrupt, inefficient or just plain perverse.

The record shows that they have certainly misled Mrs Kelly in the past. From August to October last year Mrs Kelly was coming out with some incredible statements about separation rates. She was saying that the whole issue was being incredibly exaggerated, and she was saying that the separation rates were pretty well due to the fact that people had served 20 years and were going out on pensions, that they were due to an increase in the number of women in the defence forces and that they were due to the Vietnam hump. My goodness me, we have heard it all from her, but we have also, very interestingly, heard it from Deputy Secretary A, when he gave evidence to the Estimates Committee. In fact he is still trying to give us some of that advice. Clearly Minister Kelly has been making speeches to the Parliament and public statements to the media along the lines that I believe show that she also is in control of those same grey suited mandarins. If they can do it to her, no doubt they can do it to Minister Beazley.

The Army submission to the joint parliamentary inquiry into wastage rates has given the lie to those claims made by Mrs Kelly and her advisers. I would like to give some evidence of that. Senator Ray was talking about the need for Senator McLean to address the motion. Let us look at how the Minister for Defence has handled his portfolio and what he has presided over. The motion says that he has presided over an enormous decline in morale. The Army submission that I referred to earlier has spelt out the importance of morale to the defence forces, and I would like to quote what it says:

It has often been the quality of morale which has been a deciding factor in battle and is a Principle of War. Morale, firepower and manoeuvre combine to form the basis of combat power . . . The consequence of high wastage is a lowering of this important combat power component-morale.

The factors which influence morale include leadership, unity of purpose, discipline, sense of belonging, comradeship, mutual confidence, dependants' well-being, job satisfaction, self- esteem, public image, government support, spiritual belief, and comfort and welfare. Those are the things that the Army is telling the Parliament. It goes on to say that the two exit surveys that have been run by the Army indicate that many soldiers are dissatisfied, as we know only too well. I have had so many letters from and interviews with service families and spouses around the country, and they tell me, `The general feeling is that nobody cares, particularly the Government' or, `I believe it is important to add my voice to the very few who are trying to tell the Australian public how depressed serving members are, and how resigned or angry their families have become' or, `As parents we are most concerned at the low morale developed following a period of high expectation and dedication on enlistment. Surely it is time someone stood for these people and made life a little more bearable for them.' What has the Minister for Defence been doing, for goodness sake?

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you suggest?

—He should show some leadership, but perhaps Senator Bolkus would not understand that. He has also presided over high and ever increasing wastage of Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel. A lot of evidence has already been given to the parliamentary inquiry. I am going to have great difficulty in finding time to give some of the information that I would like to give to the Senate today. The regular Army has turned over approximately 10,000 soldiers and approximately 1,200 officers from an authorised strength of about 32,000, just in the two financial years since July 1985, all during the present Minister's period of responsibility. The Army says that this increased wastage is causing concern, primarily because of its deleterious effect on Army capability, dilution of skill and experience, as well as administrative and training costs. Unless brought under control in the near future, it will have long term effects on the viability of the Army component of the Australian Defence Force. The Army points out that there is a finite limit to action beyond which efficiency falls and wastage increases. It says that the Army is close to or even past this limit now. It is terribly serious.
—Is this senior officers talking about themselves?

—This is the Army's official submission to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade inquiring into separation rates-the very submission, like the Royal Australian Navy submission, that the Minister and his office tried to get withheld from the Committee. The Army says that the wastage rate has had, and will continue to have, adverse effects on operational capabilities, officer manning, soldier manning, experience levels, morale, recruiting costs, training costs and administrative costs. There is an enormous number of categories that we are losing and that we should be aware of. The Government has given great attention to pilots, as if that covers the whole area. Sadly, by concentrating only on the pilots, it is ignoring the great areas of engineering, computers and communications experts in the three Services. It is just as serious that we are losing people in those areas as it is that we are losing pilots. It is much more serious, in fact, because of the long lead time in training their replacements.

SPEECH.PARA: The Navy has a shortage in principal warfare officers, weapons, electrical and marine engineers and seaman commanders. The very people who are needed to operate and maintain the expensive equipment that Minister Beazley has been so proud of are the ones who are resigning. That is what the Minister has presided over. Of course, as we have already said, he is also unable to control his departmental officers. I received a letter from Minister Beazley the other day, in which he said:

. . . the current strategic situation does not require the whole of the 1st Division to be at a high level of operational readiness to deploy at short notice. The Two Battalion 3rd Brigade can be deployed quickly and be sustained for at least six months and probably indefinitely on low level operations.
But the Army says:

The ODF, despite its manning priority cannot be protected from the effects of wastage. It is presently marginally under strength because the training system cannot replace wastage fast enough. The ODF Logistic Support Group can only be deployed at full strength by redeploying shadow posted personnel from lower priority units.

So the Minister is getting briefed by the civilians in the Department of Defence and the Army tells a different story. The Minister does not know what is the truth. The Navy talks about the Hamilton Review of the Effect of Service Life on Spouses. It says:
First published in April 1986, not one of the financial conditions recommended was implemented until 15 January, 1988.
And here is the interesting bit:
This was not for want of trying by the Services, but it was not until the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, acting in a new portfolio, brought pressure to bear that any progress was made.

Departmental officers from the departments of Defence, Finance and Industrial Relations all managed to deal with Minister Beazley-and they are doing a pretty good job now in continuing the pressure on Minister Kelly. They are captives of the Public Service. It is charitable, I think, even to say that they are trying.

Minister Beazley has also lost the confidence of the ADF. The Army submission says that a large number of older officers reported that they left the Army because they did not trust the Government to keep their pension entitlements intact. They are taking their commutation as soon as they become entitled to it despite there not being better jobs to go to outside the Army and despite a 3 per cent penalty per annum if they leave prior to their notional retirement age. That is how much they trust this Minister and his Government. My visits around Australia confirm that there is a very real lack of confidence in this Government and the Minister that they had such high hopes for. The disappointment is from their families, because of what has happening to them and because of the lack of action they have seen from Minister Beazley over all the time he has been Minister.

The Parliament has censured the Minister; the public does not have confidence that he has provided it with a defence force that is adequate. I am interested that Senator Collins does not seem to worry about that poll about Australians. I will leave it to my colleague Senator Tambling to tell him just what the grassroots in the Northern Territory think about his Government's protection in the area of defence. The Minister has precipitated an unprecedented crisis in Australia's defence capacity. The Army says that its training establishments have been able to cope with the increased throughput necessary to replace soldier wastage but it has been done at the expense of operational priorities. Long term vacancies are affecting its efficiency and capability. I could go on and on about the number of people it is short of. The Navy says the same thing in its submission to the inquiry. This problem is affecting, among other things, the achievement of acceptable weapons practice standards. It adds to the likelihood of increased numbers of groundings, collisions and accidents at sea.
