The trend has gradually worsened. These are serious statements and must be taken very seriously.

The Minister for Defence should have known about the urgency of the explosives problem. It is no good his trying to hide behind grey flannel suits. He is a puppet of his Department or he is misleading us. Either way, the ADF, the Parliament and the people deserve better. Puppets should stay in the toy box where they belong. We need a Minister for Defence who knows what is going on, who cares about his troops and who controls his Department. He has failed and he must go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very tawdry and sad little motion; and we have had some very pathetic contributions to what is a cavalier call in some way to try to justify the case that the person who has been widely regarded-and I will read some interesting quotes about that in a moment-as perhaps the best Minister for Defence that Australia has had since the Second World War, should stand aside. I will quote some people who would not be called the Australian Labor Party's traditional base or natural constituency. Here are some of the statements they have made about this Defence Minister. In Autumn 1987, the national journal of the Australian Defence Association was giving praise to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the Government for throwing off the shackles of the last 15 years. It was talking about a defence strategy that `represents a victory for commonsense and maturity' and having Australia represented by a government `which has given security issues a relatively high priority', recognising the importance of those defence issues. Sir William Keys, in the last election, told people not to listen to what the Liberal Party says. He said a Liberal government would have to change its defence policies and adopt the programs already begun by the Hawke Government. The Canberra Times-which is of particular significance to me and I do not want to underestimate its importance-said, during the last election:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has embarked on the greatest program of re-equipment of the armed forces ever undertaken in peacetime . . . The endorsement of the re-equipment program . . . by the national president of the Returned Services League, Sir William Keys, was powerful ammunition for the Government . . . Many will match the Government's performance to date with that of earlier governments which were long on rhetoric but short on performance. The bleak reality for the Opposition is that so far the Hawke Government has performed a great deal better in the defence area than most of its predecessors in peacetime.

This is about the Defence Minister, whose conduct of his portfolio in some way is supposed to mean that he should stand aside, that his political career should be torn up because he is not a success. He is the most successful Defence Minister that Australia has had. We try to understand how this very cavalier call could come about. It is coming from the Australian Dem- ocrats. It is comprehensible when we analyse it politically. It is a typical Australian Democrats proposal. It is breathless and belated and it is made in the frantic search for a constituency that they think might be out there-to add another half per cent to their pathetic little vote. The issue they start to speak about is one that everybody else-even the Opposition, to its credit, as well as the Government-has been talking about for three years. The Democrats are breathlessly discovering that there might be a few thousand votes out there. A couple of people in New South Wales have said, `Perhaps we will vote for you, Senator McLean; why don't you come and make a speech about defence?'. So, he decided that he would just make the speech that his predecessors had made. However, he went to the library and the cupboard was bare, so he came here and made a speech. But the next person who goes there will find that the cupboard is still bare, as Senator McLean had nothing to say.

There was no coherent overview of Australia's defence forces whatsoever. How can there be? People who have no pretension to government can just cobble together a series of unrelated policy and finance commitments-all care and no responsibility. They say, `Here we are, we will provide more expenditure here, less tax there, and we will try to reduce the deficit as well'. I shall refer further to the Opposition's lack of a coherent overview in a moment. Basically, it is a very sad and inadequate motion. Even in relation to the matters that it attempts to address in regard to the serious problems of defence personnel, which have developed over a long time and which no one can pretend do not exist, it fails to acknowledge--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not pretending.

—What the Minister said, quite accurately, was that this is the first government that has begun to address the serious problems in relation to housing and education and the adjustment problems of defence personnel. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) has never said that defence personnel do not have problems. She has said that the Government is going to start to address them. In relation to what the Government has begun to do in this regard, I refer first to the area of housing. The Hamilton report of the Review of Effect of Service Life on Spouses quite clearly stated that there was a problem and that measures to address it were under way. They certainly are. A Defence Housing Authority has been set up. That, itself, will not build any houses--
—Fifty per cent of the houses are condemned.
—That is right; that is exactly why the Government has pledged $750m over the next seven to 10 years for acquisition.
—It will not do the job at all; it's not nearly enough.

—I would love to talk about the calls for increased defence expenditure made by the Opposition; I will have the time to do that and I will return to that matter in a moment. However, some $750m will be spent over the next 10 years. Of course, the Opposition maintains that it would spend a lot more if it was in government. In fact, the Government has exceeded that promise so far. Some $73m was provided for capital expenditure and an additional $46m has since been given to the Defence Housing Authority-$10m for essential improvements and $36m for spot purchasing of houses. So, $119m has been committed to improve defence housing this financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be that the Opposition would like $4,000m or $75,000m-perhaps we could go and buy Paradis sur Mer and put a few defence personnel in there! That is a pretty good idea! But, realistically, no-one has ever made that sort of commitment before. Yet, it is claimed that the Minister for Defence who is responsible, should step aside. What positive points have the Australian Democrats made? They criticised the Government for 14 3/4 minutes, or whatever it was, and in the last 30 seconds they were a little bit embarrassed, and Senator Newman correctly said--

TALK.START.PARA: —No embarrassment at all.

—Well, the honourable senator should have been embarrassed; if he was not, it is to his eternal discredit. The Government may well ask the Democrats what their positive proposals are. The honourable senator's proposal to improve the morale of the Defence Force was to switch the emphasis to civil defence. I can see the pilots flocking back in droves. I can well hear the pilots who are leaving saying, `I won't go to Qantas, this is a wonderful suggestion; perhaps I could be involved in civil defence; I would not dream of going to Qantas with such a boost in morale'.
—What about buying some C-124s and surveying our north coast?
—The honourable senator is now saying that the Defence Force should take over coastal surveillance. What a silly suggestion.
—It's a sensible suggestion and it has been put to the Joint Committee.

—I have heard a lot of suggestions put to the Joint Committee. I am very pleased that Senator Newman and Senator Hamer are not responsible for our industrial relations. They took the defence and Navy submissions, but they cannot tell the difference between an ambit claim and a proposal. If they were Ministers for industrial relations, I would love to be a union official, as they would accede to all the ambit claims. I would love to go on about that matter some more but, essentially, my responsibility here today is to speak to the substance of this matter concerning Minister Beazley's role as Minister for Defence. After all, the motion calls for the removal of the Minister for Defence from his portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider the defence developments that have occurred in Australia since Minister Beazley became the Minister for Defence. He commissioned the Dibb report. That does not take us very far; people run around calling for inquiries all the time. The Democrats love them; they belong to the party for mirrors-they keep going around and looking into things. But they do not actually want to do anything. So, we had the Dibb report; a good report, but that is all it was. The Government then built on that, and we had the defence White Paper, based, as Senator Robert Ray said, on the important, coherent and strategic concepts of self-reliance and defence in depth.

It is not just an academic treatise, like White Papers have been in the past. The recommendations are actually being implemented. On 22 March this year we were given the Minister's statement on the implementation of recommendations. As Senator Collins correctly said, we are now moving towards northern defence, with the second cavalry regiment due to be transferred to Darwin, and the two-ocean Navy concept is finally being developed. When I was State Secretary of the Labor Party in Western Australia, every three years the two-ocean concept would be raised. Mr Killen and Mr Fraser would come over, would meet with Sir Charles Court and would announce the upgrading of HMAS Stirling. Nothing would happen and three years later they would come back and announce it again. They would use exactly the same Press release. They would dust it off, cut off the faded edges of the paper and release the same Press release again.

So, when this was announced by Minister Beazley I am sure that everyone could hear the guffaws, because people had heard it all before. However, if one goes to HMAS Stirling now one finds that there are destroyers based there and that submarines are based there. Half the Navy will be based in the Indian Ocean. Somebody has finally realised that a substantial part of Australia's coast is lapped by the Indian Ocean, that we are not just a Pacific Ocean country.

With that we have a coordinated response with both the purchase of capital and with personnel. I was fascinated to hear Senator Hamer's proposal concerning excessive emphasis on capital. I refer to the Defence White Paper of Minister Killen in 1976 which said that the then Government would restrict expenditure on personnel and concentrate on capital equipment. That was the great White Paper proposal of the Liberal Minister for Defence. The only thing one can say is that, like the Liberals' wages policy, it failed. In 1980, in absolute chaos, the former Minister had to come into the Parliament and say that the proposal had been scrapped, that there had been a proposal in its White Paper to restrict expenditure on personnel and concentrate it on equipment but that now they had had to scuttle all the way back and abandon all the capital proposals and start to give some money to the poor old workers in the Defence Force.

Thus, the previous Government scuttled all the way in one direction in 1976 and then it dropped that and scuttled all the way back in 1980. Where were the Democrats then, calling for Minister Killen to resign? They were as silent as the grave. Now, when we have the first person who is actually to coordinate a program dealing with capital and personnel, suddenly the Democrats come out and try to fill that empty file in the library. Thus, we finally have that coordinated and comprehensive list of capital developments, together with the personnel improvements that are being made for the Australian Defence Force, so that for the first time we can have a coordinated program.

At least Senator Hamer had the courtesy to acknowledge the legitimacy of the Government's strategy. He said that he had been proposing it to Liberal governments for years but that they had ignored it. Minister Beazley is the first Minister to have realised the sensible and necessary strategy for Australia's defence. However, Senator McLean shamefacedly had to pretend that he thought it was a good idea for the Minister to step down. But I notice that he did not suggest that he thought it was a good idea for the honourable member for McPherson, Mr White, to be put into the shadow Cabinet-that poor excuse for a shadow Defence Minister, of whom Mr Howard thinks so little that he will not put him in the shadow Cabinet.

It is the first time in living memory that a defence spokesman from any party has not been in the Cabinet or shadow Cabinet. We can understand why, when we hear what the member for McPherson says. I would not want him on any advisory committee of the local football club. However, I suppose that that is why he cannot cope with the contradiction between what he says about defence and what Senator Newman and Senator Hamer have said about defence-and about what I suppose poor old Senator Tambling will have to say about defence as well.

In relation to their economic policy, I notice that Senator Stone, quite sensibly, has not come into the chamber. He and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) are saying that they would cut $11 billion out of government spending. They have this awful black hole in their economic policy. They cannot work out where the $11 billion will come from; they cannot raise it by consumption tax. Senator Newman believes that $750m is not enough to spend on defence housing. Senator Hamer says that nothing in the capital equipment program should be cut back; we should just spend more money. So perhaps we should cut $12 billion out of social welfare in order to get some more money to spend on defence housing, personnel and recruitment. The arithmetic does not add up. They have always had a black hole in their economic policy. It is now showing up as the black hole in their defence policy. The longer the term of this Government goes and the closer we get to the election, that black hole in the Opposition's expenditure policy will show up in every area as Opposition members say, `Spend more money here, but cut taxes there'. They have a typical opinion poll-driven policy. They want to spend more money, have less tax and lower the deficit. It does not add up; it can never add up.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about their communications policy?

—That does not exist, so it certainly does not add up. They cannot tell the difference between nought, 25, 43, 60 and 100. That is about the same as their expenditure policy in defence. It does not and cannot add up. That is why they cannot get a coherent strategic position, because one cannot analyse defence implementation outside an economic and social context. They have to say that Minister Beazley has delivered the best defence strategy-even Senator Hamer had to admit that. He has been the first Minister to address the serious problems for Defence Force personnel in housing, education and adjustment. We have only just started; there is a long way to go. To say that the first Minister to get the strategy right, the first Minister to start to put the capital implementation program into operation, the first Minister to address these personnel problems should step aside is a sad scandal. One would think that this was April Fool's Day if one had not looked at the calendar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The urgency motion before us today is weak in only one respect, and that is that Senator McLean has called only for a change in status for the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). He should have coupled the name of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly). We have been let down very dramatically by both Ministers, Minister Beazley and Minister Kelly, neither of whom has faced up to his or her responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: We have listened to a debate in this chamber today which indicates the concern of a lot of people for defence. Senator McMullan asked about the qualifications of senators on this side of the House to speak in this debate. Senator McLean, representing the Australian Democrats, was an Army major, which gives him certain qualifications to speak. Senator Newman is married to a former Minister in the Fraser Government and a former lieutenant-colonel. Senator Hamer, who spoke earlier, is a retired Navy captain. I am the only speaker on this side who has not been a member of the defence forces, but I certainly take a very keen interest in that area and I am currently a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

By comparison, the three Labor right wing stooges that were put up today were a schoolteacher, an agricultural technical officer and a party administrator-certainly all of them heavies, not just in the weight factor but also in the Labor Party's muscle machine. But they have not been able to convince the Senate that we are wrong in seeking to address the decline in morale, the problems of recruitment, the high wastage and the inability to control senior departmental officers. What are we talking about? We are talking about people, the people of the defence forces, and their relationship to their Minister or Ministers. That is where the inadequacy lies.

Senator Collins made play of the fact that there is a large amount of defence expenditure in the north of Australia. I can identify with that, but also I can identify with my constituents in the Northern Territory electorate, the members of the defence forces who share all the concerns about morale, their services, their conditions, job satisfaction, families and the relations with Russell Offices, the departmental officers and their Minister. Certainly they share all those concerns, which have culminated today in the need for this urgency motion.

The Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, has totally ignored the executive authority that he has to show in his portfolio. As Senator McLean said earlier, that resulted in a serious report by the Joint Committee in December last year, and all that work was public and taking place throughout 1987. Some of the recommendations of that report into the senior management of the defence forces were most important. It recommended a review of the organisational arrangements between the Minister and the Department. It stressed the insufficient political control and the need for increased political participation and involvement in defence decision making. It brought out the fact that there was need for an additional Minister or Ministers and that the terms of reference of the Defence Council should be broadened so that the Minister himself should be more involved with detailed supervision, because of the size and complexity of the Australian defence forces. A number of recommendations related to Government involvement and the fact that the Minister himself should chair the Defence Force Development Committee, which is crucial. None of that has happened. There has been no report to this Parliament. The Minister has had sufficient time and plenty of warning and notice to respond to all those issues, but he has not done so.

Basically servicemen are conservative and loyal and demonstrate a very high degree of tolerance and dedication. But when one reaches the point that their frustration spills over, when issues such as this have to be raised in Parliament on their behalf, with Labor Party members sitting back and scoffing, I believe it is an insult to the service personnel of Australia. How do we underpin their involvement, their careers, their jobs and their strong belief that what they enlisted for and the jobs they took on resulted from the fact that people cared about the Services and about the constitutional arrangements that their particular jobs gave them?

Service personnel are involved in a peculiar career, one that exercises all the defence and security roles and all the rest of it. It is arrant nonsense for Ministers and for the Labor Party to argue in this place that these people do not feel that they can belong to their jobs adequately at present or that they are getting sufficient support. Their morale is constantly under threat. How do they perceive themselves? How can they be sure that they are not just living the life of a public servant, with all the attendant comforts and normal life and rights that public servants enjoy? There is something that is a bit extra and a bit more special in the defence forces.

There is a widespread malaise which can be corrected only through positive, unequivocal demonstration of the need for servicemen. Those needs are demonstrated in inducements, irrespective of the economic fundamentals, through an arbitration set of principles and through other criteria which will bind the Australian defence forces to the community at large. The thorny problems which have to be faced up to certainly attract publicity, but they are not attracting action, policies or responses from a Labor government at this time. This is what is now taking to the boundary points the tolerance levels of the personnel who are employed in those areas.

As I mentioned earlier, I am a member of the subcommittee that is looking into personnel wastage in the Australian defence forces. Over 200 submissions have already been given to that parliamentary inquiry. The number of submissions that are coming in will probably break the records. By far the largest majority are coming in from all ranks throughout the Services and from their wives and families. Let me take the time of the Senate to give a few quotations from some of the submissions. The first is from a submission by Lieutenant-General O'Donnell, the Chief of the General Staff:
The current high wastage in the Army is of major concern to my Senior Commanders and myself and-
I stress this-

has the potential to pose significant long-term consequences for national defence. There is a need to take immediate action to reduce wastage and to investigate and implement long-term strategies to keep wastage at manageable levels.
That is in the general's particular submission to the inquiry. The Navy submission states:

Navy has argued consistently [that its Authorised Average Strength] is too few, despite having made significant structural changes in order to reduce its manpower requirements . . . Navy needs 1200 more people across the FYDP [five year defence program] or will have to stop some major activity in order to accommodate the capital equipment program. This forms the background to the wastage problem.

So the Army and the Navy point out in their official submissions that things are at breaking point and stress point. I refer now to individuals who have made submissions. An Army lieutenant-colonel states:
I am finding it increasingly difficult to persuade myself and my subordinates that the profession of arms is a worthwhile career.
Another Army colonel states:
My major contention is that officers and, to an extent, soldiers in the ADF are suffering from a morale problem.
Members of an Army unit state:
Leadership at all levels from Minister and general level to corporal level is an area of strong dissatisfaction among soldiers.
Retired Major-General K. J. Taylor states:

The present [high wastage] situation is mainly due to [first] the abrogation by successive governments of their responsibility to the personnel in the Services [and secondly] the stultifying and delaying effects of the bureaucracy of the Defence Dept and the ADF in Canberra.
Dr Jans, a lecturer at the Canberra College of Advanced Education and a former Army psychologist, bases his statement on Navy morale and a rigorous survey; it is not merely assertion. Dr Jans states:

Navy officers now believe that their service is less effective than it was in 1984 . . . A comparison with Public Service executives shows that the organisational commitment of Navy officers is not very much higher than those of the civilian group . . . given the proud traditions of the Royal Australian Navy, and the very intense professional socialisation of early career experience in the services, compared with those of the unnamed civilian organisation, these comparative data do appear to indicate cause for concern, if not alarm. We would expect-indeed, service chiefs would require-service morale to be skewed markedly to the high end of any measure. Instead, they are normally distributed.

Dozens of similar statements are being submitted to the inquiry. Senator Collins mentioned recruitment figures as if they were on a score sheet and something to be proud of. Recruitment is necessary at such high levels only because of the wastage problem at the other end. Personnel are going out all the time--

TALK.START.PARA: —How are you going to fix it? You have three minutes.

—Many of the submissions presented to the committee address this area. The Minister for Defence has the responsibility to fix it, and it is his responsibility to address specifically a number of conditions of service, particularly areas such as housing, lifestyle and family; and he must attend to those areas that the Australian Defence Force (ADF) has highlighted time and again as not having been addressed. It might be preschooling or education allowances. What about the social and family disruption? Obviously Senator Collins does not want to put up cash to correct problems in these areas. They include conditions of service, pay, allowances and postings but most of all it is a question of job satisfaction. I think probably one of the most telling quotes of all in the submissions to the current inquiry is that from the Consultative Group of Defence Spouses, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: If the serving member feels highly satisfied with his work environment he is more likely to remain with the Defence Force in spite of the sacrifices that must be made. When he experiences little personal achievement and job satisfaction he looks for job opportunities in other areas of Defence. However, when they are faced with a husband who comes home dissatisfied with his job or over-tired or severely stressed because he is undertaking additional duties due to fewer personnel or increased service demands they ask the question: Why are we continuing to put up with this?

The Minister must bear the responsibility for the seriousness of the problem. Senator McLean's motion today points out the urgency of this problem. There can be no denying that morale is low and that it needs to be addressed. There are recruitment problems in attracting the right type of people to the right sorts of places and ensuring that the wastage problem is not merely the hole in the bottom of the bucket with recruitment going in through the top. The Minister is unable to control departmental advisers to himself and to the ADF. He has been totally derelict in not being able to supervise and demand a standard of satisfaction that instils in people in the defence forces and the general community of Australia the necessary standards that are so vital. I commend Senator McLean's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In the few minutes remaining I will respond to some of the observations made by Government senators. I was rather looking forward to the time when the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) became Minister for Defence, and hoped that perhaps it would be relatively soon. However, my opinion changed a little this afternoon. The Minister began by saying that he went to the Parliamentary Library looking for the Australian Democrats' defence policy but the file was empty, so he jumped to the conclusion that there was no policy instead of concluding that someone had borrowed it to read it. It struck me that the Minister hardly came to the obvious conclusion. I point out that there is a Democrat defence policy. It was our first policy and it has existed for 10 years. It was on file in the Library but obviously someone has borrowed it to read it. The fact that the Minister was not able to arrive at that conclusion is a little alarming. The Minister then concluded, wrongly, that because we Democrats are anti-nuclear we are anti-defence. The Minister was unable to make the distinction that it is possible to be anti-nuclear and at the same time pro-defence. In fact, we are very pro-defence. If the Minister looks at our defence policy he will gain the impression that we are vitally concerned with the defence of this nation. The fact that I have moved this motion today is indicative of the fact that we are vitally concerned with the defence of this nation. I was not impressed by the Minister's logic because within two minutes he revealed two illogical and gross flaws.

SPEECH.PARA: He then asked about the alternative models that I have offered. Obviously the Minister has not read anything that I have said about defence. In my maiden speech I addressed the whole question of defence models and on about five occasions I have attempted to build upon a number of simple propositions which hopefully he as the representative of the Minister for Defence might hear. He may even refer them to the Caucus room and offer them as constructive suggestions to get the Minister for Defence on the right track. I think that honourable senators opposite were oversensitive about criticism of the Minister for Defence. Quite obviously this motion will be carried this afternoon but the Minister will not resign-it is just a kick in the tail. He should do his job a little better, alerted and better informed as a result of this exercise; so there is no need to become emotionally stressed about it.

I stood here and quoted statistic after statistic-in fact, two pages of them-and Senator Collins sat with his pen poised but did not write anything down, but I am not surprised because he had his own biased set of figures in front of him. Senator Collins then stood up and interpreted the figures at the point of entry. Everything that we have been saying is about how people react once they get into the Services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Biased figures from the Director-General of Recruiting?

—Senator Collins is missing the point. I am talking about how people react once they get into the defence forces, but Senator Collins is telling us about the recruitment figures. I have heard Senator Hamer tell us that the Navy is 1,200 short; I have heard Senator Newman quote from the most senior members of the Australian Defence Force. I have heard Senator Collins's figures and I have my own here. So we are all confused.

SPEECH.PARA: However, we are not the slightest bit confused about the state of morale in the defence forces. Senator Tambling read out one opinion after another, coming directly from serving members of the Australian Defence Force about their personal morale and their own circumstances. Senator Newman has told us what senior officers think about it. The news is bad yet the Government is trying to convince us that it is good. The news of the defence forces in this nation is appalling.

We are simply delivering the message to the Minister for Defence to get his act together. This is the final message that he should get from this whole exercise. Having read the summary of the Auditor-General's report-and the last four pages are enough-I can tell honourable senators that that summary is absolutely decimating of the level of information and control that this Minister has over his Department. The report relates to only one dimension of his Department. It is absolutely castigating and it happens to be the event of the last two or three days. I am talking about his performance over the last two or three years. This is the most damning report that a Minister could be confronted with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Really?

—Yes. The Minister has been utterly snowed by his Department. I shudder to think what the realities might be in other dimensions of his administration. He has been snowed by the senior officers of his Department. I wonder how the United States has snowed him over the question of the bases? I wonder how he has been snowed time and again over questions of defence contracts? Frankly, I have no confidence when I look at one dimension of his Department. In the final analysis, he has had a kick in the tail in this place this afternoon. I hope he gets on with the job because he is being paid big money to get on with it. We are told by Senator McMullan that he is so competent, so presumably he will take on board the observations that have been made and proceed--
—You do not want him to resign now?

—Yes. I think that would be the best thing that could happen. The fact is that there has been placed before the Parliament and the public a document which suggests recent inadequacy. We cite inadequacy over a period of three years. We are calling for the Minister's resignation. We do not believe that that is unjust or that it will be the final outcome of this exercise, but we believe that it is an appropriate and responsible measure for us to take as a result of seeing what has happened in the last few days and watching his performance over the last three years. I thank the Opposition for its support in this urgency motion because it is indeed a matter of grave urgency. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator McLean's) be agreed to

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendment made by the Senate to this Bill.
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Over the last two years this Labor Government has embarked on a program of major improvements in the quality of administration and decision-making in the Social Security portfolio. This programme has dual objectives:
To ensure that every Australian resident obtains adequate income support as and when it is needed;
to protect the revenue by ensuring that payments are not directed to those who do not require them.
This program has involved major legislative change and significant new administrative arrangements.
There is no area which more fundamentally shows the difference in approach between this Labor Government and the conservative Opposition.

Our approach has been, as Professor Fred Gruen recently noted to `square the circle'. We have substantially increased the real level of pensions, benefit and allowances while reducing the level of social security expenditure as a proportion of gross domestic product. We have done this through close attention to the detail of the administration of each program to maximise the accuracy of social security decision-making.

When in Government the conservatives proved themselves incapable of this form of development. In Opposition the conservatives have confirmed their approach. They would reduce social security expenditure-but how would they do it? They would do it by wholesale cutting of programs-by denying help to those who need it:
They would terminate eligibility for sole parent pensions when the youngest child turns 10;
they would make people who resign a job wait for 6 months before paying any benefit;
they would not pay benefit to people who are sacked for lengthy periods, not until their redundancy payments are exhausted.

These measures are exactly the sorts of steps this Labor Government will not take. We will continue to improve the standard of living of all those residents of Australia who cannot adequately support themselves. We will do this, while protecting the taxpayers of the country from excessive burdens by close, hard, detailed examination of social security program and administration. This Bill is a further step in our program of improving the quality of administration and decision making in the Social Security system.
Last year this Labor Government introduced family allowance supplement as part of its attack on child poverty.

Under this Bill the administration of the family allowance supplement will be improved by refinements to the treatment of lump sums under the income test. People who take leave from employment and are paid in a lump sum rather than during the period of leave will have their payments spread over the period of leave. At present family allowance supplement may be forfeited if the lump sum is treated as income within the period of receipt. This disadvantages those who receive leave payments in a lump sum compared with those whose leave payments are staggered by their employers. Lump sum education payments will also be spread over the period to which they relate.

A measure will be introduced to protect student parents who, in 1988, were not aware of their family allowance supplement entitlements until they received education payments. As the education payments may be made in respect of an earlier period, family allowance supplement will be payable to cover this earlier period of entitlement. To obtain these arrears of family allowance supplement the student parents must claim family allowance supplement within 6 weeks of receipt of the education payments.

Improvements will also be made to the parental income test on the job search allowance. The year of parental income that is tested will be moved forward to the year ending in the month of June in the previous financial year rather than the month of June in the previous calendar year. This will assist in ensuring that the level of payment is more closely aligned to real need. Where a parent is a social security recipient the parental income test will not apply.
This Bill contains measures to improve the administration and integrity of compensation recovery provisions.

Where a person receives personal injury compensation that makes up for lost income the Social Security Act provides that pension or benefit may be reduced or recovered. This is one way in which social security expenditures are directed to those most in need.

Settlements of lump sum compensation particularly in the workers compensation jurisdiction are being manipulated to obscure the economic loss component and to avoid recovery of social security payments. To prevent this abuse I announced on 8 February 1988 that, for future personal injury settlements made by agreement or by consent order, 50 per cent of lump sum compensation will be deemed to be in respect of economic loss. This Bill gives effect to that proposal. Where, on the other hand, a court has made an order after a contested hearing specifying the economic loss component, the Secretary to the Department will continue to have regard to the characterisation given to the award by the court.

To improve consistency in the treatment of income of social security recipients the Bill proposes to exempt German restitution payments from the definition of income under the Act. This will ensure that payments from West Germany made by way of compensation for nazi persecution are not treated as income. Only those payments expressly paid for lost income will continue to count as income.

The rules preventing payment of arrears of sickness benefit to those who have failed to lodge their claim within the necessary time limits will be modified to accommodate those whose incapacity has prevented them from lodging their claim in time. Up to four weeks arrears from the date of claim will be payable in such cases. This will ensure that the very ill have access to four weeks arrears just as those who are able to claim shortly after the date of their incapacity.

In recognition of the care required by a disabled child who attracts child disability allowance, a sole parent will not lose his or her entitlement to sole parent's pension when that child turns 16 years of age.
Other measures contained in this Bill clarify provisions in the Social Security Act or close gaps remaining from amendments enacted last year.

Assets limits for married beneficiaries under the benefits assets test have been clarified. Previously the benefits assets test for a married beneficiary was linked to the pensions assets test. Where only one spouse was in receipt of benefit but claimed additional benefit for a dependent spouse this resulted in a limit that was half the combined married limit. The assets limits in these cases will now be twice the sum available to each individual spouse under the pensions assets test.

The residence requirements for children who attract additional pension and benefit for their parents have been adjusted to reflect the particular residential status of special beneficiaries and non-Australian residents with portable pensions.

Sickness beneficiaries or their spouses who temporarily leave Australia, for example to seek medical treatment abroad, will be permitted to continue to receive sickness benefit or to attract additional benefit for up to three months of their absence.

Finally, to complement the introduction of supported employment services under the Disability Service Act 1986, Sheltered Employment Allowance will be available to disabled people who are employed in these services.
The Social Security Act is amended regularly in the interests of good administrative practice and to improve the efficiency of the services provided to clients.
The Bill will ensure that these aims continue to be served.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The main purpose of this Bill is to establish the Civil Aviation Authority.
The Government's decision to proceed with establishment of a Civil Aviation Authority was announced in my statement to the Parliament on 7 October 1987.

I indicated at that time that it was hoped to see the Authority operational within 12 months or so, after appropriate consultation on implementation details and parliamentary approval of the enabling legislation. A commencement date for the Authority of 1 July 1988 has been adopted for planning purposes.

The proposed Authority will have operational responsibilities for air traffic control, flight advisory services, communications, navigation and surveillance systems, and rescue and fire fighting services at airports.

The Authority will provide an aeronautical information service and will offer consultancy and management services in its fields of expertise. It will also be responsible for organising aviation search and rescue services.
It is the Government's view in the light of experience, that these functions would now be better performed through a statutory authority than by a department of state as in the past.

It has been the policy of successive governments that the costs of services provided in support of the conduct of civil aviation operations should be recovered from the aviation industry. Given this policy, the body providing these services should be so structured as to make it adequately responsive to the industry's requirements and to industry's capacity and willingness to meet associated costs.

Growth in both the volume and complexity of air traffic in recent years places increased demand on the air traffic services system in Australia. At the same time there is a need to reduce national transport infrastructure costs through increased productivity.

Advances in technology, particularly in the communications field, offer the potential to develop a more cost efficient air traffic services system, but this will entail a major program of investment in modernisation and upgrading of the present system. Planning and implementation of such a program can be better undertaken through a self-funding body which directly recovers the costs of services it provides, than through a budget dependent department.

In the light of these considerations, it is proposed that the Civil Aviation Authority be established as a statutory body, under the control of a nine member board appointed by the Minister. A group of this size will allow for an appropriate range and balance of expertise in the composition of the board's membership.

There is provision for the board to establish advisory committees to assist it, which widens the scope to draw upon persons with experience in business, aviation operations, air safety regulation, trade unions, academia and other appropriate fields, for planning and conduct of the Authority's functions.

Close consideration has been given to whether safety standard-setting and day-to-day regulatory control should become the responsibility of the Authority, or whether these functions should remain with a department. A wide range of interested parties has been consulted and views differ on this important question.

As I indicated in my statement of 7 October 1987, there is considered to be strong logic in the view that the task of regulating aviation safety must be regarded as an integrated system in which all elements are coordinated to achieve maximum reliability and effectiveness.
The operation of air traffic control and the flight advisory service is as much a part of safety regulation as the regulation of an aircraft and its crew. The two areas complement each other.

Safety regulation has been successfully combined with the operation of the airways system for many years in Australia and in a number of other countries. In the United Kingdom, that country's Civil Aviation Authority has very successfully combined the two functions, although they were initially separated in two different agencies.

The United Kingdom decision to bring the functions into a Civil Aviation Authority was taken after a formal review, and on the basis that the setting of standards, regulatory control and the day-to-day operation of the airways system should be under single control in the interests of efficiency and effectiveness, because of the close inter-relationship involved.

A concern expressed from a number of quarters is that safety standards may become degraded if the body responsible for safety regulation is required to operate on a commercial basis and is therefore subject to cost pressures.
The commercial nature of the Authority needs to be clearly understood.

It will be the Government's requirement that the Authority adopt a business-like approach to its affairs, including the ongoing pursuit of cost efficiency and productivity improvement. The Authority will operate commercially in this sense.

However, it will not, because of the nature of its activities, be subject to the full range of pressures that apply to business enterprises operating in a free market situation. Whilst the legitimacy of the concern that safety considerations should not take second place to commercial aspects of the Authority's operations is accepted, the latter aspects should be kept in a proper perspective.

It also needs to be recognised that aviation safety is not solely dependent on regulation by Government authority. Australia's outstanding aviation safety record was not achieved, nor could it be maintained, by official fiat alone.

Departmental officers have made a splendid contribution to our aviation safety in the context of integrated safety and operational functions, and the Government is confident they will continue to do so in the new Authority. Their past contribution has been essential, but was not sufficient in itself.

Australia's airlines and other operators have made their own essential contribution to the safety record by their professionalism and concern for safety in air operations. This concern is deeply ingrained in our aviation industry and that situation would not be expected to change readily.

Nonetheless, the Government recognises the concern that various parties have voiced and has decided to adopt a number of measures in recognition of this. It is the Government's intention that the Australian Civil Aviation Authority will be required to give primacy to safety considerations over commercial ones.
The Bill reflects this intention and makes provision for the Minister to give broad directions in relation to the Authority's safety regulatory role to ensure that occurs.

As previously announced, the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation will remain in the Department of Transport and Communications, separate from the Civil Aviation Authority, and directly responsible to the Minister. This will ensure that the authority responsible for improving and enforcing safety standards will not be left to be the judge of its own performance. The Bureau's resources will be augmented to equip it to advise the Minister on safety trends and on any emerging issues on which the giving of directions to the Authority may be desirable.

The Bureau will not duplicate the safety regulatory functions of the Authority, but will have the role of independently assessing and advising the Minister on trends and significant broad issues relating to maintenance of appropriate safety standards.

As a direct measure to meet concern about commercial influences adversely impacting on safety regulation, it is the Government's intention that costs of standard setting and ensuring compliance with standards be funded from the budget and that the Authority perform these functions under contract. Finally, the legislative framework for safety regulation will remain under the control of the Minister.

It is considered that these various measures will provide adequate safeguards in relation to the concerns expressed about the possible adverse influence of commercial factors on the maintenance of our outstanding safety record. The function of aviation security also will remain with the Department of Transport and Communications. However, this Bill does provide for the Authority to participate in arrangements to prevent or deal with hijacking or other acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation.

Where appropriate, the Bill reflects the Government's announced guidelines in regard to legislation for statutory authorities. In broad terms these guidelines seek to provide a proper balance between the need to remove detailed controls over the operations of statutory authorities on the one hand, and accountability to the Government on the other. With this in mind the general thrust of this legislation is directed towards involving the Government in long term planning and strategic decisions of the Authority.

As previously mentioned, the operation of the Authority will be the responsibility of a nine member board which includes a Chairperson, Deputy Chairperson and the Chief Executive Officer of the Authority.

Staffing of the new Authority will involve transferring officers of the Department of Transport and Communications, who currently carry out tasks associated with the functions being transferred. These officers, about 7000 in number, will continue to be employed under the Public Service Act. Their terms and conditions of employment will therefore remain unchanged upon transfer.

The headquarters of the Authority will be located in Canberra. As a significant number of officers who will be transferring to the Authority are already employed at this location there would be major costs entailed in locating the headquarters elsewhere in Australia. This is not considered to be justified.

Turning to the broad question of financial arrangements which will apply to the Authority, the Bill provides that the Authority will be required to draw up a corporate plan for a three-year period, defining its objectives and identifying its strategies and policies to achieve these objectives.

The Authority will be required also to prepare a financial plan covering the same period. Both plans are to be submitted to the Minister. Provision is made in the Bill for the Minister to give directions to the Authority to vary certain parameters in the financial plan. In this event, the direction must be made public, in common with other directions given to the Authority under provisions of the Bill.

As already mentioned, costs of setting safety standards and ensuring compliance with those standards will be met from the budget. Costs of implementing the standards are to be met by the aviation industry through charges levied by the Authority. However, full recovery of implementation costs is to be phased in over a period of seven years, and during that period the shortfall in revenue will also be met from the budget. The Government will continue to meet the costs of search and rescue. So far as the airways system and the rescue and fire fighting service are concerned the Authority will be expected to fully recover associated costs from industry.
Provision is made in the Bill for the Authority to determine charges for its services, but proposals for such determinations will be subject to disapproval by the Minister within 60 days of receipt.

Provision has been made in the Bill for the transfer of assets to enable the Authority to perform its functions. A valuation for these will be determined, together with the loan and capital components, by the Government.

The Authority will be required to earn a reasonable return on its assets and to pay to the Commonwealth a reasonable dividend. It will be able to borrow to meet its capital requirements, if necessary with a Commonwealth guarantee.

Subject to certain safeguards, the Authority will be able to participate in partnerships and companies and will be given freedom to provide consultancy and management services, particularly to overseas aeronautical bodies seeking to use the expertise or services of the Authority.

The legislation provides for regulations to be made, consistent with this Bill. The existing Air Navigation Regulations will need to be divided into regulations under the Air Navigation Act, which has been amended to allow the transfer of functions to the new Authority, and into regulations under the Civil Aviation Bill. This is an interim step.

As previously announced, the Government has established a task force to review the legislative framework for safety regulations. The outcome of this review may well have implications for the regulations under the Air Navigation Act, and, more importantly, for the regulations under this Bill. Steps can then be taken to revise the regulations to the extent necessary. However, this important revision should not be allowed to delay the establishment of the Civil Aviation Authority.
Financial Impact Statement
There are no implications in the Bill for additional costs in the public sector. To the extent that greater efficiency is achieved, costs can be expected to reduce in real terms over time.

To the extent that the Authority funds its capital investment program from commercial borrowings rather than budget appropriations, the financial impact of the Bill will be to reduce Commonwealth budgetary outlays.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement, on behalf of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), relating to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, to move a motion that the Senate take note of the statement, and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

On 10 December 1987 in a statement to the House entitled `Foundations for the Future', I outlined the Government's proposals to establish the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). These proposals derived from the commitment by the Prime Minister to bring the various elements of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio into one statutory commission `so that there will be an absolutely firm legislative basis for expressing the total commitment of the Commonwealth and the people of Australia to the Aboriginal people'.

In my statement of 10 December, I stressed that the ATSIC proposal would not go ahead if it did not receive a positive endorsement from the Aboriginal and Islander community. In making this commitment it must be remembered the Government could have made the necessary changes to the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio without getting involved in this comprehensive process of consultation. As Minister I could have done this while sitting at my desk in Canberra. Instead I undertook to consult personally with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people prior to proceeding with the proposals.

Between 23 January and 10 March this year, the Secretary to my Department, Charles Perkins, and I attended 46 meetings throughout Australia involving an estimated 6,000 representatives of some 1,200 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations and groups. These meetings were preceded by 450 community meetings in 415 locations, to ensure that preliminary matters were worked through prior to my visits. Far from being a `whistle-stop tour', as some have suggested, the ATSIC consultations are the most wide reaching ever undertaken by a Minister in this portfolio.

Throughout these consultations I stressed at every meeting the proposed Commission would not go ahead if Aboriginal and Islander people did not want it. I also made it clear the proposal could be changed if need be. There were a few who doubted my word on this. Some said the Government had made up its mind and the community meetings amounted to `token consultations' only. Well, allow me to explain what has happened as a result of those community meetings.

Following the first round of consultations it became evident that there were a number of widely shared concerns regarding aspects of the Government's proposals, but that there was overwhelming support for the basic principles outlined in the foundation's booklet. Accordingly, a further document was prepared setting out a range of alternative options to those aspects which were of concern. This document was also widely circulated, and was the basis of the second stage of the consultation process. This second stage amounted to a series of follow-up meetings convened by departmental officers and Aboriginal liaison officers in all States, the ACT and the Northern Territory.
As a result, and in keeping with the commitment this Government has given to consultation, it is now proposed to vary the foundation's proposals in a number of significant areas.
Firstly let me deal with the key area of regional councils.

Virtually all consultation meetings called for an increase in the 28 regions originally proposed, mainly on the basis that those regions were too large. It is now proposed that there be around 56 regional council areas, subject to the finalisation of boundaries. These amended boundaries reflect Aboriginal and Torres Strait islander requests and recognise historical, cultural, linguistic and other important factors. Instead of regional councils comprising one representative from every Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander community and organisation within their regional area, it is now proposed that regional councils consist of 20 members, elected under a `one person, one vote' system. This overcomes concerns about inequities in representation. Regional councils will meet up to four times a year.
I now turn to the proposal to establish zone councils

Many consultation meetings expressed a view that a separate council at the zone level was unnecessary and could interfere in the relationship between regional councils and the Commission. It is therefore proposed that the planned zone councils be abandoned. In the absence of zone councils, a postal ballot of regional councillors in a particular zone will be held to elect commissioners.
A section of the foundations for the future proposal which created much discussion was the question of commissioners.

It was originally proposed that the Commission consist of 12 members, those members being an appointed full-time chairperson and 11 part-time commissioners (7 elected and 4 appointed by the Minister). There has since been a call for additional commissioners, especially in the larger States and those with large Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander populations, and for a greater proportion of elected commissioners. It is also accepted by the Government that the unique circumstances of central Australia require there to be a special zone (and therefore an elected commissioner) for that area. The Government now proposes a 15-member Commission, with an appointed full time chairperson and 14 part time commissioners. The chairperson and two commissioners will be appointed by the Minister. Twelve commissioners will be elected:
Western Australia, New South Wales and Queensland would each have 2 commissioners;
there would be a commissioner for a new central Australian zone covering parts of Western Australia, South Australia and the Northern Territory;
the remainder of South Australia and the Northern Territory, and Victoria and Tasmania would each have 1 commissioner; and
a Torres Strait Islander commissioner would be elected by the Torres Strait regional council.
Under these changes the fears people had that the Government-nominated commissioners would dominate the elected commissioners have now been eliminated.

Members of the House will recall that I visited the Torres Strait islands twice during January and February. I now inform the House of details of the proposal agreed to at the second meeting held on Thursday Island.

The interests of resident Torres Strait Islanders will be represented by the Torres Strait Islander commissioner, who will be elected by the Torres Strait regional council. There will also be an Office of Torres Strait Islander Affairs created within ATSIC, to ensure that Commission and other Government programs adequately address the needs of Torres Strait Islanders, including those living on the mainland. The Office will provide a secretariat to a Torres Strait Islander Advisory Board, consisting of 6 part time appointed members plus the elected part time Torres Strait Island commissioner, who will chair the board.

According to 1986 census figures, more than three-quarters of the Torres Strait Islander population live on mainland Australia, rather than in Torres Strait. There is a clear need to ensure that the interests of both groups are not overwhelmed by the interests of the much larger Aboriginal population, and that both Island residents and mainland Torres Strait Islanders do not feel that their interests are ignored. I believe the above proposal, plus the inclusion in the legislation of a provision ensuring that the Torres Strait regional council has direct access within the Budget process to the Minister, will satisfy Torres Strait Islander concerns and ensure that many of the complaints about their past treatment will be overcome. The issues that were raised during my first visit will be dealt with at another time.
An area that was initially the subject of some confusion and misunderstanding was the powers of the Minister.

There will be two categories of Commission functions. Firstly, those functions on which the Minister can make specific directions, and secondly, those functions on which the Commission will make final decisions, and about which the Minister may only make a general direction. This latter category is consistent with the degree of ministerial powers which currently apply to the Aboriginal Development Commission. It is now proposed to add land acquisition to this second category of functions, which will mean that ATSIC will have autonomous responsibility for all the powers and functions currently held by the ADC, plus those additional functions set out in the foundations statement.
Another issue which received some attention by Aboriginal groups during the course of my consultations was that of the preamble.

I am bound to say that the Government remains committed to a preamble which does no more than recite the facts which have led to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of this nation being the most disadvantaged socio-economic group within the Australian community. More importantly, the Government in no way resiles from its decision to recognise the fact of prior occupation and original ownership of the descendants of the people now known as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

There have, however, been some reservations voiced by Aboriginal people in relation to certain parts of the preamble. These reservations centre more on the way in which those facts have been expressed rather than with the facts themselves.
As a consequence the Government is prepared to give further consideration to the wording of the preamble in its drafting of the legislation.
I would now like to make some clarifying points regarding the establishment of the Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation.
Members would be aware that the AEDC is a commercial corporation charged with building a significant capital base for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

There has been some confusion relating to the dividend arrangements which will apply in respect of the AEDC. The legislation will provide for the Corporation to recommend an annual dividend to the Minister, who will accept or vary that recommendation after consultation with the Treasurer. The maximum dividend payable will be 50% of net profits, and there will be a dividend moratorium for the first three financial years' operation of the Corporation. The dividend provisions apply because the Corporation is essentially a commercial entity; they are consistent with the Government's policy guidelines on government business enterprises. The AEDC will be subject to normal corporate taxation requirements.
In relation to the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies I am continuing to consider a number of relatively minor adjustments to their operation. Final decisions have not been taken.
In the light of these changes to the foundations proposals, the essential features of the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission can now be summarised in the following terms:

The amalgamation at regional, State and central office levels of the two major Aboriginal Affairs portfolio bodies: the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission. Subsidiary bodies of the Commission will include Aboriginal Hostels Limited and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies;

The establishment of an all-Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, the overwhelming majority of whom are elected, with executive responsibilities across the whole spectrum of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs;
The establishment of around 56 incorporated regional councils throughout Australia, with statutory responsibility for setting priorities for ATSIC expenditure within their regions;
The establishment of a new Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation in addition to programs funded by existing enterprise loans and grants;

Specific attention to the interests of Torres Strait Islanders (both in the Torres Strait and on the mainland) through the provision of their own elected Commissioner, the creation of a Torres Strait Islander Advisory Board, and the establishment of an Office of Torres Strait Islander Affairs within ATSIC.

In a very real sense, these changes represent a complete overhaul of the existing relationship between the Federal Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. No longer will they be held at arm's length from Government under the guise of `advisory' bodies and the like. No longer will the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people be excluded from the executive decision-making processes of government. No longer will the priorities for expenditure be determined by appointed commissioners or bureaucrats in Canberra without reference to the views of Aboriginal and Islander communities, be they in the bush, or more isolated regions of Australia, our rural towns, or our State capitals.

It is precisely because these changes to the structure of the Aboriginal portfolio are far-reaching, that I have been at pains to involve all Aboriginal communities and organisations in developing them. Their participation was crucial in making these changes. Many of the key concepts in the original foundations statement can be traced to the Coombs and O'Donoghue reports, both of which were based on direct consultations with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I repeat, my own consultations involved the most sustained and extensive round of meetings with the Aboriginal and Islander community ever undertaken personally by a Government Minister.
The process as a whole far exceeds all the consultations ever undertaken in respect of any previous Federal or State legislation dealing with matters affecting Aboriginal people.
This is how things should be. And this is how I will continue to approach matters with such far-reaching and sensitive implications.

One matter consistently raised by Aboriginal and Islander people has been the announced commencement date of July 1 1988. I inform the House that the establishment of the Commission will be 1 January 1989. This will allow legislation to be drafted, enable me further consultation on specific details which may arise during the drafting process and ensure that the necessary time required to conduct the elections will be available. The Bill will be introduced early in the Budget sittings.

To enable the Commission to commence operations on 1 January, it will be necessary to hold elections for regional councillors, and subsequently, for commissioners, before the end of this year. It is proposed these elections, which will be supervised by the Australian Electoral Commission, be held in October, November, and December.

In conclusion, I wish to thank the Aboriginal and Islander communities for their willingness to consider and debate these issues, and for the welcome and hospitality afforded me everywhere I travelled. I would also make the point that the consultations gave me an opportunity to hear first hand the communities' views on a range of other issues. This was an additional advantage of the meetings.

Other people I would like to thank include the Secretary to my Department, Charles Perkins, for his loyal and sustained support during this arduous process, Lois O'Donoghue, chairperson of Aboriginal Hostels Limited for her general support and assistance at meetings, Department of Aboriginal Affairs officers at central, State and regional level for their excellent work throughout the consultations, the members of the ATSIC task force for their important contribution to the process and my own staff for their dedicated and unflagging support. I would also like to thank the parliamentary members of my own Party who assisted in the consultation process.

As I pointed out in my previous statement to this House, these proposals lay the foundation upon which real progress and achievement for Australia's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people can be built.
Aboriginal people, by their responses to the Government's proposals, have demonstrated their willingness to build on these foundations.
It is now the Parliament's turn, as the representative of the Australian people, to face the challenge and indicate its willingness to meet Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people halfway.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This statement reports to the Parliament on the progress that the Government has made or has not made in establishing an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. This is one of those rare occasions on which the Opposition, as I am doing at this moment, welcomes the fact that the Government has made less progress in this matter than it had indicated it would. The Government, when it made the announcement on 10 December last year that it intended to establish this Commission, indicated that it hoped to have it established by 1 July of the current calendar year. The statement of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) confirms what a number of us have long suspected; namely, that the Government is not now proposing to meet that timetable and that it now thinks that the Commission might be put in place by 1 January next year.

SPEECH.PARA: I regard that period of delay as good news, as being in the interests of not only Aboriginal Australians but all Australians, because it provides for an opportunity for some further consideration to be given to what the Government is doing and, hopefully, will ensure that a better outcome is achieved than would otherwise be the case.

Just for the record, I would like to recall for the Senate that on 15 April, during the first week of my return to Canberra for the current period of sitting, having spent some days in the Kimberley region of Western Australia-a good deal of that time was taken up in talking with Aboriginal communities in that area-I gave notice of the following motion:
That the Senate calls upon the Federal Government to delay the introduction of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission because of:

(a) the short period which has been allowed for consultation with the Aboriginal and Islander communities, and the resultant failure of the Government to ensure that there is real understanding of the major changes proposed; and
(b) the doubts which exist that the revised arrangements will ensure more effective delivery of programs for Aboriginal and Islander advancement.

There is, I think, impliedly in the Minister's statement an acceptance of the first point in my notice of motion. But there is nothing in the Minister's statement which indicates an attitude on his part or on the part of the Government to the concerns which I have expressed in that notice of motion and elsewhere that the revised arrangements, like the current arrangements, will not assure effective delivery of programs for Aboriginal and Islander advancement.

I note the Minister's comments in the statement about the fact that he has attended 46 meetings, involving an estimated 6,000 representatives of some 1,200 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations and groups. The Minister makes claims to this being the most extensive consultation which has been undertaken by a Government Minister. I do not have the statistics to challenge that, but I would say that I do not believe that the Minister set himself an achievable task in trying to do the sort of consultation which he described back in December 1987 in the time which he allowed.

The unfortunate fact of the matter is that there has been a real change of direction by this Government in terms of its approach to Aboriginal affairs over the last year or so-over the period that Mr Hand has been the Minister. I do not believe it is realistic to expect the Aboriginal community or, indeed, the wider community to absorb those changes in the time permitted. Perhaps I should quickly explain that. I think it would be fresh in the memory of most honourable senators-certainly those who have taken an interest in Aboriginal affairs-that the previous Minister, Mr Holding, for most of his ministry placed enormous emphasis on the idea of national land rights. That was really a focus for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) for the bulk of the period of the Labor Government.

It was always my view that that was a particularly stupid thing to do because it was never likely that the Government would deliver on that promise. But, in fact, that promise effectively distracted the Government from the more practical problems which it faced in Aboriginal affairs and was a contributing factor to the generally negative attitude which now obtains in the Australian community towards programs of Aboriginal advancement. I very much regret that negative attitude. Some speakers in this debate may dispute the fact that it is there, but it is my own experience that in the metropolitan, country and remoter parts of Australia there is a quite considerable disillusionment with what the Government is doing and there is a rather bad reaction, often against the Aboriginal people themselves, because of the disappointment which is felt by so many people, principally because of the failures of the Government and Government programs.

My own experience of consultation over recent times is, of necessity, much more limited than that of the Minister and more limited than that of some other members of this place. Senator Tambling from the Northern Territory will be speaking and Senator Collins from the Northern Territory is in the chamber. I would defer to both of them in terms of the opportunities that they have for communication with the Aboriginal community. But I would say that the overwhelming impression that I got from visiting a number of Aboriginal communities in the northern part of Western Australia was that whilst in many of those communities there was considerable support for change, and that support flowed from the considerable dissatisfaction in Aboriginal communities with the way things are working at present, there was at the same time a real confusion about just how the Government's proposals might work and what the direct implications for the communities were.

There was a welcoming in the limited number of communities that I visited of the broad idea that they might have greater control over the programs which so closely affect their lives, but a complete lack of any detailed knowledge of how that would in fact work in practice. I can only say that, given the relatively short time that this idea has been abroad, I do not believe that one could, with the best will in the world on the part of the Minister or the Department, have expected anything more.

The other thing which is very important and which I would ask the Government to consider is the extent to which this process of consultation should be extended beyond the Aboriginal community. It is my view and the view of a very wide cross-section of people from all parts of the political spectrum with a close interest in Aboriginal affairs that there is a very great lack of success in Aboriginal affairs. An important element in that lack of success is the loss of sympathy within the general community for what governments and Aboriginal individuals and communities are trying to achieve. I believe that the consultation process ought to be extended to a much greater degree of consultation with the general community.
