The most disturbing thing I found on my recent visit to the Kimberley was not that there was any lack of interest in Aboriginal affairs-quite the reverse: there was an intensity of interest, which was almost disturbing, both from people who were very hostile and critical of government, and in some cases, Aboriginals themselves, and among people who are deeply sympathetic to the plight of Aboriginals and seek to help. There seemed to be an almost obsessive interest and concern. It was impossible to escape the subject. Quite frankly, I think it is a matter which should concern the Government that in some parts of Australia we have achieved a degree of tension about this issue which is very destructive.

I make that point because I believe it ought to influence the Government in the way that it approaches this quite radical change to the way Aboriginal affairs are dealt with. It is dealing with change when there is very widespread hostility in the general community to what is perceived to be the failure of what is being done at present and the extraordinary degree of waste which is involved-the ineffectiveness of many programs and the failure to develop any sensible way of administering programs so that they will be more successful and so that those who are involved in their administration are more accountable.

I do not put those matters forward on the basis that there is some wonderful, simple answer to them and I do not suggest that the problems have occurred only because of the administration of Minister Hand. I suggest that these things have a much longer history than that. But Mr Hand cannot escape the fact that he is the current Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and he is the one responsible for coming to grips with the situation as it is today. I do not believe that in this debate, on what is essentially a statement about the mechanics of what the Government is trying to do, it is appropriate for me to go back, as I have in other debates, on some of the reasons why I think we have got ourselves into this very difficult situation. Honourable senators will recall that I am very prepared to be highly critical of the Australian Labor Party and its history of dealing with Aboriginal matters over the last 15 years-the excessive raising of expectations, the subsequent disappointment of those expectations, the encouragement of a white backlash because of that raising of expectations, the raising of the levels of Aboriginal demand, and so on. I mention that in passing because, again, that is part of the context in which this enormous change in Aboriginal affairs is being proposed. I believe that the Government, unless it is completely lunatic and is closing its eyes to reality, has to examine both the successes and the failures of the past and try to do what it is doing now in a much more gradual and careful way. Quite frankly, it has to stop following a political agenda in this.

One cannot escape the feeling that from the time the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made his unfortunate visit to the Northern Territory last year when, seemingly out of the blue, he reawakened talk of a treaty after the thing had been left lying quietly doggo for years without any real government attention, with the pending bicentennial celebrations and the threat of Aboriginal disturbance of some of those celebrations, the Government is following, essentially, a timetable which is dictated by political considerations rather than by programmed considerations and by considerations of what can be done in a practical sense to improve the delivery of programs for and by Aboriginal Australians. I hope that the statement which we are debating today, this statement which pushes things back to next year and which contains the promise of further consultation, indicates a shift in the Government's approach away from the political agenda towards a more practical policy oriented agenda.

I simply want to stress, as my contribution to this debate, that I believe there is a need for real caution on the part of the Government and a need for it to get it right on this occasion. If the Government fails to get it right, if it simply achieves a temporary level of satisfaction among both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians, because it is effecting change to a situation with which people are genuinely dissatisfied but without making sure that it puts things in place which work on the ground in a practical sense, we are simply commencing the next chapter of discontent. Quite frankly, in my assessment that is what we are in the process of doing.

I stress again what seems to me to be very obvious-namely, the widespread community concern at the failure of too many programs and the need, therefore, to address those failures in a practical way. It is worth making the point that the failures of programs and the discontent which is being expressed cannot be sheeted home to a shortage of money. I am sure that both Senator Tambling and Senator Collins could produce some quite drastic stories about areas of physical or material need. They could point to communities which do not have good water supplies and proper facilities of various sorts. But the truth is that the level of discontent has been growing during a period in which the Government has been vastly expanding expenditure. Whatever the Government might have done in terms of breaking its promises on national land rights and whatever, the Labor Government has expanded very considerably the amount of expenditure in Aboriginal affairs. Quite clearly, expenditure which is perceived to be unwise, wasteful or ineffective does nothing but increase the level of problems that we have.

I believe that the central problem that has to be tackled in looking at this question of the proposed Commission is whether it will contribute to having a coherent and accountable administrative structure on the ground. That is an easy point to make. The question is: how do we deal with it and assess it? I suppose the Minister and the Government can claim that, in establishing this Commission, they are at least trying to reduce the multiplicity of bodies which interact with Aboriginal communities. That in itself may add to the possibility of coherent and more accountable administration, but I do not think that that will make a very substantial contribution. For example, the absorption of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies is totally irrelevant and is of doubtful value. Again, I have some question marks about the absorption of the housing and hostels function with other broader administrative functions and policy functions, for the simple reason that, in the case of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd, there was some value gained in having a manageable assignment which could be undertaken, defined and delivered quite satisfactorily in many cases. The absorption of that into a larger structure may not contribute in any serious way.

What the proposed Commission does not seem to come to grips with is the fundamental problem of what is happening on the ground in communities around Australia. Circumstances differ from State to State, State to Territory and so on, but it seems to me that there are certain common patterns. The first is that in most of Australia it seems that a serious mistake has been made. I am now talking about relatively isolated or self-contained Aboriginal communities. The Government has erred in imposing excessive responsibility for basic services on the community. By that I mean that the orderly delivery of basic services-power, water and so on-is seen too often as a function of self-management, of encouraging Aboriginal people to be responsible for their own lives, often to the detriment of giving Aboriginal people ade- quate facilities in those areas and a greater capacity to assume responsibility for their own lives in the same way as other Australians are required to do. The people who live in my middle class suburb in Perth are not required to be directly responsible for the provision of basic services for themselves. There are paid employees of the local authority who do that to the general satisfaction of the populace who are then left to go on with their own lives. I believe that in many cases there is insufficient regard for the need to have an orderly administration of basic services to provide a framework within which personal responsibility and individual lives can be conducted. As a result, one gets communities in which there are breakdowns of things which are simply taken for granted by other Australians.

I hope that honourable senators from the Northern Territory, in contributing to this debate, might have something to say about the extent to which the local government model which is used in that territory has in fact been a success in providing some more accountable structure. I must say that I found it depressing, in visiting communities in Western Australia over that pre-Easter week, to see to what extent there are simply not the sort of administrative structures in place which guarantee the orderly provision of services. For those communities which are fringe dwellers-and I cite, for example, the community at the settlement known as Red Hill outside Halls Creek-one finds an appalling lack of basic services because fundamentally there is no-one who is responsible. Quite frankly, I do not see the putting in place of this Commission as in any significant way contributing to the alleviation of difficulties that are being experienced in communities such as Red Hill. It seems to me far more likely that one would get some sense into the administration of a place such as that if there were a far greater attempt made to involve the local authority of that area. I stress that that area is one in which there is a very substantial Aboriginal majority in the population. If the local authority were more closely involved in the administration of that settlement in terms of the basic services which are provided-and I am not suggesting that the local authority should do that without reward or without some rating capacity or things of that sort-I believe there would be much more prospect of seeing the people who live there having a reasonable chance to make social progress through the education of children and so on than we have with what I would describe as the present shambles which I saw when I visited there just a few weeks ago.

It seems to me that DAA has always had a fundamental problem in coming to grips with circumstances in which there is really very little or no direct DAA authority to use. The only authority that DAA has, and the only authority which this new Commission will really have, is the extent to which it is paying the piper. Since it is quite clear that the funding for Aboriginal people will not, in a majority sense, be coming through this Commission, I would express very great reservations about the capacity of the Commission to achieve more orderly progress for Aboriginal people than is currently being achieved by DAA and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC).

I think that there has to be a far more fundamental rethink about the whole relationship between Aboriginal programs and, for example, local government in Australia and, indeed, the State government departments which deliver basic services to other Australians than there is any sign of flowing through this reorganisation of DAA and the ADC which is the subject of the Minister's statement today and which was the subject of his statement in December.

I would offer support to the Government to the extent that it is encouraging Aboriginal people to assume responsibility for their own lives and providing programs which genuinely enable them to do it. However, I would be highly critical of the Government to the extent that it simply engages in reorganisation for the sake of being seen to do something and where the Government simply does not face up to some of the obvious defects which exist at present, particularly defects in terms of the accountability of those who serve many Aboriginal communities. I mention in passing the obvious problems in the Northern Territory in terms of the potential for conflict between the jurisdiction of land councils and the jurisdiction of community councils, a matter which probably needs legislative attention in terms of looking at what powers the land councils possess, as an example of some of the sorts of fundamental areas which need to be addressed. I think it is a pity that in our bicentennial year we are likely to have only one debate in this autumn sitting of Parliament on the subject of Aboriginal affairs, and that that debate essentially is on the mechanics of the reorganisation of the Government's administration in this way.

I suspect that all of this is a long way short of really coming to grips with the on the ground problems of Aboriginal Australians which are very obvious to anyone who visits Aboriginal communities at any frequency at all. I would therefore say to the Government, in making some comment on this statement, that I believe that it ought to put before us not a statement in the sorts of terms put down by the Minister today, but a statement which tries to come to grips in a far more practical way with the real situation of Aboriginal people and tries to build from the ground up in terms of giving Aboriginal people, yes, control over their own lives-accountable structures which they can control in a political sense but which are made accountable to taxpayers as well as to the community who control them in a political sense. I believe that if we start to come to grips with some of those basic problems we will go a lot further than if we build grand new commissions which I think will simply reproduce the mistakes of the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the statement by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). The reason I do so is that it is precisely what my constituents want. I can in fact speak with any kind of authority only about the situation in the Northern Territory. I was involved in the consultation process which took place with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) in relation to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). There is no question at all that the predominant message that was delivered in various forms and shades of strength from Alice Springs to the Top End was that most Aboriginal people did not want ATSIC to start on 1 July. It is also true to say that there was certainly an apprehension, reflected in the correspondence received by me and, I know, by others, that that predominant wish would be ignored. I must say in relation to that matter that I am very pleased indeed that the Minister made a statement today saying that the commencement date of 1 July had been put back to 1 January next year. I know that my constituents will be extremely pleased about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Not surprisingly, there was an enormous degree of interest within Aboriginal communities in the proposals in the document Foundations for the Future. It is true to say in respect of the statement delivered by the Minister today that there have been a number of quite substantial changes made to what was proposed in that original document. That has come about directly through the willingness of the Minister to listen to and respond positively to representations that he received from Aboriginal communities. I will list the major concerns of Aboriginal communities in order of what I think was their priority. The No. 1 concern was the starting date for ATSIC. The No. 2 concern was their dissatisfaction with the boundaries as they were originally drawn and, therefore, the number of regional councils, predominantly of course through people in one particular cultural and language group being lumped in with people who did not share that language or particular culture. There was concern about the proposals for the way in which those regional councils would be constituted and with the concept of zone councils. That is something I want to say a few things about because of the feelings in the Aboriginal communities that prompted concern about zone councils, which the Minister has announced will be removed. I found out from the Minister that the concerns expressed in the Northern Territory in respect of zone councils were, in fact, simply reflecting a feeling that was Australia-wide.

The boundaries problem has been largely addressed in that the original 28 regions have now been expanded to around 56 regions. I understand that that figure is still flexible, although I think that the final result will be somewhere around that figure. The councils will now be constituted by election, which should also remove the majority of concerns about the non-representative nature of the original proposals. The formation of zone councils was strongly resisted. It is interesting to reflect on why the proposal for the formation of zone councils prompted the response in Aboriginal communities that it did. That response interested me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Experience with land councils perhaps?

—I think it is true to say that it was experience with bureaucracy generally. Whether land council bureaucracy or Public Service bureaucracy, I think it is fair to say-and I must say I was stimulated personally by the community response to the zone councils-that Aboriginal people have had a gutful of bureaucracy. They saw the zone councils simply as being a further unnecessary structure that was going to stand between their communities and the funding body, the Federal Government. The Minister has responded positively to those concerns, and the zone councils have been removed.

SPEECH.PARA: Another concern that at least some of my constituents had, and I shared that concern, was that we have in the Northern Territory a unique system of Aboriginal local government. It is the most flexible system of local government for Aboriginal communities that exists in Australia and it was introduced by the Northern Territory Government, to its credit. I was a member of the Northern Territory Parliament when it was introduced. It provides-and this is the fundamental manner in which it is flexible-for the individual scheme of each Aboriginal community to be tabled in Parliament, not as part of the principal Act, but as a schedule to the Act, as each scheme is uniquely tailored to the unique needs of each community. In the case of some communities the negotiations over the kind of scheme that they wanted for their own local government have gone on for years. The scheme provides for an almost open-ended manner of accommodating the Aboriginal relationship system, the moiety system and the skin group system, and local conditions in the community. Many of them have uniquely different systems of electing their councils in terms of how they are constituted with representatives from each skin group in the community. I think it is fair to say that despite the concerns that a great many people have had about the introduction of this scheme-concerns, I might add, within the ranks of the Country Liberal Party in the Parliament itself and outside it-the scheme has worked very well.

Again to its credit, the Northern Territory Government has set up a local government association particularly to represent these small communities. The opposition to that from within the ranks of the Government became public. A number of Ministers were unhappy about setting up a separate Aboriginal local government association when a local government association representing the major urban communities of the Northern Territory already existed. The fear that Aboriginal communities had-and it was shared by the Government-was quite simply that because this form of local government was new to communities they would be dominated and overwhelmed, as I think they would have been, by the Darwin, Katherine, Tennant Creek and Alice Springs councils. To the credit of the then Minister for Community Development in the Northern Territory, he stuck to his guns and introduced a separate fully Aboriginal association to represent those small councils. The scheme now operates in something like 25 or 26 communities and is expanding at a slow and steady rate, again to the credit of the Northern Territory Government. I stress `slow and steady'.

The reason I am dwelling on the Northern Territory scheme is that I have looked very carefully at all of the local government schemes that operate around Australia, and there is no question that the Territory scheme is unique in the degree of flexibility it offers Aboriginal communities. I am not suggesting that is a criticism of other States in Australia. I think it is simply a reflection of the unique demographic nature of the Territory's population. Twenty-five per cent of our total community is Aboriginal, and 80 per cent or more of our rural community is Aboriginal, so we are in a position where we can put such a unique scheme into operation.

There was a great deal of concern by Aboriginal communities that operate under this scheme that ATSIC would in some way intrude on the relationship which they had with their funding body, the Northern Territory Department of Community Development. I am pleased to say that the Northern Territory Minister for Local Government has given a categorical assurance that that is not so, and that the arrangements that are currently in place for funding from the Federal Government to the Northern Territory Government will continue unimpeded. Indeed, in the Northern Territory now around 80 per cent of the global funding to Aboriginal communities comes through agencies of the Northern Territory Government.

Two very positive things about ATSIC as far as communities are concerned-Senator Chaney has, I think, canvassed both of them-is that, firstly, Aboriginal people were very supportive and positive about an arrangement that would give them a decision making role in setting priorities for spending; and secondly, they were very enthusiastic about combining principally the roles of the current Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). I think it is true to say that, so far as people in the bush were concerned, the question of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies and Aboriginal Hostels did not rate very highly in their concerns. But they were very supportive of the proposal to incorporate the ADC and the DAA, for obvious reasons. But-I put this caveat on it-the principal reason for that, in my view, is that there is an expectation in Aboriginal communities, which I profoundly hope will be realised, that this combination of the ADC and the DAA will result in a better delivery of services to the community. That combination of these two organisations is the source of the support.

The true test of ATSIC will come in the delivery of services to Aboriginal communities. That is not my expectation; that is the overwhelming expectation of the Aboriginal people who have been involved in this consultative process. If ATSIC succeeds in getting more Aboriginal people into houses and reducing the number of Aboriginal people going to their graves and into hospitals, it will have been a success. If it does not achieve that, it will be seen by the Aboriginal community of the Northern Territory as having been a failure. I hope, along with the Government and the Minister, that the initiatives that have been taken by this Government in establishing this body, in the hiatus that existed after the disbandment of the National Aboriginal Conference, are realised.

The consultative process has been a highly productive one and has not been a waste of time. I can honestly say, having been part of the process, that most of the suggestions that have resulted in the changes reflected in the Minister's statement today have come directly as a result of the community discussions that have occurred, not, I might add, at the time we visited the communities but subsequent to those visits. Again, that is reflected in the number of requests I got for follow-up visits and the amount of correspondence I received making suggestions.

The second round of the consultative process is almost finished. It is the Government's intention now to examine all of the results of that second round of negotiations and to draft them into an acceptable form for further consultation. The Minister has given undertakings that he personally will go back to a number of communities at least. I know that officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs are keeping up a constant round of negotiations and consultations at grassroots level to make sure that the final form of the ATSIC legislation which appears in this Parliament is the best possible result to give a start to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. I said, I think in the first speech that I delivered in the Senate, when the subject of Aboriginal deaths in custody was being discussed, that my major concern for many years has been, and remains, the number of premature Aboriginal deaths out of custody.

I repeat, in conclusion, the point that I made just a few moments earlier, because I believe it is the fundamental point in the establishment of this organisation. There is an expectation in the Aboriginal community of the Northern Territory-and it is not an unreasonable expectation-that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission will result in a fundamentally better and more efficient delivery of services to Aboriginal people on the ground. Probably that will not be able to be tested for at least a year after 1 January 1989-and perhaps not even then. But I have no doubt at all, considering the positive responses that have been made so far by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to the representations he has received from communities-and I must say that he has positively responded to almost every suggestion that has been brought to my attention-that that consultative process will now continue for the balance of this year and we will end up with a piece of legislation, toward the end of 1988, that will be worthy of support from every member of this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather unique that when we have been debating issues relating to the Aboriginal portfolio in recent months there has been a degree of bipartisanship between the parties and the personalities in this place. We are all seeking an objective that will ensure that in future the foundations certainly will be well laid, if I may plagiarise the title of the statement Foundations for the Future, put out by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) in December. The Minister, in effect, has presented us today with a progress report on the stages he is proposing on behalf of the Labor Government to implement an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission basically to administer all of the Aboriginal affairs portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly agree with Senator Chaney and Senator Collins that in the past few months the Minister has been hard at work in a very elaborate, detailed and genuine consultative process around the community. I do not believe that that consultative process is yet complete. I will take a bit of time this evening to outline a number of areas where additional consultation is necessary. In particular, there are a number of issues that I do not believe even the Minister's statement today adequately or properly addresses-the very fundamental principles that must be outlined fully when the legislation comes before this House at some future date. But I do accept that the Government has embarked on a very meaningful consultation process. From my experience, and that of Senator Collins, in the Northern Territory we can certainly appreciate the efforts of the Minister and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

As the statement is a progress report, a number of issues still need to be properly addressed. The Minister distributed the booklet Foundations for the Future very widely. Also, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs distributed a video to many Aboriginal communities that enabled them to have a better understanding. At the same time, the Aboriginal Development Commission presented a different and alternative view to those very same communities and Aboriginal organisations throughout Australia. So there was not a unanimous view among the agencies of the Government. I commend a lot of the activity and criticism that was contained in the proposals put forward by the Aboriginal Development Commission. They were developed by senior officers of that Commission, they were fully approved by the Board and they very much involved Aboriginal organisations throughout Australia that have a present relationship with the Aboriginal Development Commission.

It is a very sad point that in the Minister's statement today he does not make one acknowledgment of the Aboriginal Development Commission. He does not even mention it, yet its contribution to this consultative process is unique. It has been very special and contributory and, in a lot of instances, it has been very critical. It is possibly one of the main factors why we are now seeing a stalling on the date for the commencement of the proposed new Commission. The consultation process has in many areas so far, because of the way in which Aboriginal communities respond, still been of too short a time span and too narrow in really gauging the proper new systems that many of the traditional Aboriginal communities would want to see in place.

We have to be reminded that over the last year or so Mr Hawke and the Labor Government have really put forward three specific announcements, all of which have been delayed. There was the proposal for a treaty, the proposal for the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody and this proposal for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. All were delayed in their implementation from the time of the original announcements. I question whether the 1 January date that is now proposed is a feasible date, given the nature of the aspects that now have to be addressed in this issue. The principles that are important to the entire Australian community, and in particular to the Aboriginal and traditional Aboriginal communities, will require, as the Minister says on page 2 of his statement, `a series of follow-up meetings'. If there is any indication from the thousands of meetings that have been conducted, we really have to ensure that that is going on.

The original document, Foundations for the Future, was quite comprehensive. It certainly covered many points relating to the preamble and the proposals put forward by the Government. In recent months, the Minister has distributed, around the other areas, a further document. In it many more alternative options are floated. I am not in any way denigrating Aboriginal communities when I say that this complex area of study, in many instances, tends to confuse and compound the problems that they must come to in dealing with the paperwork, the options and the alternatives being presented to them. Many of us in this place are very familiar with reports that have complex recommendations, minority views and counterviews. The process of political decision-making is one we are part of. But in Aboriginal communities there is a very difficult style and process for that decision making to take place.

When the Minister proposed a date of 1 July 1988 he gave himself an unachievable timetable to have an acceptance of views and opinions-and not necessarily an acceptance but the ability to arrive at decisions which would necessarily result in the best option to ensure that future Aboriginal administrative programs were properly carried out. But there are still a number of issues which have not yet been properly addressed. The Minister's statement today does not cover such areas as the costs of amalgamating the present Aboriginal Development Commission, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Institute of Aboriginal Studies and the education functions of the Department of Education. It will require a very complex marriage and in going into that marriage considerable costs must be passed on. They must be known, be made public and be properly scrutinised and available.

The Minister is now proposing, as part of his changed options, to look at the regional system and to go from 28 regions to 56. Whilst he is abandoning the proposals for superimposed zones across the top of those, that administrative requirement to run 56 regions will entail a very complex management and financial arrangement. We have not yet been given any details of or indications as to how that will happen. I believe that that is equally important to the Aboriginal community and to the broad general community. I certainly accept that Minister's view of the change in the way in which representation will arise on the regional councils, at least to moving to a fairer and much more equitable voting system for representation. The previous system, of course, was ghastly.

I am concerned that the proposals to change the regional councils still run contrary to traditional State boundaries in Australia. I would not like to see the Hand proposals amount to a new Whitlam regionalisation system of government, albeit relating to Aboriginal matters. There is no way that the Constitutions of the Commonwealth and the States will be changed, and local government is still a matter for State administrations. If these regional councils, as they properly should in many places, are to take on the local government type functions, they must properly recognise that traditional constitutional arrangements must be set in place.

The costs of the new expanded Commission and, as I have said, those relating to the many more regional areas need to be identified, quantified and discussed with the consumers, that is, the Aboriginal communities, and with the parliamentary interests. I also do not believe that the Minister has adequately addressed the differences around Australia between traditional Aboriginal communities-those, as I have previously described here, that are still ceremoniously and ritually connected to their communities-and the many other Aboriginal communities in Australia that have a much more urbanised lifestyle, where the traditional cultures no longer prevail but where, of course, there is still Aboriginal identification. I think the Minister should give us some inkling of how these principles are to be incorporated. I do not believe that the management structures that he has proposed adequately address this area.

Similarly, matters relating to land, land acquisition and compensation need to be elaborated in much more detail. Whilst, arguably, these will be presented to us when the legislation is introduced, I am a little concerned whether the program put when we consider the Bills presented for debate and discussion will properly address issues of land, land reform, land acquisition, dispossession and compensation, matters that have all been covered previously in various statements. These matters certainly need to be put out on the table now in much more detail with access guaranteed for all sectors of the community, without creating backlash, racial confusion or dissension, which can so easily arise in this area.

I am very concerned-and I know that submissions have been put to the Minister about this-about problems that could be created in relation to the proposed preamble outlined in Foundations for the Future, concerning the very complex legal arrangements relating to antecedent native title. By including this in legislation we could be creating precedents that may haunt us for centuries in Australia. We know that there are legal opinions floating around in the Government but they have not yet been outlined.

During the Estimates Committee hearings dealing with the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of Administrative Services and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Opposition asked questions about these legal opinions that had been given to the Attorney-General and made available to other Government Ministers with regard to the principles and the precedents that could be created with regard to antecedent native title. We certainly have to check out what the implications in this area will be. I would like answers to the following questions: What does the preamble purport to do? That must be spelt out in clear, precise terms. Further, what will be the effects on mining and industry? Are the proprietary rights of individuals or the Crown in relation to the rights of the States or a Territory affected and, if so, how? What are the constitutional ramifications? Will this improve the position of Aborigines or is the whole exercise merely a political exercise on the part of the Federal Government?

The preamble that is proposed is innovative. It is something that has not been put into legislation before. Therefore, consequences pertaining to land administration will flow through to the High Court, and that will create very dangerous precedents. The Minister has not yet been forthcoming. I hope that during the coming months and before the legislation is prepared he will make further statements relating specifically to these areas. If he does not do that, the underpinning areas of Australian industry, agriculture, and mining-and in fact the very lifestyle of millions of Australians-will be affected. We will be formulating legislation that does not properly take into account these implications for the future.

Senator Chaney and Senator Collins both referred specifically to local government and the forms that must flow from that. Certainly, the model which is currently being used and which is part of the law of the Northern Territory can stand up and it is widely accepted by the Aboriginal community as being a very desirable form of local government. I hope that these proposals for Torres Strait and others relating to the States of Australia will be looked at very carefully by the advisers, the councils and the organisations in Aboriginal communities that are considering these matters.

The proposed legislative timetable worries me considerably. The Minister has said on page 11 of his statement that he hoped that the Commission would commence operations on 1 January and that a series of elections, supervised by the Australian Electoral Commission, would be held in October, November and December. For those elections to take place in October the legislation would have to be passed in September. As it cannot be introduced in this place before 22 August, that puts it within a very tight timeframe for both this Parliament and also the Aboriginal communities.

Whilst there has been criticism about the timetable for the present consultative process, once the legislation has been introduced it is our responsibility particularly to take it back to the Aboriginal communities. Last week at the Estimates Committee hearing Mrs McPherson, the Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission, made a couple of very specific remarks which I shall read to the Senate. In response to a question that I asked about the representations that she was receiving, she said:

The majority of the responses that we have received have indicated that people would like more time to be made fully aware of the Government's option and for more time to put up any other options that they would like included in the proposal.
In reply to a further question that I asked, she said:
They are indicating that they would like to have time to review the draft legislation. At this stage they are being given no indication that they will be able to view that before it is presented.

I think that is a vital and very perceptive comment by Mrs McPherson. If the Labor Government thinks it can bring in legislation here on 22 August, on our first day up the hill, ram it through in a couple of weeks and hope to have it in place by the end of September, in order to proceed with the first elections in October, it is fooling itself, and it would be doing a disservice to the whole of the Australian community. This relates particularly to the Aborigines of Australia who must live under the consequences of this legislation-which they are so keen to carefully look at. One should also bear in mind that other alternative proposals are being floated. The Aboriginal Development Commission distributed last week a discussion paper entitled An Alternative strategy for Aboriginal self management. It is a complex document and is probably just as comprehensive as Mr Hand's Foundations for the Future. It looks at a practical alternative.

It must be remembered that the Aboriginal Development Commission has handled the commerce and enterprise functions. We need to be careful not to gobble up the education, health and welfare functions that are so vital to Aboriginal communities and couple them for convenience with the enterprise, commerce and economic types of functions. We should be careful not to stick them all under one umbrella, where it would be so easy for the Government to say, `Here is your $700m a year budget; you now determine all the priorities and expenditure and divide it up'. If that proves to be the case, the Government will be merely taking away the odium from decent, strong political decisions that often have to be taken. I have no objection to full Aboriginal participation and consultation in the process that vitally affects Aborigines, but I do not want to see this Parliament impose structures, commissions or a system which are inadequate and which do not lead to overall acceptance by Aboriginal people throughout Australia.

The postponement of the commencement date is all that one can read from Minister Hand's statement today. If one looks at the detail of the statement, one sees that the only other proposal that contains any meat is the tentative arrangement for elections. The details need to be spelt out. Let us be honest: because the Aboriginals of Australia were certainly the original occupants of this country, and because of the emotionalism that surrounds this issue in the community, this is probably one of the most crucial and important pieces of constitutional legislation. Let us not walk away from that because the manner, style and language used in all the proposals by the Minister fit all those debates. It is not a piece of legislation that can be shoved through Parliament in a couple of weeks with late night sittings and limited debate. If honourable senators think that the debate on the recent conservation and environment issues in this place was important-and we took 16 hours to discuss them-I put the Government on notice to allow now for 30 or 40 hours debate for this piece of legislation. If it is not dealt with in that manner, we will not honour our obligations to all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the statement by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) and I am pleased with a number of aspects of it. I commend the Minister and the Government for a number of the matters that it contains, especially for the flexibility and sensitivity displayed by the Government in its consultations with the Aboriginal people. One of the disturbing things, however, is that the Minister says that the consultations are `the most wide reaching ever undertaken by a Minister' in the portfolio. He repeats this statement later in the document:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . my own consultations involved the most sustained and extensive round of meetings with the Aboriginal and Islander community ever undertaken personally by a Government Minister.

I commend the consultation, but would remind the Senate that this most extensive consultation ever undertaken with the Aboriginal people went from precisely 23 January to 10 March. Commendable as that is, it is a tragic reflection on the history of our relationship with Aboriginal peoples around the country that such consultation is the most extensive that there has ever been.

I am pleased that the Minister has seen fit to amend the boundaries originally proposed to reflect the requests of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and to recognise historical, cultural, linguistic and other important factors. As Senator Collins has already said, this was a concern reflected in the original statement and it is pleasing to see that this is being taken into account. It is also good to see that the zone councils have been abolished, again at the insistence of Aboriginal people. It is also good to see that the interest of the resident Torres Strait Islanders has been taken much more thoroughly into account. On this whole range of matters I think that the statement and the Minister's efforts deserve praise.

There are a number of matters, however, which have not been addressed and need to be dealt with. The economic development corporation that has been proposed leads one to think about Western capitalist-style economics being transferred on to Aboriginal traditional cultural and trade patterns. I wonder whether a dependence upon the sort of economic model which has already wreaked such havoc on the environment in this country socially, and in terms of the poverty, homelessness and all the other problems that we in the non-Aboriginal community suffer as a result of our economic system, and the introduction of an economic development corporation, will promote that same sort of model within Aboriginal communities. Will it lead to the same sorts of homelessness, unemployment and despair which already exist in many communities, and indeed which still exist in our communities? I would like to see a greater effort made to discuss the implications for traditional lifestyles of the sort of economic development that is being proposed.

My other worry about the economic development corporation is whether the development of the Aboriginal people will depend on the sorts of economies that may be generated in local areas. I hope that Aboriginal people will not be expected to resource their communities 100 per cent when taxpayers around the country subsidise residents in small States. On a per capita basis Tasmanians get a bigger share of tax revenue than do people from New South Wales. Anomalies of that sort exist quite rightly and deliberately around the country to take account of the different population densities and all the rest. I hope and suggest that the Aboriginal people should at least be guaranteed a certain percentage of the take, and perhaps should be represented at Premiers Conferences every year to negotiate formulae for disbursement of taxes. That was something of a digression on my part because the model I would prefer to see is one of Aboriginal sovereignty.

Senator Tambling made some point about dispossession and compensation. He of course was talking about the dispossession of and compensation for more recent owners of their land-farmers, companies, whoever owns it at the moment-and Senator Tambling is concerned about dispossession of their land and compensation for their land. It would be an interesting exercise to do the mathematics to see what sort of compensation is proposed for people who have been dispossessed of their land in order that it may be returned to its original owners. If the mathematical formula was carried through to its logical conclusion and the same level of compensation was granted to Aboriginal people for the whole of the Australian continent, I think that would be a substantial claim for compensation for dispossession.

Senator Tambling also talked about the costs involved in the reorganisation of the consultation process with Aboriginal people. I think no cost is too great to achieve justice for the Aboriginal people and for us to gain self-respect as a non-Aboriginal community. I do not believe that there is any room for negotiation. I think we have a duty and a moral obligation to pay whatever price is necessary for just an adequate compensation to the Aboriginal people for the dispossession of their land. That leads us to the preamble. Senator Tambling cautioned us about creating a precedent in recognising an antecedent legal title. I suggest that this is the precise heart of the matter: as a first step and as the basis of any following discussion we should recognise the antecedent legal title of the Aboriginal people. We should dispense with the legal fiction of terra nullius and accept as a non-Aboriginal community that the Aboriginal people were living here in a number of communities, entire and whole, and that they were forcibly, violently and horribly dispossessed of land which was theirs by right-dispossessed by invasion, by the use of firearms, by the use of disease and by the use of economic weapons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say `by the use of disease'?
—Yes, I did.
—And do you imply by that the deliberate use of disease as a form of genocide against the Aboriginal population by our European ancestors?
—I am implying that.
—That seems to be an extremely serious charge.
—It is an extremely serious charge.
—Have you any evidence?

—I do not want to get into a debate. I have already cited some of the evidence and Noel Butlin's book Our Original Aggression: Aboriginal Populations of South-Eastern Australia. There has been a fair bit of academic debate over Noel Butlin's work and I am quite happy to provide Senator Stone with a quite extensive range of material and articles which discuss Noel Butlin's propositions. However, I do not think that Senator Stone should become too upset about the allegation of deliberate use of disease in the colonisation process because there is ample, adequate and in fact irrefutable evidence that the British and other colonists of North America and elsewhere deliberately used disease-namely, smallpox-to achieve their ends. There is incontrovertible and ample evidence that smallpox infected blankets were deliberately given to American indians.
—What a load of garbage!
—I think Senator Stone is demonstrating the limits of his understanding of the world outside his narrow financial world. Senator Stone says, `What a load of garbage'.
—I do indeed-and I am glad that you repeated it.
—Sadly, that demonstrates Senator Stone's unwillingness to accept the record of history and accept truths, however painful they may be.
—I am totally prepared to accept the record of history; I am not prepared to accept a lot of smears on our ancestors put forward by smart alec academics.

—If Senator Stone is offended by the proposition that colonisers deliberately used disease in their colonisation of places around the world, he is rightly offended by his heritage and my heritage. However, as an aside, my heritage is a bit more complex, with Irish grandparents from Enniskillen, mother from Italy and a father from the north of England.
—A very much publicised mix.
—Yes, a very much publicised mix. I once sat next to Al Grassby on a plane-
—Don't mention Mr Grassby in this place.

—Senator Stone says that I should not mention Al Grassby; I probably should be careful about what I say about him. Al Grassby was quite taken by the fact that my ancestry was Italian, Irish and English because he said they were the three largest migrant population groups in this country. I am quite proud of them.
—You have got all three in one.
—Yes, all three in one.
—It's your citizenship that we are worried about, not your ancestry.
—I am definitely an Australian citizen. On two occasions I affirmed allegiance to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth, so I must be a good Australian.
—It's a bit late in the day.

—That may be-perhaps I should have renounced my allegiance to Queen Elizabeth much earlier and then reaffirmed it much earlier, too. It would be interesting to take up this matter with Her Majesty when she is here, but I doubt whether that will occur.
—I shall be seeing her a couple of times. I might do it for you.

—Yes, please talk to Her Majesty about it. I return to the notion of the antecedent legal title and the fiction of terra nullius. I am sorry to cast some darkness over Senator Stone's bright vision of history, but unfortunately there are some dark shadows which he may not wish to accept but which the rest of us must. The Aboriginal people were violently and horribly dispossessed of land which was theirs by right. As a community, we must acknowledge that.

SPEECH.PARA: Much has also been made about the traditional versus the non-traditional lifestyles of the Aboriginal people. There is a bit of a myth around that somehow Aboriginal people who live in a predominantly urban environment are somehow less Aboriginal than those who live in a more traditional environment and continue the ceremonial and ritual traditions of over 40,000 years. Many Aboriginal people have been cut off from many of their traditional ceremonies and rituals. I worked for a number of years in an urban environment with Aboriginal communities and it taught me a great deal about culture and its survival in fairly adverse circumstances. Traditional Aboriginal values have survived, and they continue to survive and operate in places where the ceremony and ritual no longer do.

It is a harder notion to grasp, but when we look at so-called traditional communities where the traditional ceremony and ritual continue we see a substrata of values underlying the ceremony and the ritual. The ceremony and the ritual support the values and the values support the ceremony and the ritual. This is the way in which culture works. In urbanised Aboriginal communities the values are still strong and are still transmitted from generation to generation. The cultural identity is strong and I am concerned-it may be that I have not looked at the material from Mr Hand's office closely enough-that in the rush to develop this legislation traditional value systems may get lost in the sorts of structures that may be generated to deal with these sorts of reforms.

I would like to see a continuation of what Senator Collins called a slow and steady approach. I believe that the consultation has to go on for a much longer time than until September of this year. I can understand the symbolic imperative to try to have something achieved in 1988-the 200th anniversary of the invasion. That would be a great symbolic gesture. I have advocated that we set ourselves on a new course and in a new direction this year and that this be the year in which we decide that things will change. But I do not think that we have to have all the i's dotted and the t's crossed and the whole structure in place to be able to make an in-principle commitment and to start the process rolling. I think the process has begun. I commend this Minister and the Government for what they have achieved. I commend the Minister for ignoring some of the rhetoric that has been thrown around by others in his Party and others perhaps higher in his Government and for proceeding with sensitivity and commitment on the course that he has taken. I look forward to further progress reports from the Minister in his consultations. I urge that in the common quest for justice for the Aboriginal people we do not go too far too fast. This would promote the sort of conservative backlash which would prevent significant achievement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by picking up some of Senator Tambling's words. He pointed out that this was an interim report which stood between, on the one hand, the statement made by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) last year in announcing the development of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) and, on the other hand, the actual establishment of that Commission. This is a report on the progress of that process. In speaking after Senator Collins, Senator Tambling said that there appeared to be a degree of bipartisanship. The only disagreement I have with Senator Tambling's remark is that I would have said `tripartisanship' because the Australian Democrats are also giving this statement cautious and qualified support. It certainly moves in the right direction. Having heard Senator Wood speak and represent his Party, and presuming that the National Party of Australia is also supporting the proposal, we might talk about a `pentapartisanship' because there seems to be a wide degree of support for this statement.

SPEECH.PARA: What needs to be recognised-and I think it is coming through many of the speeches-is that we are a group of Europeans in this Parliament who are addressing this issue. We must ask to what extent the debate has been taken back to those affected-the Aboriginal groups-whether it is adequate and, particularly, whether the time and the processes of consultation have been sufficient. Several speakers have pointed to the fact that we are in our Bicentenary year and that we are now 200 years on in the period of white settlement in Australia.

This year, 1988, represents a crossroads. For a moment, I would like to point to some of my limited experience in talking to Aboriginal people about this year and the directions which Australia needs to take as an integrated society. A view which I have put forward, both in this place and outside, in relation to the differences between Aboriginal and European cultures the integration of those cultures and the Bicentenary is that there is abundant evidence that the dominant, largely European exploitative culture which has come into this country in the last 200 years has within it the seeds of its own destruction. This is contrary to what we find in traditional cultures, not only in the Aboriginal culture but in traditional cultures generally which have survived for a long period-in the case of the Aborigines probably at least 40,000 years. Such cultures have developed attitudes and relationships with each other, with other tribes and with the natural environment which have guaranteed their survival in the long term without seriously, and I stress seriously, depleting the ability of their environment to support their continuation.

I am aware that some environmental damage was wrought in Australia by Aborigines, and has been wrought in other countries. I instance the damage which occurred in North America as a consequence of the invasion of the Red Indians from Asia about 11,000 years ago. But by and large there was a balance with the environment and an ability to survive. There was a caring for the environment which became built into the culture. By contrast, in the last few hundred years, Europeans have developed an attitude of exploitation to anything that can be exploited whether it be a racially disadvantaged group, such as the Aborigines, a sexually disadvantaged group, such as women, or an economically disadvantaged group, such as migrants or people who have recently entered the country and people who are less skilled. Also it could be some aspect of the environment, such as trees in Tasmania or north Queensland or the living animal environment. We tend to look at these as items to be turned into immediate short term gain. As I have indicated, there is abundant evidence that that attitude contains within it the seeds of its own destruction.

It seems to me that 1988, the Bicentenary year, is an excellent year in which to address the proposition that, if we are to develop a society in Australia which has within it the seeds of its long term survival, it is vitally necessary that the dominant European culture pick up those elements which are caring and which look after the environment. It would be extremely useful to the dominant culture if it were to pick up those elements from the Aboriginal culture. At the same time-and I am speaking now as a European-we would be holding out the hand of understanding to Aborigines. We would not be saying, as we have in the past, `You have nothing at all to offer us. If you want to integrate into the culture, you must come 100 per cent across to our way of doing things'. Rather, we should be saying to Aborigines, `Within your culture there are elements which not only are vital to you but are now, we recognise, vital to us, and we will work together towards a new and integrated culture which contains the best elements of both'.

I am not in any way denying that there are extremely valuable elements in our culture. We do not want to play down the creativity which we find in European culture. But there is no rational or logical reason why it should not be possible to put these two elements together and build not only a creative and vibrant culture but one which contains within it this element of caring for the environment, caring for each other and guaranteeing our long term survival.

When I have taken that view to Aboriginal people I have been met with two sorts of responses. On the one hand, many of them have said, `Yes, that is indeed the way we would like to go, too. We would like to see a culture which incorporates some elements of our culture and we accept that these are elements which you need in your culture. We are prepared to work with you for the achievement of that end'. But the other response that I have received is one of considerable anger and frustration. Aboriginal people well educated in the white culture-urban Aborigines, particularly-have fairly bluntly said, `Okay, that would have been all right 20 years ago, but now it is too late'. Essentially, the expression is one of war between the European dominant culture and the Aboriginal culture. It is not at all surprising that we have come to this very sad situation.

Senator Collins mentioned that on many occasions he had expressed concern not only about Aboriginal deaths in custody but also about Aboriginal deaths out of custody and the conditions of life which have brought that situation about. I would just like to deal briefly with a situation concerning a group of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders which came to my attention in recent weeks and which illustrates the urgency of the plight of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders with the dominant culture and the way in which many of those problems are simply not being addressed. This case concerns a group of 18 young students-nine from Darwin, six from Queensland and three from the Torres Strait-who had come down to study at the Port Adelaide Aboriginal College. All of them were a long way from home, from their family and from their cultural roots and at the beginning of a new academic year were thrown into a strange and alien situation.

No preparations for accommodation were made up to four days before the students arrived in Port Adelaide. Within four days of their arrival it was suddenly discovered that there was no accommodation for them. A home which had been housing mentally retarded people was quickly emptied out and the students were put into it in about the middle of February. There were no facilities for studying at the home and students of different sexes were put into one room. I am told that the provision of food and other facilities was totally inadequate.

Having been a student many years ago and coming from Perth to Adelaide to study medicine, I know the feeling of being a young student in a place away from home and having to cope with those pressures. But imagine the plight of these students who had the extra burden of operating in an alien culture where, by and large, the dominant culture does not look particularly kindly on them. An Aboriginal gentleman who had come down from Queensland and was living in the vicinity was kind enough to extend hospitality to those students. He took them out of the situation they were in and put them into his own home. He looked after them and provided them with meals and accommodation. That situation persisted for several weeks before eventually some of the students were accommodated by Aboriginal Hostels Ltd in a facility in north Adelaide, which is some distance away from where they had to study. Some others were accommodated in private homes.

Mr Glen Williams, the Aboriginal man from Queensland, did this-and it is interesting that, again, this reflects a difference in cultural attitude between Aborigines and whites-because, by and large, Aborigines are much better at looking after fellow Aborigines than whites are. He tells me that, as a consequence of his kindness and action, he is now some $2,500 to $3,000 in debt. That sort of situation-the desperation in which those students found themselves and the desperation in which Mr Glen Williams now finds himself, having suffered a substantial financial penalty for looking after some of his fellow Aborigines-is a very sad reflection on our society and the way in which we have dealt with these problems. One can only express a hope that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission will deal better with these sorts of problems in the future.

Senator Tambling has reflected on the time scale. Certainly, the Democrats had become very alarmed at the Minister's earlier proposal that the introduction of this legislation be arranged so that the Commission could begin on 1 July. It seemed quite evident to us that the consultative process could not be adequately carried out by then. We made representations to the Minister that the date be put back to 1 January. It is pleasing to see that that has been done. However, I think we would express similar concerns to those expressed by Senator Tambling, namely, that the timetable for elections for the Commission in October, November and December and, therefore, for the necessary passage of legislation in September does not allow a great deal of time for these now modified plans to be taken back to Aboriginal groups and for adequate consultation to take place so that the legislation, when introduced, properly reflects their wishes. Clearly, that is the point: it does not matter so much what we white Europeans in this Parliament think about this. What is really important is whether it fits the needs of the Aboriginal communities.

It is pleasing to see that the Minister has modified the arrangement for the election for commissioners and expanded the size of the Commission so that now we have a proposed Commission which will be predominantly elected by Aboriginal communities. It is also pleasing to see, as Senator Collins pointed out, that more natural boundaries which are more in keeping with the wishes of Aboriginal people have been drawn and that the number of groups has been expanded from 28 to 56.

The powers which reside with the Commission are somewhat ill-defined in this paper and the door is certainly left open for the Minister to exercise considerable powers over the Commission. The Minister says that there are two categories of Commission functions. The first category is those functions on which the Minister can make specific directions-in other words, direct the Commission. Clearly, in those cases the Minister could so direct the Commission that it would have very little room in which to manoeuvre. One hopes that Mr Hand is not such a Minister and would not do that, but clearly this must serve the needs of Aborigines long after this Minister has left the office. Secondly, there are those functions on which the Commission will make final decisions and about which the Minister may make only a general direction. If most of the Commission's deliberations are of the second kind, the Commission will have a great deal of latitude. If most of the decisions are of the first kind, the Minister may exercise a considerable power.

The question of Torres Strait Islander independence, or a move towards independence, is addressed partially in the statement. The Australian Democrats have been persuaded that there is a substantial move among Torres Strait Islanders for a greater degree of independence. We have at least floated the idea of a separate commission to meet that need and of allowing that separate commission to evolve along somewhat more independent lines. The Minister has met that by offering an advisory body within the Commission-the Torres Strait Islander Advisory Board, which will be directly responsible to and will advise the Minister. To what extent that will meet the wishes of Torres Strait Islanders is yet to be discovered. Again, further consultation is required for that to be ascertained. The matter of the preamble is addressed by the Minister in fairly severe terms when he says:

I am bound to say that the Government remains committed to a preamble which does no more than recite the facts which have led to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of this nation being the most disadvantaged socio-economic group within the Australian community.

The opening words-`I am bound to say that the Government remains committed to a preamble'-seem to leave very little room for negotiation in relation to the preamble. Senator Tambling has raised the question of what force the preamble would have in law. My understanding is that a preamble which is not actually written into the Act itself, while it would be unusual, would have no force in law. It may act as some sort of guidance to a court interpreting the Act which followed it, but it would have very little force in law. I am aware that many in the Aboriginal community are disappointed that at this time the Government is not prepared to write something into the legislation which recognises prior Aboriginal occupation and the claims which flow from it. I pick up Senator Wood's point that it seems strange that we should be so concerned about the proprietary rights of those who have come to this country so recently and yet we seem blinkered and unable to see the proprietary rights which would flow quite naturally from the recognition of 40,000 years of occupation which, as I have pointed out earlier, has been much more benign on this country than 200 years of white occupation.

In summary, the Democrats support the statement. We hope that this is a move in the right direction and that it does open up the opportunities which the Aboriginal people are looking for. We believe that it may be necessary to extend the time still further. There may not be sufficient time for adequate consultation over the actual legislation before this comes into place, and certainly that should be done if it is demanded. There should be no pressure to cut short the time if Aboriginal people want more time. With those provisos, it seems to us that the Minister has gone a long way to meeting at least the first round of criticisms, objections and changes which the Aboriginal people themselves have asked for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) on the statement that he has made and support the attitude that he exhibits in relation to this question. It is an attitude that must give Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders a great deal of hope for the future. I can never involve myself in a debate on the rights of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders without thinking of my involvement with the former Federal Council for the Advancement of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, particularly in the 1960s when there was very little support for the cause. Governments gave no support and there was no recognition, even though a number of Labor politicians gave their support personally and were very much appreciated for it.

SPEECH.PARA: One thinks of the history of Aboriginal people and their treatment and compares that with what the foreshadowed legislation will provide. There is no doubt that Aboriginal people suffered terrible cruelty, exploitation and, to a lesser extent, lack of concern from the white community in this country. They were on settlements run by governments and, in some cases, churches. Even though they may have thought they were doing good, sometimes they were very cruel, unthinking and unconcerned for those they claimed publicly to be helping. They were bureaucratic in their attitude to the way those people were handled.

It is unfortunate that Senator Stone has left the chamber. I was rather concerned at his lack of knowledge of the treatment of Aborigines. He took Senator Wood to task, by way of interjection, when he spoke about disease. I suggest that white people in the community used methods that were quicker and more final. Some people and groups of people-not all, of course-saw Aboriginals in the 1800s as nuisances and obstacles in the way of accumulating wealth. They gave them poisoned flour and poisoned waterholes because they said that Aboriginals, in their hunting procedure, frightened the beasts that they were raising for profit away from the waterholes. That has been written into our history and is accepted by the community, if not by Senator Stone.

One also looks at some of the organisations which have been put in place by governments over the years which, they have claimed, were put there for the service of Aboriginal interests. Again, there was no consultation, no consideration of the rights of individuals and no democracy for Aboriginals who were governed by those organisational tools that were put in place.

As I have said, when I was involved with the former Federal Council for the Advancement of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, which met in Canberra each Easter in the 1960s, the one thing about which they were concerned was land rights. They were deeply concerned about the right of Aboriginals to make decisions about their life and that they should be recognised in the community as Caucasians, white people, were. At that time a struggle was going on by the Gurindji people of Wattie Creek on the Wave Hill Station. They were seeking land which they felt was theirs historically and which had sacred implications for them. They did not get much help other than from certain progressive organisations in the community, including the trade union movement. They struggled for some months, which ran into more than a year, and finally they were given some land on Wave Hill Station at Wattie Creek. They are still there using that land in their traditional ways of sharing and caring for people. At the same time there was a struggle for equal pay for stockmen going on and the North Australian Workers Union played quite a good role in this, as did the Australian Workers Union. There was a struggle to get equal pay for Aboriginal stockmen because in some cases their wages were only 25 per cent of those of white stockmen. This was despite the fact that Aboriginal stockmen had to teach white stockmen how to do their work and had to find the white stockmen when they got lost. Yet all they were paid was a pittance of 25 per cent of the white stockmen's rate of pay.

Those were the times when the Aboriginals struggled. All through their struggles they were looking for the right to express their point of view, the right to make decisions for themselves and the right to be heard. The foreshadowed legislation goes to that question. It goes to the question of an involvement in decision-making in a way that is meaningful. There is a lot said in this place, when we talk about legislation, about its effectiveness-whether it is properly drafted and whether there is enough detail. I would assert that any legislation passed in this chamber, regardless of how good the written word may be and all the care that is taken with it, will not achieve what it was intended it should achieve unless it is enacted in the way it is intended, unless the people that have to use that legislation in their day to day lives understand it, believe in it and work for it. Of course, the Minister has done that. He said clearly in the first part of his statement that the ATSIC proposal would not go ahead if it did not receive a positive endorsement from the Aboriginal and Islander community. He showed a concern in that regard for what they wanted. That was the nature of the legislation they wanted. That is what the legislation would provide. Obviously, if one looks at the culture of the Aboriginal people, one realises that they have never really asked a lot for themselves. They have certainly wanted things for their collective because they have always had a culture of sharing and caring and not one of accumulating wealth or possessions.

The Minister, of course, has made this statement following the consultations that he described at a time when there was quite a vigorous outcry from the Torres Strait Islander community and they were able to outline how they had been disadvantaged and not been given a fair go by successive governments over many years. They were asking for independence. The Minister was able to talk to them and get their views. It has been agreed as a result of that consultation that there will be a special Torres Strait Island regional council and that they will have a commissioner elected by their own people. I will quote from the Minister's statement:

Members of the House will recall that I visited the Torres Strait islands twice during January and February. I now inform the House of details of the proposal agreed to at the second meeting held on Thursday Island.

The interests of resident Torres Strait Islanders will be represented by the Torres Strait Islander commissioner, who will be elected by the Torres Strait regional council. There will also be an Office of Torres Strait Islander Affairs created within ATSIC, to ensure that the Commission and other Government programs adequately address the needs of Torres Strait islanders . . .

That is the bottom line-it has to address their needs and has to give satisfaction. When I read that statement I cast my mind back to a visit I made to the Torres Strait Islands some two years ago when the people said that they were very pleased with the Labor Government because Bob Hawke had given deferred pay to some amongst their community. I had not heard the term `deferred pay' used since just after the last war when a lot of the soldiers who fought in the war to protect this country were given a payment, as a deferred payment. But those people from the Torres Strait Islands, who, of course, in those days were not even counted in the census, were not given anything. They were given the right to fight and risk their lives but no recognition in the same terms as people in the Australian community who had white skins. The Hawke Government provided that payment. For that they were grateful. They were grateful from the point of view that at last they had been recognised on equal terms with white Australians.

In the Minister's statement he makes it clear that the regional councils will be set up. They are organisations which will be close to the rank and file of the Aboriginal people, in which decisions can be made and in which everybody will have an input and be proud of whatever results. If the result is not good, the people will have to live with that; they will have to fix that; they will not be able to blame other people. Therefore, that proposal for democracy at the lowest possible level in the community is excellent. The Minister in his statement went on to point out that, of the 15-member Commission, 12 would be elected. So it is very clear that appointments by the Minister will certainly not create a situation where he will have any control over, or undue influence on, what those bodies decide. The Minister went on in his usual open and honest way-an attitude which I believe goes down well with honest and reasonable people-to say:
The issues that were raised during my first visit-
to the Torres Strait Islands-
will be dealt with at another time.
