He does not try to say, `We have fixed everything up; this Commission will fix everything up'. He recognises that there are still problems but that, with an honest and open approach and with cooperation, those problems will be solved. He then went on to say:

In a very real sense, these changes represent a complete overhaul of the existing relationship between the Federal Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. No longer will they be held at arm's length from Government-
that has always been their concern and their criticism-
under the guise of `advisory' bodies and the like.

Even within the Islander community bureaucrats can grow up and subvert the sort of activity intended to benefit all Islanders, not just a few. Of course, the same applies to the Aboriginal community. The Minister continued:
No longer will the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people be excluded from the executive decision-making processes of government.
What the Minister is saying is that they will have access to the Government. That is correct. That is how it should be. The Minister continued:
The process as a whole far exceeds all the consultations ever undertaken in respect of any previous Federal or State legislation dealing with matters affecting Aboriginal people.

Again he has made the point that that has been the situation up to now. The critical aspect of it is that it continues so that nobody can ever say-in any community, let alone the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities which have all these difficulties that they have tried to address over the years-that it is possible to come up with a plan or proposition that fixes everything up. However, if we have the right attitude, a sharing and caring attitude, an open attitude and one which shows concern for the people whom one serves, all things are possible. Solutions can be found and, I believe, will be found under the administration of the Minister. I am sure that the Aboriginal people will be hoping that he remains in that post for some time. It will certainly be a fruitful relationship between the Aboriginal people and our Minister, Gerry Hand.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Construction of Radio and Orchestra facilities for the ABC and SBS at Ultimo, New South Wales

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act, I present the report relating to the construction of radio and orchestra facilities for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service at Ultimo, New South Wales. I seek leave to have a short statement incorporated in Hansard and I table the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows:-
The report which I have just tabled relates to the approval by the Committee of the construction of radio and orchestra facilities for the ABC and SBS at Ultimo, New South Wales.

The Committee has concluded that the project will lead to a more efficient use of resources resulting in economies which it is expected will substantially pay for the new complex. The project will be funded on an instalment purchase basis and not from the budget. The ABC advised the Committee that savings of $10.2m per annum are expected as a result of the co-location of ABC radio and SBS radio and these will be offset against the cost of the project.

The Committee has noted the concern of the ABC staff union regarding the achievement of the project cost savings and the Committee recognises that the realisation of the potential savings will depend greatly on cooperation between management, staff and their unions.

The Committee has also drawn attention to the failure of the consultation process between ABC and the ABC staff union and believes that meaningful consultation must take place if this project is to succeed.

It was suggested to the Committee that the project should not proceed during the current review of national broadcasting policy. This matter was given serious consideration by the Committee but it has accepted advice from the ABC that the design of the complex is sufficiently flexible to accommodate modifications should these be necessary.

In conclusion, on behalf of the Committee I would like to congratulate the ABC Board for responding to the needs of staff by agreeing to provide child care facilities in the Ultimo project. These facilities will replace existing child care facilities sponsored by the ABC staff union.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) relating to the implementation of the Hamilton report and to move a motion that the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
In November 1985 the Minister for Defence commissioned a study into the problems facing spouses of service personnel.

The Minister realised that circumstances have changed. In the past, service families were expected without question to up stumps and follow the colours, wherever they led and whatever the family circumstances. That is no longer the case, and nor should it be. Community expectations have changed, and so have the expectations of service families.

The study the Minister commissioned was undertaken by Mrs Sue Hamilton of the Office of the Status of Women over a period of 5 months. The Hamilton study broke new ground. It identified, for the first time, all of the issues that service in the Australian Defence Force creates for the spouses and families of its members. It recognised that ADF policy should pay real attention to the needs of the spouse and family, to their quality of life and to the effect on them of a member's service in the ADF.

The Hamilton report had no predecessor, and no substantial research base to work from. No broad examination, investigation or study had looked at the needs and wants of the people who, though they are not bound to the Australian Defence Force by service, are deeply affected by its policy and day to day decisions.

During the course of the study Mrs Hamilton travelled to all States and visited all areas with major concentrations of service personnel, as well as a number of smaller bases in remote locations. Open meetings for spouses were held in every area visited. Attendance at these meetings totalled about 4,300.
Over 700 written submissions were made to the study. Many people took the opportunity to air their views through radio phone-ins around Australia, by private telephone contact, or by office visit.

Contact was not limited to individuals. Mrs Hamilton also had discussions with commanding officers, administrative staff and other serving personnel in the areas she visited; with chaplains and welfare staff attached to bases; and with civilian agencies in areas around bases.
The Hamilton report is thorough. I am pleased to report that the Government's actions in response to the recommendations of the report have been flexible and comprehensive.
The first recommendation Mrs Hamilton made was for a clear directive to be given at ministerial level that the issue of family morale in the Australian Defence Force is one of high priority.

My colleague the Minister for Defence gave his personal commitment. The Government expressed its commitment by appointing me Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. My actions since assuming this ministry confirm that commitment.

Since my appointment I have made extensive visits to defence bases throughout Australia to talk to service members and their families and to gauge for myself the issues that concern them and the problems they face.
These visits have given me a vital insight into the sheer size of the Defence community, and the variety of places in which service families live and work.

These visits have taught me that, above all, our efforts to improve the quality of life for Defence families must be adaptable. They must allow for the local and regional differences between the many places-from capital cities to remote and isolated communities-that service life takes people to.

Different places require different assistance, and people moving from one place to another have different needs in different places. Service life can mean you move from Canberra to Puckapunyal, and then to Townsville or Melbourne.
The operational and training needs of a service career demand postings. Many, if not most, of the unique difficulties that affect service families derive from this inevitable need for postings.
The Hamilton report recognised the problem, and its importance. The Chief of the Defence Force recognises it, and so does this Government.

Following the Hamilton report we employed an independent firm of management consultants to examine the policies on promotions and postings in the three Services. They concluded that the incidence of postings is at a level consistent with the operational and training needs of the ADF.
At the same time, they made recommendations to assist in achieving a balance between the requirements of service and domestic life.

The Chief of the Defence Force has determined that postings will be for three years, subject to operational exigencies. Further, a policy of back to back postings in the same locality will be pursued wherever possible, giving those who want it stability for up to six years.

I do not want to give the impression that moving from place to place is necessarily an unwelcome thing. Many Defence families, many of their children, enjoy the variety of a service life, and the range of experiences they gain from it.
What the Government must try to do is to find the best way we can to ease unnecessary burdens and pressures on families when they are posted.

One very important means of helping a family to adjust to a new location is to provide as much information as possible to the family about the place it is going to. Families need to know about schooling, about the availability of employment for spouses, about child care and community services.

The Hamilton report identified this need and made recommendations about it. They have been implemented. The Government has set up the Australian Defence Force Family Information and Liaison Staff (ADFILS), to provide community development and education support for service families throughout Australia.

ADFILS headquarters in Canberra coordinates an extensive network of full and part time professional staff. The recruitment program to fill all the positions that have been created is well advanced. In all there will be:
one senior community development coordinator and six community development coordinators
eight regional education liaison officers
thirty community development officers

In addition, 51 family liaison officers (FLOS) have been established in the Services to act as the first point of contact for families. They will operate as a supplement to the support systems that have been run by the individual Services for many years.

The regional education liaison officers (REDLOS) will provide professional advice and assistance to service families and to FLOS, establish and monitor the education needs of families, and represent those needs to State governments and authorities.

The community development coordinators (CDCS) will provide the essential link between civilian and service communities, and ensure the smooth delivery of support services for defence families. They will also select, train and monitor the thirty community development officers (CDOS) who will be based in areas of major service concentration.

This extensive professional network will be a boon for mobile families. It will make reliable information easy to obtain, and assistance readily available to any family that needs it. ADFILS is a very important source of direct support to service personnel and their families, and I confidently predict that, once it is fully operational (and that will be soon), the network will prove to be the most valuable resource government has ever provided to service families.

It is essential that all members of the ADF know about ADFILS and the service it has to offer. Communication is effected through ADFILS outposted staff, by the regular publication of a newsletter and by frequent contributions by ADFILS to the three service newspapers. I make it my business whenever I visit a base to talk to servicemen and servicewomen and to spouses groups to raise with them family issues, so that everyone I can reach is up-to-date with their entitlements.

Close attention has been given to the prompt settlement of claims for compensation submitted as a result of loss or damage to goods during removal. The Spouses Working Party on Removals on which services spouses are represented keeps a close eye on the efficiency of removals. There is evidence that all aspects of removals have improved considerably.

Disruptions to children's education can be a major problem for service parents. The frequent requirement for interstate postings means children, particularly those at important points in their schooling, may suffer disadvantages. We are taking action to minimise any bad effects.
My consultant, Mrs Helen Mayer, is currently working on obtaining agreement with State education authorities on reporting processes.

We have developed a pilot scheme to introduce a student portfolio into schools with a high service population. The portfolio will contain examples of students' work and interests that will be portable from school to school. This will assist teachers to place students at the right level and give them vital information about what a student has learnt at the previous school and what has been missed out.
The student information portfolio has been introduced in every State and Territory and has been enthusiastically received by service parents.

I would like to see a common-core curriculum introduced in high schools that have a high defence population. This will involve complex negotiations with the directors-general of education in each of the States but it is the direction I want to pursue.

The student portfolio is only one of a number of initiatives we have taken in an area that is clearly of great concern to defence parents. I have introduced an extra tuition allowance payable for children in the last two years of primary or in any stage of secondary school who move as a result of a posting. Where needed extra tuition for up to six weeks will be available, with tuition fees being reimbursed up to a maximum of $40 a week.

The eligibility criteria for education allowance have been broadened. In the past, education allowance was restricted to children who would suffer serious interference to their education if required to change schools as a result of a posting.

The new provisions give the approving authority greater discretion also to consider the impact of the member's next posting where that is likely to cause serious interference. This will particularly help members on short duration postings to remote areas, such as Tindal.

In writing her report, Mrs Hamilton talked to many service spouses to find out what they thought. This process of consultation proved so useful that Mrs Hamilton recommended the establishment of a National Consultative Group of Service Spouses (NCGSS).

This group was established in 1986 and its expenses are funded by the Department of Defence. Members come from all over the country. The aim of the group is to improve the quality of life for service spouses and their families. The group provides a forum for their views and a mechanism to make recommendations to me and to CDF. Service spouses thus are in a position to influence the policies that directly affect service families.
As you can tell from what I have listed so far, the Government's implementation of Mrs Hamilton's report has been both flexible and comprehensive.
We have set up support networks and employed professional help, as well as introducing new conditions of service where that is a more effective and appropriate response.

Child care is an issue that shows how this combination of responses works. Approval has been obtained for reimbursement of child care expenses for up to two days during removals where only one spouse is available to do the moving.

Discussions on the child care needs of service families were held with the then Department of Community Services in the wake of the Hamilton report. A number of centres was identified where there was a mutual service and civilian interest in community child care. Centres which have been or are soon to be established as a result of these discussions include Townsville, Katherine, Wagga, Nowra, Rockingham and Hastings.

I recognise that service families have to compete for places at these centres and that they are disadvantaged by their frequent removals. Nevertheless, these facilities do contribute to meeting the needs of service families living in these areas.

I am currently working on a comprehensive defence policy on provision of child care support for defence families. I am committed to improving the level of support available to defence families in recognition of the special pressures which defence force employment imposes in a society which is changing. Self-help will continue to be an important element though, in my view, some employer support by defence is also warranted. I hope to have policy guidelines formulated in time for consideration in the lead up to the August Budget.

Meanwhile approval has been given for licensed family day care schemes to operate from service married quarters and for surplus defence facilities to be used to house child care centres. Limited child care facilities have already been established at some bases. I opened the new centre at Swanbourne in Western Australia earlier this year. Next month I go to Enoggera to open the occasional care centre and kindergarten there.

Because of their mobility services spouses often find that they are discriminated against in obtaining employment. This is not only unfair but a terrible waste of talent. Recently I met a service spouse at HMAS Stirling. She told me that she had applied for a job and when asked what her husband did, replied that he was in the Navy. No job was forthcoming. She called again the next day using her maiden name. This time when asked what her husband did she said that he was engaged in underwater research. She got the job.

I am presently undertaking a series of visits to speak with employers about this problem. I am being helped in this regard by the Committee for Employer Support of Reserve Forces. My aim is not preferential treatment but simply to make sure that service spouses get a fair go in employment.

There are several other initiatives which the Government has pursued to improve the lot of service families. Legislation will be introduced shortly to amend the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act. the purpose of the amendment will be to allow retiring members to make an election, up to three months before retirement, to commute a proportion of their pensions to a lump sum for payment on their retirement. This will minimise if not entirely remove any delay between severance and receipt of the commutation lump sum.
Members of the ADF are now entitled to four reunion visits each year if they are separated from their spouses on long term postings.

If the serving member is posted to a remote locality at the time that his or her children are finishing their last years at high school, or if his or her spouse has compelling career obligations, the family might decide that their collective interests are best served by the temporary absence of the serving member. In a case like that reunion visits are a crucial element in maintaining family stability.

To alleviate the disruptions to families who are presently required to move to a new locality when a member is posted, consideration is being given to a proposal that the member be able to decide, having regard to family needs, to defer movement of the family and continue to receive housing assistance at the old locality. This proposal is one of three that are under consideration by my colleague the Minister for Industrial Relations.
Another important recommendation of the Hamilton report also under consideration by the Minister for Industrial Relations is disturbance allowance.

With regard to disturbance allowance, the rates for the third, fourth, fifth and sixth moves are being reviewed. Possible inequities relating to members without families are also being considered. The overall aim is to fairly reimburse service personnel for movement necessarily incurred by the need of their employment.
An improved means of recognising and compensating members for the costs involved in the movement of their household pets is also under consideration.

One of the additional costs associated with the removals is that involved in complying with State regulations. Drivers licences are an example. My consultant has been meeting with State authorities to try and obtain a more tolerant approach. If I had my way there would be a national drivers licence for Defence Force personnel. Unfortunately, I have been advised that constitutional difficulties might be encountered in unilaterally pursuing such an objective.

No statement about service families would be complete without talking about housing. The Hamilton report made no specific recommendations about service housing, apart from indicating that there was a problem and that measures to address it were under way.

They certainly are. On 1 January the Defence Housing Authority was set up. The legislation establishing the DHA ensured it the flexibility to manage defence housing commercially, to reduce management costs and delays in deliveries and to improve maintenance.

The Government has pledged that $750m will be made available to the Authority over 10 years for acquisition and building of new houses and for improving our current stock. That is a very significant financial commitment and one that means a lot to defence families.

The reality has far exceeded the promise. $73m was earlier provided for capital expenditure on housing this financial year. An additional $46m for the Authority has just been announced, $10m of which is for essential improvements such as security locks, the extra $36m is for spot purchasing of houses and land for defence families where the need is greatest. This brings to $119m the funds committed to improved defence housing this financial year.

Including the measures implemented in response to the Hamilton report, annual defence expenditure which contributes to supporting service families totals some $193m. That is over $5,000 per year for each married member of the ADF.

But the benefits of what we have done are more than merely economic. The real benefits lie in the process of communication that we have made possible, and in the understanding and flexibility of administration which follows.

The flow of information between families and headquarters is guaranteed, and guaranteed to flow both ways. Spouses are represented at the centre, where policy is decided, and they are supported locally when they need information and help. Commanding officers on bases are involved, and their support is crucial.
The result is a vastly improved system of reciprocal communication. That is the improvement we have made that forms the basis for all other improvements, both now and in the future.

In three years we have addressed problems that have been building up and festering for decades. It is a record of initiative and achievement that we can be very proud of. It is unshakeable evidence that this Government cares about the people whose work it is to defend this country, and their families.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking tonight on the statement from the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) on the implementation of the report of the Hamilton Review of Effect of Service Life on Spouses I would like first of all to draw attention to the fact that although it is 12 pages long, the first three pages cover the history of the report and its provisions to the Government. Three pages, 25 per cent of this statement, relate to what has gone on in the past, before the Minister gets to the substance of the report. One page is virtually a re-run of a Press release about the setting up by the Government of the Australian Defence Forces Families Information and Liaison Staff (ADFILS). The Minister put out that very detailed release long before today but has used it again today to pad up this statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I get too unkind about the statement I would like to set it in context and to draw the Senate's attention to what the Chief of Naval Staff says about the Hamilton report and its implementation. The Royal Australian Navy made a submission to the joint parliamentary inquiry into wastage rates in the defence forces, and the Navy's submission contained this paragraph:
Another, more recent example of the inadequacy of the internal committee system is the Hamilton Report. First published in April 1986-
I repeat, 1986-
not one of the financial conditions recommended was implemented until 15 January, 1988.
That is, nearly two years later. The Navy went on to say:
This was not for want of trying by the Services, but it was not until the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, acting in her new portfolio, brought pressure to bear that any progress was made.

That really points to how much effort the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) made on behalf of the defence forces in the matter of their conditions of service and the well-being of their families. The Chief of Naval Staff has made it quite clear that it took a new Minister and a bit of push before anything started really to roll with the Hamilton report and its implementation. So full marks to Mrs Kelly for coming in like a new broom and trying something. The sad thing is that those of us who have been closely associated with this matter know that poor Mrs Kelly was not too successful in what she was able to achieve. When she did get the ball to start rolling, it was only in a very small way, and the things that she got through at the early stages at least were only the things that cost either no money or very little money at all. So she has not been as successful with the implementation of the Hamilton report as perhaps she might have liked and as I certainly would have liked to have seen her. She has had some very real difficulties in that area which I will refer to later.

On page 3 of the statement the Minister said that `the incidence of postings is at a level consistent with the operational and training needs of the ADF'. That was a conclusion from the management consultants who examined the policies on promotions and postings in the three Services. That may be all very well, but that really does not tell us the whole picture. The incidence of postings may have been at a level consistent with the operational and training needs of the Australian Defence Force (ADF), but the statement does not give much attention to the needs of the families and whether the incidence of postings is consistent with their needs. Of course, we know that it is not. We know very well that trying to plug holes, which is one way of describing it, the Services have been trying to fill up the gaps of those who have been departing in such numbers, and this has led to very unacceptable rates of turbulence for postings for service families.

On page 4 of the statement the Minister says that `the Chief of the Defence Force has determined that postings will be for three years, subject to operational exigencies', and that `a policy of back to back postings in the same locality will be pursued wherever possible'. I am very glad about that. I welcome that decision. I recognise that those instructions have gone out to unit commanders in the Services, and if it can be achieved it will be very useful and helpful to service families. However, I have grave doubts about how successful they will be in this area, because the proviso-which was `subject to operational exigencies'-is very real and, in the current state of undermanning in the defence forces, is likely to cause so many problems with allowing postings for three years and back to back postings. I have very grave doubts about how successful they will be in achieving their very worthy aims. That has not long been decided. It is something that in my opinion could have been done long ago, and in many ways it would have saved money, with fewer people moving from posting to posting than has been the case recently.

Page 5 is pretty much the Press release that the Minister put out in the past. I draw your attention, Madam Acting Deputy President, to page 6, where the Minister says that she makes it her business, whenever she visits a base, to talk to servicemen and servicewomen and to spouses groups to raise with them family issues, so that everyone she can reach is up to date with their entitlements. I am very glad, as that is exactly what I urged her to do when she took over the portfolio. It is certainly something I have been doing since I have been in the Senate. My only critical comment is: How does she expect to get the sort of frank exchange of views that she gives the impression she would like to get when the spouses are acutely aware of the guidelines for behaviour in dealing with her when she visits as a Minister. I do not know whether she realises what terrible resentment the issuing of those guidelines caused to defence families. Inevitably, when the Minister these days visits units, those guidelines of how to behave to the visiting Minister and on the putting of questions on notice in advance-very kid glove treatment of the Minister, I might add-will always be in the minds of the service men and women and their families. I am not too sure just how frank a treatment the Minister now receives.

I am glad to see that the Minister claims that attention has been given to the prompt settlement of claims for compensation submitted as a result of loss or damage to goods during removal. Quite a lot of work was done in this area by the previous Government and by this Government in trying to improve the standard of removals. The spouses working party has been doing a lot of very useful work in that area. I am glad that the Minister, after some pushing, I might add, from the spouses working party and also from the Opposition, finally agreed to give a small amount of financial assistance to enable these spouses to inspect furniture repositories around Australia and not to be stranded for lack of a Royal Australian Air Force flight to bring them back to their homes. I recognise that that is an improvement.

However, I discovered recently during the Estimates Committee hearings that the Department of Administrative Services, which has the responsibility for these removals for the client department, was not even aware of the existence of the organisation ADFILS which was set up to assist service families. It was only after I explained what the organisation was all about and suggested that it might try to do a little information exercise in the ADFILS newsletter that I understand that that is now to happen. It seems to me that if the Minister was really on top of her job she would not need the Opposition to tell the Department how to make better arrangements for information to get to her servicemen and their families.

I recognise that in recent weeks the Minister has made some announcements about education matters. I think this is one of the most critical areas in which service families need help. The announcement a while back about extra tuition for children was a step in the right direction, but the freeing up of the criteria for education allowances for boarding is a much more worthwhile and valuable step. At this stage I am not sure just how well it will operate because it has been very hard to find out just what the fine print will be. There has been quite a reasonable education allowance on the books for some years, but when only 87 children in the whole of the defence force families are receiving an education allowance, it is clear-and all the evidence I have shows that it is clear-that the criteria have been implemented far too severely, and a freeing up of that is important. I reserve judgment because I want to see just how it operates. At the same time, I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the allowance needs increasing. It has not been increased for some time. In some way, it has to be allowed to rise with the cost of keeping children in some kind of boarding facility when their families are faced with moves.

Mrs Kelly talks about some of the allowances, such as the disturbance allowance, which will need to be looked at. The disturbance allowance most certainly will have to be looked at. The greatest amount of disturbance allowance available to a family now is $700. That was increased not terribly long ago. A service family kept very precise records for me on a recent move over Christmas. There were two parents and two teenage children. It cost $1,500 to move that family just halfway across Australia. They were eligible for $700. The important point is that these families are moving so often. It is not as if they move once every 10 years or so and perhaps we could expect them to absorb the difference. When they are moving, sometimes once a year, it is a terrible burden to place on families who are not really in receipt of high incomes by anybody's standards.

We all like to think that the family can move the pet with it. There is a pet allowance of something like $70. It cost a family $700 to take a german shepherd from Melbourne to Cairns and it costs $10 a day to keep that dog in kennels while the family is in the process of moving. That may sound a bit trivial but the fact is that those dogs are needed these days for families posted to areas where the married quarters are in very low socioeconomic areas with high crime rates. That is happening in a number of areas. The men are away for such long periods that the families need protection. So big dogs are really quite an integral part of many service families' lives. They give the families a feeling of protection when they have no security locks on their windows and doors and no men to repel intruders.

The Minister on page 8 talks about the expenses of the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses (NCGSS). Obviously she is not aware-and she should be-that although the expenses are funded by the Department of Defence, they are just not good enough. The group's role very much is an information role in the exchange of information with its constituents right around the country. It is very difficult to get messages through to families. So often husbands will not take service newspapers home. Unless families in their homes can be communicated with directly by post there is not much hope of letting them know what their entitlements are and how they can get help if they need it. So just a little thing like a decent postage rate is very important to them. The Minister should be aware of that and do something about it.

There is so much to say about this statement. On page 9 the Minister said that `some employer support by Defence is also warranted'. This concerns spouses who cannot get child-care support. I hope she can convince her Government that there is virtue in providing employer support in the area of child-care. I have grave doubts that she will be able to achieve anything in this area, although I hope she can. I have grave doubts that Senator Walsh and Mr Willis will be very cooperative. It seems to me that when it comes to anything to do with service families, they are the ones who call the tune, not the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and not the Minister for Defence, because he is not interested-and we all know that.

The sad thing about the child-care that is available for Defence Force families is that it has been provided by way of self-help, which is very worthy, but in the two or three centres where it is currently provided, it has been provided mainly so that one-income service families will be able to afford occasional child-care. Because of the requirements of State and Federal governments in the area of child-care, the cost overheads of these child-care centres are so great that the one-income families are unable to afford occasional care. When servicemen are away for weeks on end, or months on end if they are at sea, and a young mother with one or two babies has to go to the doctor, for example if she is pregnant, she needs someone to look after her children-and she cannot afford it. She has no mother or sisters anywhere near-she may be thousands of miles from her home. That is the sort of back up support people in the defence forces particularly need. The Minister says on page 10:
Legislation will be introduced shortly to amend the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act.

I call on the Government to do something about amending it so there can be a restitution of the 2 per cent indexation increase which was whipped off people a year or so ago and which the Government has steadfastly refused to do anything about handing back. That has caused great unhappiness in the defence forces. If the Minister were really able to achieve anything for Defence Force families, that would be one very important thing.

I draw attention to the fact that the Minister talks about four reunion visits a year for families who are separated on long term postings. Mrs Hamilton recommended six. There is no compassionate travel for spouses, although there is for service personnel. If the wife of a corporal or private soldier in Perth wants to get back to the funeral of her mother or father, there is no help whatsoever from the defence forces which have sent her so far from home. There are problems with drivers licences and certainly a number of other areas which I will not have a lot of time to cover tonight. But the Minister talks about what the Government has achieved in the way of defence housing. At this stage, although it has put its foot on the ladder, it really has not taken this very far. There are a lot of things I could talk about if we got into the defence housing area.

But I want to set one matter straight: the Minister has been trumpeting recently about an extra $46m for the Defence Housing Authority. In fact, on page 12 of the statement she says that that has just been announced. I would like the Senate to understand that that is an advance out of the $750m. It is not an extra amount being given to the Defence Housing Authority and there are still no service spouses on the Board of the Defence Housing Authority. The Board still does not have the basis for its finances finalised because it still has not even been worked out whether its funds will be provided as a loan or by way of grant. That is pretty critical for any calculation of its overheads and expenditure and what it can offer in the way of services.

There is so much more that I could say but I just want to remind the Senate that this is the very same Minister who sent a representative, the Deputy Secretary A of her Department, to Holsworthy last year to represent her when service people were so concerned about what was happening to the defence service home loans scheme. That representative told those people, `The Government gives you your conditions of service and the Government can take them away'. It is not much good the Minister putting out a statement that is of such flimsy value when she sends people like that out with such an attitude to talk to the people she is supposedly serving. There are things that can be done. There are innovative ways of rewarding people for their service but the $70,000 bonus for pilots that has been announced today is likely to exacerbate the problems. What about all the other categories of personnel who are also critical to the effectiveness of the Defence Force, who see that there is going to be no re-engagement bonus for them?

The Government waters down claims which go before the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal. The defence forces see that they have a bureaucracy which does not fight for the welfare of their people. That erodes morale and increases resignations. We have to remember that these people have no overtime, penalty rates or union protection. The Hamilton report raised expectations, only to have them dashed. There are a lot of things that still need to be done. I have covered some of them tonight but this statement is really an exercise in public relations. There have been some small improvements but when the Minister gets the support of her senior Minister and her Government, gets some money out of Finance and clears all the hurdles that she faces in industrial relations, she might have something to make a statement about. I seek leave to continue my remark later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 17 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) During the financial year 1986-87 what was the cost of funding Torres Strait Protected Zone Joint Authority to the Commonwealth.

(2) Who is paying under the joint management arrangement between the Commonwealth and Queensland in relation to the Torres Strait Protected Zone, for the fisheries surveillance and enforcement, and in what proportion.

(3) During the financial year 1986-87 (a) how many illegal fishing activities were detected; (b) how many people and boats were apprehended; and (c) how many convictions were achieved and what was the total amount of the fines imposed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The cost to the Commonwealth of funding the Torres Strait Protected Zone Joint Authority's program during 1986-87 was $1,095,324. This comprised $92,463 on capital items, $442,116 on recurrent costs, $91,745 on charter of an interim patrol boat, and $469,000 on scientific research and fishery monitoring programs.

(2) Torres Strait Fisheries Management Cost Sharing Agreement between the Commonwealth and Queensland apportions cost as follows: (a) the Commonwealth fully funds the cost of agreed initial capital items, including the construction of a patrol boat; (b) Queensland and the Commonwealth share equally the cost of replacement of initial capital items and subsequent capital items; and (c) Queensland and the Commonwealth share recurrent costs equally. In addition, the Commonwealth fully funds the cost of the charter of an interim patrol boat.

(3) During the financial year 1986-87 in the Torres Strait Protected Zone: (a) 15 illegal fishing activities were detected; (b) 9 persons and 8 vessels were apprehended; and (c) no convictions were achieved, however, 7 prosecutions were proceeding at the end of the financial year 1986-87.
